title: Game-Changing Controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2023
text: I recently purchased the Nintendo USB Switch Pro Controller, and it has completely changed my gaming experience. As someone who loves playing games on the Nintendo Switch, I've always been a fan of the Joy-Con controllers that come with the console, but I found them to be a bit too small and cramped for extended gaming sessions. That's where the Switch Pro Controller comes in.The first thing I noticed about the controller was how comfortable it is to hold. The grip is smooth and ergonomic, and the buttons are placed in a way that makes them easy to access without feeling like you're reaching too far. The controller also has a good weight to it, making it feel substantial in your hands without being too heavy.One of the standout features of the Switch Pro Controller is its battery life. I've used it for hours on end without needing to charge it, which is a huge improvement over the Joy-Con controllers. And when it does need to be charged, it only takes a couple of hours to get back to full power.The controller is also incredibly responsive, with no noticeable input lag. The buttons and joysticks have a great feel to them, and I've found that it's made a big difference in my gameplay. I'm able to be more precise with my movements and actions, which has helped me improve in games where accuracy is key.Overall, I would highly recommend the Nintendo USB Switch Pro Controller to anyone who spends a lot of time gaming on the Switch. It's a game-changer that will improve your experience and make your gaming sessions more comfortable and enjoyable.

title: The best controller on the market right now
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2019
text: I have large hands, and I find that most controllers are smaller than I'd like (many are much smaller than I'd like). It's been years since I used a controller that I thought was large enough to sit well in my hands (Logitech used to make one that I really liked, but it's probably been at least 15 years since they stopped making it, and their more recent controllers are all much smaller). Historically, the Playstation controllers have been particularly bad. The PS4 controller is much better than previous generations, because they adjusted the shape to make it less cramped, but it's still too small. The XBox One controller is a much better size, but for me at least, it hurts my hands to use the RB and LB buttons because of how I have to twist my hands to press them (whereas with the PS4 controller, it's really easy to move my fingers between the R1/L1 and R2/L2 buttons). The Switch Pro Controller is not quite as large as I would like, but it sits far better in my hands then either of those controllers (or any 3rd party controller that I've tried in recent years), and while it's not quite as easy to move my fingers between R/L and ZR/ZL on the Switch Pro Controller as it is  on the PS4 controller, it's close. So, for me at least, the Switch Pro Controller is far more comfortable than either the XBox One or PS4 controllers (or any 3rd party controller that I've found in recent years). So, from a comfort standpoint, this controller is a _huge_ win for me. No other controller is even close.I very much wish that the analog sticks were lined up like they are with the PS systems. Most of the controllers that I've used over the years have had the analog sticks on the same level, and I much prefer that to having them staggered like the XBox systems do and the Switch Pro Controller does. However, the comfort improvements with the shape and size of the controller vastly outweigh that problem for me.I have heard that the dpad on the Switch Pro Controller isn't that great, and some folks end up pressing up or down when they mean to press left or right (or vice versa), but that hasn't been a big problem for me, and there are videos on youtube which show you how to fix that problem. So, it's disappointing that they didn't make a better dpad, but it hasn't been enough of an issue for me to care.Ultimately, the Switch Pro Controller is so much better for me than any other controller currently on the market that I'm actually using it not only on my Switch, but I'm also using it on the PC, PS3, and PS4. I had to get adapters to get it to work on the PS3 and PS4, but it works, and for me at least, it's a huge improvement. If I had an Xbox of any kind, I'd get the appropriate adapter and be using it there too. Right now, the Switch Pro Controller is the only controller that I use.As an interesting bonus, the fact that the Switch Pro Controller has digital triggers actually makes playing games on systems whose official controllers have analog triggers more pleasant (even aside from the comfort improvements that come with the shape of the controller), because all of the games that I play either just treat them as buttons anyway or use them for something like the speed you run at, and I've never wanted to run at anything other than full speed, so having a simple button to press rather than having to push in an analog trigger and make sure that I press it in all the way is a really nice improvement. I'd probably feel differently if I played racing games (which apparently like to use the analog triggers for their throttle), but for the games that I do play, it's been great. And of course, if you only use the Switch Pro Controller on the Switch, then the way the triggers work is never a problem, because that's the way that all of the official Switch controllers are.So, from both a comfort and functionality standpoint, this controller is a huge win for me.

title: Great controller with one main problem *UPDATE 07/07/18*
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2018
text: *UPDATE*After a day with the controller, I decided to call Nintendo's customer support. They ran me through the typical home diagnostics (update system/controllers, perform "input test") and then recommended I send in the controller for repair. So I sent it in.Within a couple weeks, I was opening the box they sent back, and the receipt said "Service Performed: Product Replacement". So I guess they just gave me a newer controller? (10 years ago I sent in a Wii, and they returned a replacement Wii, so I guess that's just how they often do it.)I loaded Puyo Puyo Tetris and tried out the controller in Tetris, and the dpad seemed to worked flawlessly. After playing some actual games, I feel like there is still some odd sensitivity that causes me to mess up a direction sometimes, but not like it did before. I will probably still play Puyo Puyo with the JoyCons.I'll leave my rating of the product at 4 stars, since it should have worked that well in the first place, but I am now very happy with my controller.I might want another one someday though, so hopefully this doesn't have to happen again.*END UPDATE*After reading about how the corded controllers tend to have 0-2 frames of input lag, and knowing that I'd rather not play most games with the joycons, I decided to get a pro controller along with my new Switch.Now, the only game I've played is Puyo Puyo Tetris, so I haven't really tested all the functionality of the controller (I'll play Super Mario Odyssey soon though), so I'm not sure about the quality of the control sticks or how well the trigger buttons work yet. But here is what I know:ProsLooks really sleek ( I only see two screws; phillips head)Charging cable plugs into top of controllerTriggers/bumpers have a bit more resistance than the Wii U gamepad bumpers, which were definitely too easy to pressButtons are all pretty big, including dpadSmaller buttons (Plus, Minus, Home, and screenshot) are conveniently located within thumb reachEvery part of it feels good to touchConsCharging cable is USB, but only seems to work if plugged into the switch dock's USB portUp on the dpad is too easy to pressSo that last point is really upsetting; in Puyo Puyo Tetris, you need to press dpad up a lot to instantly drop tetris blocks, but there is a high chance I will drop them accidentally whenever I press left or right on the dpad. Dpad down has significantly more resistance and I will never accidentally press that. For many games this might not be an issue, but I honestly think I'll have to use joycons for Puyo Puyo Tetris. It's not horrible, but I should be able to use this controller well for any game, so there's no way I can give it five stars.I will also note that I prefer to grip gamecube controllers with two fingers up on each hand (i.e. one each for L, R, ZL, and ZR), but this controller seems a bit less comfortable that way, probably because your middle fingers have less leverage, since the trigger buttons are smaller and not curved. However, the buttons are positioned such that having only one finger for two buttons is quite natural (more so than with joycons). Using only your index fingers is probably more ergonomic anyways.Overall I really like this controller. I don't have a lot to compare it to, but I've played Super Smash Bros. Melee competitively for a long time (which means I've gone through a lot of gamecube controllers, and often cleaned them/fixed them myself), and this controller feels like high quality hardware. I'm just really disappointed about the dpad up button being to easy to depress. Maybe other people/pro controllers don't have this problem, but it seems like something that shouldn't have been overlooked.

title: weird d-pad, good overall
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2022
text: Something about the d-pad's construction makes it prone to misinputs. If you hit anywhere but the outermost edge of each directional, you have a good chance to experience one of the adjacent buttons being input before the intended input. A good demonstration is if you rock your thumb back and forth on the down button, you will experience left and right inputs as well.Otherwise, this is a nice controller. Worth the money you're charged? No, this thing should be 60 dollars. It's got fairly nice sticks that tend on the sensitive side, the face and shoulder buttons are satisfying to press without being particularly noisy or rattly with the plastic, the grips are weird but they work. the d-pad is kinda the worst part of the controller. that's not unique to nintendo in this case but the point is if you want a controller good for 2d games or games controlled primarily by d-pad you should find something else or just stick with the joy-cons.

title: Update: not that bad.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
text: UPDATE MAY 2020: Not that badSo after I wrote my initial review, I was able to get the stripped screw off (and destroyed the grip in the process, having to order replacements from ebay). Then over the ensuing months I tore apart the controller probably 20 times, trying different variations of the tape trick to fix the D-pad with varied success. The tape did largely correct the false inputs, but at the cost of sometimes not registering button presses. In the end, I decided to take off all the tape and use it as it was originally designed to be used, and guess what? It isn't all that bad. Sure, when you do the input test in Switch settings it registers LOTS of false inputs, but this is less noticeable during actual game play. Now granted, I'm not a professional gamer, but I used the D-pad extensively to play Rayman Legends and Super Mario Maker, and it worked just fine. So in conclusion, yes, the D-pad is far from perfect, it's a major blemish in an otherwise perfect controller and a disgrace for Nintendo, but NO, it is not as bad as everyone makes it out to be. It's probably still the best Switch controller out there at the time of writing. My advice is to buy it and spend some time actually using it before buying into all the negative hype and trying to mess with it. It really isn't all that bad. (with regards to my original review, everything I had said about the design and ergonomics still holds true, even with the aftermarket replacement grips I had to install).------Original review:First off, this controller looks and feels amazing. It's probably the most ergonomic controller I've ever held, and *almost* everything about it feels extremely well-built. But I say "almost," because there's one major inexcusable flaw that just ruins it for me, and that's the D-pad. If you do a quick search, you'll see that this has been an issue with Pro Controllers since the very first model. The D-pad is way too squishy, and registers incorrect inputs when you move between directions quickly. It just blows my mind, how Nintendo, the company that INVENTED the D-pad can get away with making such a poorly designed sub-par one and putting it inside their Pro controller. There IS a fix, but it requires opening the controller and putting tape on the chip.  I attempted it, but ended up stripping one of the screws and now it'll be impossible to ever open it up. So I'm stuck with a $70 "premium" controller with a D-pad that's so imprecise that it's borderline unusable. If playing games with a D-pad is at all important to you, save yourself the headache and frustration and buy a PS4 controller and an 8bitdo or Mayflash receiver.  I used to always prefer official accessories going all the way back to the NES, but sadly, this whole experience has made me lose faith in Nintendo.

title: The only way to play a docked Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 28, 2022
text: Nintendo Switch Pro Controller: $69.39 at the time of reviewI stood in line on launch day in 2017 to get my hands on a Nintendo Switch. The combination of portable and big screen play is hard to beat and though I donâ€™t travel as much I still like the ability to pick my Switch up off the dock and play elsewhere. The reality of my gaming these days though is in front of the TV so a couple of years ago I finally broke down and bought a Pro Controller. It was really the best gaming choice Iâ€™ve made in a long time.*What I liked*:This controller is *much* more comfortable than the two Joycons that come with the Switch, even when theyâ€™re in the holder.The battery life is second to none in all of the top consoles. I think I might charge this thing like once a month.All of the controls feel really good. The buttons have the right amount of key travel. The analog sticks have the right resistance and bounce-back. And the d-pad is about as good as a d-pad can be (which is to sayâ€¦ good but not great).*What I didn't like*:I was going to say something about the cost of this controller, But after a quick search of XBox and Playstation controllers, I see that it is directly in line with the competition. So itâ€™s a little high, but so are all the other options.*The Bottom Line:*This is, without exception, the most comfortable way to play games on the Switch. It may be on the spendier side, but the comfort, battery life, and ease of use make it a no-brainer for people who spend a lot of time with their Switch docked. Itâ€™s a home run for five stars out of five. Iâ€™d absolutely buy this over again.

title: Pricy but solid
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 26, 2018
text: Where to begin...I've always been fine with the Joycons, Handheld mode, in the grip, or one in each hand. I don't mind any of those control methods, nor do I find their D-Pad buttons to be a problem. But I bought this controller for Smash Ultimate and to see what all the fuss was about, because I don't want my Joycons breaking in a moment of carelessness.I thought the Joycons were solid enough for the most part, but this thing, you could practically crack chestnuts with it. From the minute I opened the box and took it in hand, I thought "this isn't the prettiest thing I've ever seen, but this thing is sturdy!"I charged it up right out of the box, played a bit with the wired connection (haven't had any lag problems at all in Wizard of Legend with it) and it finished charging from the Switch dock in a couple hours. Over the next month, I played with it every day when my Switch was docked (I just stopped taking hte Joycons off the main unit when docking it since getting this). It took, with about an hour or more of play per day, maybe a month before I got a "low battery" warning from this controller.Analog sticks are definitely taller, and face buttons are definitely bigger than the Joycons. That felt a bit odd at first, but I can switch between this and the Joycons/handheld mode for any game I own without trouble. The only difference I had to get used to is the placement of the + and - buttons; rather than being above each thumb as on the Joycons, they're between my hand here.I've had no troubles with the D-Pad, and find I rather enjoy it. Got this thing back in April, and have had no troubles at all with either analog stick or the D-Pad. (Which registers up, down, left, right, or diagonals only if I press them- no false positives at all from my Pro Controller.)Reads Amiibo just fine, I place them in the center of the controller to scan them in after I remember the right thumbstick does nothing .This is an entirely optional purchase for me, especially as I've always been more of a handheld gaming man, and am perfectly fine with the Switch's provided controller setup. But the Pro Controller is the best-feeling thing I've held that I can recall, as far as gaming goes. (Note: I've owned Game Boys, DSes, the Gamecube and Wii, and the Logitech Cordless RumblePad 2 for my PC, and that's basically it besides the 8bitdo NES30 Pro.)I have no fears of anything ever breaking this Nintendium-forged artifact, and it still looks as new as it did out of the package down to minute details. Also, the battery is massively overkill- I love it.If you think you'd like one of these, and are okay with whatever the asking price is at the moment, go right ahead. You can use it with Windows and Android phones or tablets as well, so if this controller lasts as long as my old Logitech has, $70 should average out to maybe pennies per month, especially since it works with a bunch of different machines. Planning to keep it until it wears out decades from now.

title: The most comfortable switch controller to play docked
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 18, 2019
text: This thing feels really well built. The controller has a good quality feel to it, plus it feels just the right weight to make it feel secure in my hands. At first it felt a little big since I had been using the joycons mostly, but i quickly got used to it. The price can be a bit hard to justify, but i paid it since I knew that it wasnt a gamble. There are cheaper options out there that might feel this good, but i knew FOR SURE, that this one would be good. And it didnt dissapoint.Pros:- Good placement for the analogs- Nice big face buttons- Nice clicky shoulder buttons (not loud)- HD Rumble- Great motion controls- Great for 3D games- Comes with a high quality USB-C to A cableCons:- Price is a bit high- The analogs have a longer travel so it can feel a bit off putting if you are coming in straight from a Joycon like i was.- Not great for 2D platformers- The home button and screenshot buttons are a bit awkward to reach while playing.Overall this controller is great for games like Zelda BotW, Mario Odyssey, Doom, Ys, Mario Kart, etc, but i don't recommend it for 2D platformers like New Super Mario Bros U, The Messenger, Axiom Verge or Dead Cells. It will function alright, and i bet after playing for a bit your hands get used it, but for me it wasn't ideal and since I have a SN30 Pro, I use that one specifically for 2D platformers and this for everything else.The battery life is certainly impressive. I used it for over a week before I had to charge it, but then I dont do heavy gaming on the most part. My only real complaint is that the home button and the screenshot buttons can be a little difficult to find while playing.Also, take into account that this thing is not really portable. Not only is it big, but it keeps coming on and scanning for the switch each and every time a button is pressed. This is definitely a controller to keep beside the dock for docked playing, and NOT in your bag for hand held or table top. One of the times i packed this and brought it along for table top playing I found it had turned the switch on while it was in the bag. Its also kinda big, so definitely keep it at home. If you want portability go for the SN30 Pro, if you want comfort, go with this.Overally I think its a great controller, my biggest gripe is the price.

title: Highly Recommend over Joycons
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 4, 2021
text: So we just got these the other day, so this isn't a review on their longevity. However, we absolutely love these controllers in comparison to the joy cons. These are SOOO much better.We've been playing Age of Calamity in 2 player mode, and it was a huge pain and no fun to do with the Joy cons. These controllers are worlds better. They are a little big compared to a PS4 controller, but a better shape than the combined joycons.They have a nice heft to them, and they're rechargeable. A lot of the 3rd party controllers for the Switch weren't rechargeable,  and most, if not all, were not compatible with amiibos. If amiibos matter to you, it might be worth noting that the PowerA controllers and other 3rd party controllers probably aren't compatible.As for their charge, we charged them straight out of the box, played with them about every night for the past week and they still have a charge to them. I can't really quantify that in hours, but they definitely seem to last longer than our PS4 controllers (which are a couple years older to be fair).Last point of note is the button mapping. Trying to play Age of Calamity with 1 joycon per person, the buttons on each controller is limited, and the button mapping was confusing and aggravating. Having a controller or complete set of Joycons per person is really the best way to play, and it's definitely less aggravating. I'm not the best gamer, so when the button layout became too confusing with the joycons, I just ignored the confusing buttons (which in this particular game included the button to heal yourself).Last points of note is that they do come with their own charging cords, which plug right into the side of the Switch docking station for easy charging. They are a Type C cord, so most phone charges would probably work as well. And they don't have a spot to plug in headphones or a mic, but neither do the joycons.

title: Mediocre at best, unresponsive and flimsy at worst!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 6, 2021
text: So I've had this Pro controller for a month now and felt I'd been hands on long enough for a full review. Gotten about 150hours on Monster Hunter Generations and played a little Breath of the Wilds,I'm coming from 30+ years of gaming experience and have used every leading console developers (Nintendo, Sega, Microsoft, Sony) 1st party controllers since NIntendo Entertainment System onwards to today. I've owned many, but have used all of them extensively at some point. I've been on PS4 extensively since lunch, easily putting 2k+ hours a year, and 3k hours on Monster Hunter World since launch. So PS4 controller is my most relevant comparison now so you know were im coming from.So firstly, I consider the Pro Controller to be a big improvement over the standard Switch Joy Cons. The Joy Cons ar3 just way to small, right Anolog stick in particular hurts my average sized hands after 30min of use, and button spacing isn't great. To be fare, there Controllers ment for a handheld and in that space they do there job reasonably well. So if you want a more traditional Controller for couch gameing, it's the Pro or a GameCube controller clone, and the Pro is probably a better choice assuming you need motion controls.The Switch Pro controller isn't terrible for sure. Size is fine, maybe slightly small, but decent for average man hands and probably great for smaller hands. But immediately I noticed the Anolog Sticks aren't great. The press function is too tight, Anolog placement feels off and need to be about 25% bigger. I've heard ALOT of stick drift issues, but a month isn't long enough for that to be a issue. Face buttons fell a little mushy, no click or feed back at all. And the face buttons are raised far too much, makeing simultaneously pressing two buttons inaccurate. The ZR/ZL triggers aren't variable at all, this could be particularly frustrating on a racing game, as it's either full or no throttle. I don't mind them not being variable since I play RPGs mostly, and they feel responsive. However the L/R shoulder buttons are awful! They drop inputs frequently and sometimes don't register promptly. Unfortunately many games use shoulder inputs frequently, Monster Hunter GU being a strong example of were this is a issue. It seems to be because the actual button press happens on the outer edges, meaning to get a responsive touch you need to hold them with fingers in claw like hold. This causes alot of finger fatigue on medium sized hands and surely far worse on large hands. 4 way D-Pad is fine, and probably better than PS4 controllers. I've also noticed the left grip moves slightly already, the grips are separate pieces and shift slightly. They don't feel like there breaking, but it's unnerving to have this in 30days. Finally my biggest gripe is there is absolutely no 3.5mm standard headset inputs on the controller, and I've been told USB-C inputs don't work either. So you still need to use the Switch 3.5mm input for a headset. This is 16years behind other console devs, and is completely unexeptable in the age of online gaming.3 stars I'd is very fare, it's not terrible and unfortunately is probably your only choice for a traditional Switch controller. But aside fantastic battery life and decent ergonomics, it well below what I've come to expect from Sony and Microsoft since lunch of Xbox360 in 2005.

title: What You Should Know About the Pro!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 6, 2018
text: So originally I got this controller because I needed something other than the controller grip that was included with the Nintendo Switch which just wasn't cutting it for me. The Joy Cons themselves, while are impressive little controllers, can be frustrating at times due to their size and the size of the buttons being so small. This is especially apparent for games like Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild where you need those precise controls in order to really take full advantage of the combat mechanics.So I bought this and I've got to say that I'm pretty impressed. First off, being someone who's always played Playstation and used to having the analog sticks being side by side, Â I was worried that the directional stick layout which is very similar to Xbox One's layout, would take some time to get used to but that turned out to not be the case. Not only do they work great but I also adjusted to it very quickly and had a blast using this. The controller feels lighter than my PS4 controllers and it fits snug in my grip. It didnâ€™t cramp up my hands like the Joy Con controller grip did. The grips have a nice texture to them that keeps them cool and easy to hold for long periods of time and with the buttons also being a lot bigger then the Joy Cons, I don't have much of an issue with hitting the wrong buttons. Also this controller is rocking a rechargeable battery that boasts a 40 hour life span on a single charge. Since Iâ€™ve gotten the controller a couple weeks ago, Iâ€™ve only had to charge it once, which is a major plus compared to other controllers like the Duelshock 4 which Iâ€™m lucky if I get a good 8 hours out of. I'd even go as far to say that the RZ & LZ trigger buttons are better than both Playstation's and Xbox's counterparts. The buttons seem to travel less distance to activate so it feels like they're responding quicker. Other pluses to this controller is that all the buttons found on the Joy Con make their way over onto this controller, it has the reader which lets you use Aiimbos with it, and its a very quick transition if you want to swap from the Joy Cons to the Pro controller during gameplay.Â There are some cons and things I would have liked to have seen different to this controller. For one, thereâ€™s no dedicated audio jack on the controller for headphone users, the rumble feature feels like its more centered in the controller rather then it being at the grips, I wish there was some more color variations then just the dark gray/black, and for it being a PRO Controller one might think that there would be extra buttons, features, or the ability to remap the button formats, but there are none of these. At the end of the day though, if it came down to me having to choose between buying another pair of Joy Cons or buying this, I would hands down go with this.Â And if you have bigger hands or youâ€™re just used to using the classic grip style wireless controller than I definitely recommend this.

title: My new favorite controller, so far!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2020
text: Before I got the Switch Pro Controller, the Xbox One controller was my favorite. It has a great ergonomic design, nice feeling sticks, and a good weight. I pretty much thought that it was the perfect design for a controller.After I got the Pro Controller though, my opinions changed.The Pro Controller has a great ergonomic feel as well. The face of the controller is nice and large, and it has a matte finish to it. While the grip handles are a bit to small for my liking, the controls make up for it. The sticks feel has as good if not better than the Xbox controller's sticks, and I actually prefer the grip design of the Pro sticks. The Pro Controller face buttons are also miles better than the Xbox controller face buttons. While the Xbox buttons are only clicky, the Pro Controller buttons are nice and mushy, with a satisfying click at the end of the travel. The Pro Controller face buttons are also very large, which is something I didn't know I wanted.Other things that make the Pro better than the Xbox controller include: motion controls, heavier weight, and a better d-pad.That being said, the Pro Controller isn't perfect. While the aforementioned d-pad is better than the Xbox d-pad, it's still not great. The Pro is notorious for it's less than average d-pad. The size is a bit on the small side, and the d-pad is quite loose, which makes it prone to false inputs. Later revisions of the Pro Controller have improved on it though, and it's a least useable if nothing else.Overall though, I have to say that the Pro Controller has become my favorite controller to use. It's a shame that it really only works well on Nintendo Switch (it does have Bluetooth support for other devices, but you have to use external programs and the signal is prone to input lag), making it so that I can't use it on all devices.If you want the best controller experience on Switch, I think this controller definitely has to be on your final shortlist.

title: Good controller, not great, definitely not professional grade
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2021
text: I mainly use this for PC gaming but obviously it pairs well with the Switch. Which imo you may as well buy this asap after getting a Switch because the joycons are the worst input devices I've ever used in my 40 years on Earth. The Golden Tee trackball during 25 cent chicken wing night at the local bowling alley 20 years ago is more reliable and accurate than joycons. But I'm getting off topic.The grip is comfortable. I prefer the way the analog/dpad is setup compared to Playstation controllers. Unlike most Xbox controllers it comes with a charging cord instead of hoping you buy AA batteries in 20XX. Buttons are nice and responsive, the right trigger has taken a pounding since I've bought it and seems to be holding up just fine. Rumble feels fantastic on both Switch and PC. This is obviously the way to go if you need a Switch controller and don't want to mess with adapters or 3rd party pad.So what's the issue? Why the 4 star review instead of 5?Simple. There's slop in the dpad. I can't think of any reason why when I hold left or right on the dpad it wants to also toggle between up and down randomly. If you're considering this controller and you play games that require very precise dpad inputs like fighting games or kaizo Mario then I suggest looking elsewhere.When something is called "pro" there's a weight to that word. It has connotations of being precise and well built to a standard that would be acceptable to professionals. I'm not a pro gamer by any means at all, I'm not even good enough to be called an amateur. But I believe anyone who plays any kind of game only wants to experience failure due to their own actions. Not because the controller gave a false input.

title: Eveything is great except... (Updated)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 25, 2019
text: ...the Directional Pad is *very* subpar. If you're only going to use it for accessing features or items like in Super Mario Odyssey or Breath of the Wild, it works just fine. However if you're going to use it for retro or 2D games it leaves much to be desired. There's no central pivot point like in most every good D-Pad allowing you to hit Up, Down, Left, and Right at the same time and they are sensitive so you will be hitting directions you don't mean to. There's ways to modify it and there's tutorials all over YouTube, but you will have to disassemble the whole thing to do it. I have yet to do it but people have said it makes it a lot better.That said everything about this controller is fantastic. It's not a nice weight, feels quality. It is by far the most comfortable controller I've ever held. It lasts seemingly forever. It says 40 hours but I've yet to put a dent in the battery icon even after extended play. Motion controls are flawless and precise. If it wasn't for the D-Pad I'd say this is the best controller ever made. I don't know why Nintendo dropped the ball on that considering they are the ones who perfected them.If you're looking for something for classic or 2D games line the Online NES games, Sonic Mania, or Mario Maker this might not be fore you but all of your 3D titles couldn't be played on a better controller. If you want something for 2D games, there's some for sale here on Amazon that look like SNES controllers but with analog sticks (ones without sticks are also available) with an amazing D-Pad. Not sure if I'm allowed to mention them by name in reviews but they're not hard to find if you search for Nintendo Switch controlers.Update:After using this on Super Mario Maker 2 the D Pad works a lot better out of the box than I expected. Though not perfect it's fine for casual play but I'm sure people who do kizo levels might find problems. I've been using this with few problems. Occasional accidental diagonal presses but not nearly as frequent as what I saw when first trying out some of NES games. Might need it to be broken in a little. Still prefer the D Pad on the other controller but this one is so much more comfortable in my hands.

title: Great feel, Terrible QC
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 25, 2022
text: Let me just start by saying that, externally, Nintendo has made a great controller. The buttons and triggers are crisp and the grip feels great. The controller is small for my hands but that is okay. The one and biggest problem with this is the lack of QC. I've had multiple Pro Controllers, each one came with stick drift. Mind you, each one I ordered was brand new unopened.  Nintendo has a big problem with joystick drift and I feel as though with all the backlash on the joycon drift they would go out of their way to fix it in their Pro Controllers. Another thing is the price. I cannot recommend getting this at a $70 price point when things like the Gullikit King Kong 2 Pro or 8BitDo Pro 2 exist. (Especially with the $70 8BitDo Ultimate coming out soon). I would pay $50 max since this thing is prone to stick drift and its essentially inevitable. Conclusion: Don't get this controller unless you are a die-hard fan of Nintendo. Opt for the 8BitDo Pro 2 or even better the Gullikit King Kong 2 Pro which can wake your switch up from sleep and it promises no stick drift. Or, you can wait for the 8BitDo Ultimate to release at the same price point (it also comes with a charging dock). Thank you for reading!

title: Why did I wait so long to get the pro controller? Worth the $$.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 3, 2022
text: I got a switch right around launch time.  I assumed I'd pretty quickly get the pro controller because I'm not an on-the-go kind of guy.  I play docked, and I play mostly single-player games. But man, the price of this controller is really quite high.  Since the switch came with the little joycon grip thing, I put off the pro controller.Fast forward to playing Metroid Dread with my kids.  What a difficult, technical, and seriously fun game.  My joy cons were experiencing some connectivity issues, which has been intermittent through the life of my switch.  Both sets I own occasionally have responsiveness issues.  Frustrated, I turned back to the Switch Pro controller, and MAN, WHAT A DIFFERENCE.My connectivity problems are gone.  My joy con drift (granted, this is still new) is gone.  And the controller is solid, well-built, and enjoyable to play on.  Yeah, the switch pro controller is expensive, but I could afford it, and it was worth it. I enjoyed using it every time I played up until I beat Metroid Dread, and now I want to find more excuses to play the switch just to use this controller. So much nicer than the included joycon grip controller.

title: It's the perfect controller. In every sense of the word.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2017
text: This is the best controller I've ever used. I own a PS4 and, god damn, this is leaps and bounds ahead.First, the sticks. They feel buttery smooth, just like they're gliding along. The grips are well build and feel good. They require a good amount of pressure to click, and it's perfect.Now, the buttons. The ABXY buttons are large, with around a 1cm diameter. As you smash the A button in Mario Kart, you'll appreciate it a lot. They don't hurt, and while they're a little mushy, they begin to feel perfect after around 5 minutes.The D-Pad is a traditional Nintendo D-Pad. They make the best ones, hands down. This one stands up to that quality perfectly. It feels clicky, but not like a button. Way above the PS4 D-Pad and a little clickier than the Wii U one. It's perfect also.The triggers and bumpers (those buttons on the back of the controller), ZL, ZR, L and R also feel great. Like the ABXY buttons, they're large and a touch mushy. They feel like they were made for my fingers.I have larger hands, and this controller is the best one I've ever used. So much better than the Joy-Cons, so much better than anything you've ever used. A couple more small notes: the + and - buttons are nice and clicky, along with the HOME and the Capture button. Unlike the Wii Remotes and the Wii U Pro Controller, the player indicator lights are located on the front of the controller, in between the the two hand holds. It's not too bright, and they're green. Cool, right?I don't play enough of my Switch to test the 40 hour battery life, but damn, it's good. I've charged it maybe weekly with daily use. It's got a great battery. It's heavy enough to feel substantial, but not too heavy. It's perfect. (I know I keep saying that but it is.)The gyro feels good, the NFC is serviceable.In the box, by the way, is a USB-C cable. It works with the controller and the switch, as it's a fully standard cable. (For those who would think about using it with a USB-C laptop/phone, it's USB 2.0 not 3.0. It doesn't have the extra 5 connectors for USB 3.0.)I know it's $70. I know. It's worth it, though. Please don't buy a second set of Joy-Cons. Please buy this controller. You won't regret it.

title: A must for large hands or enthusiasts
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2017
text: +It's very comfortable to hold and feels substantial in your hands. I want to stress how solid this controller feels and the build quality behind it. I can twist the grips pretty aggressively and they donâ€™t give or make noise. In comparison Sony and Microsoftâ€™s controllers creak and feel like theyâ€™ll break from noticeably thinner and weaker plastic.+The analog sticks are very comfortable, have little friction, and the edges have a nice grippy pattern. After 2000 hours of Splatoon 2 the analog sticks return to neutral and thereâ€™s no wobbling or drifting. The sticks do rub against the sides though and will produce some plastic dust. One disappointing problem I ran into was occasionally the right stick would register a click despite not being pressed down.+It uses USB-C and comes with 1 Nintendo branded USB-A to USB-C cable about 5 feet in length. Plugging it in to your Switch will instantly sync the controller.+It lasts 40 hours. That's not impressive compared to the Wii U's Pro Controller at 80 hours, but it's still going to make it near impossible to run out of juice if you're addicted to Zelda. The controller feature gyroscopes, HD Rumble, and NFC which reduce battery life.+The area your fingers get into contact with are matte, and you won't have to worry about scratches, fingerprints, or other blemishes if you take care of it.+I clean my hands religiously, but on other controllers, oils would still build up and get into the cracks and itâ€™s pretty disgusting. Iâ€™ve had only extremely minor oil build up on this controller. Maybe the plastic is coated in an oleophobic coating? Itâ€™s strange, but thatâ€™s possibly the most impressive thing I can say about this controller.+You can use the controller on a PC as a generic input device. It does not work over USB and requires Bluetooth.-The only part the controller that is glossy plastic is at the top of the controller which comes shipped covered in a plastic protective sheet. This also happens to be where the USB cable plugs in. Itâ€™s going to get scratched. It might look nice, but functionally this is foolish. Why would you make the only area where the metal could come into contact with controller the one spot that could get easily scratched?-The D-Pad registers false inputs when pressed. As of this review, Nintendo has refused to acknowledge this design defect. It makes playing Puyo-Puyo Tetris and Tetris 99 impossible since pressing Up makes pieces drop instantly.-The L and R bumpers have a very small area weâ€™re pressing them wonâ€™t register an input well. If you use the outer edges you probably will never run into this but itâ€™s still worth mentioning.-The Share and Home buttons are way too close and similar in shape to the + or - button, and there's no intuitive way to feel for which you're pressing. Itâ€™s too bad they arenâ€™t + and - shaped like on the JoyCons.-The Switch has an option to use the controller wired for reduced input latency, but for most people this is rather useless unless you buy a much longer cord.-There's no analog triggers, but that's because it has parity with the JoyCons. Still not an excuse and would have made this item far more valuable if supported.-I had a harder time feeling HD Rumble on this than the JoyCons. It's a subtle effect, but given the size and rigid nature of this controller, it really should have been amped up overall.-It's $70 MSRP. That's not only more than a game, it's more than the competitors. I know controllers are more complicated than ever and its build quality is far superior with the exception of the D-Pad, but that doesnâ€™t make it any easier to swallow.Children and smaller handed people can probably get by with Joy-cons. If you find them too small, this controller will be a welcome bit of comfort.I have personally gotten a lot of use and enjoyment out of it, especially with Splatoon 2. The only reason Iâ€™m giving it three stars is because I expect more responsibility and the highest quality from Nintendo products. One of the major reasons to invest in this controller is the D-Pad. Nintendo practically invented the modern D-Pad. That theyâ€™ve allowed this defect to exist and be denied is a travesty.

title: Control stick wears on the housing - Worried about how long the controller will last.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2019
text: This controller just may replace the second-gen Sega Saturn joypad as my favorite first party controller ever.  It's comfortable as can be to hold, but I have just one concern.  The analog sticks rub on the face of the controller and wear the plastic down, it's white powder around either analog stick.  I just hope Nintendo is going to be supporting to their loyal players in a year or so when these things start wearing out.Back in the N64 days, the Nintendo customer service number on the sticker on every Nintendo product took care of their gamers and they sent me three new N64 Analog sticks for the controllers that got worn out for free.  Just the analog sticks, and I had to take apart the controllers to put them in.I've only had this particular controller for about a month and I've already had to clean off the plastic wear dust from the analog pads twice.It's a very comfortable controller, but I really think it's overpriced (same as their Joy-Cons) and I question just how durable it is after seeing this much wear and tear after some casual use during less than a month's time.I'm gonna really be upset if this expensive official controller wears out early, and I sure hope Nintendo's customer service is as good as it was 20 years ago when this control stick gives up the ghost like you can tell it's going to do.It's comfy, it's USB-C, good battery life, but the powdery wear around the thumbsticks really concern me.  They rub against the controller housing and I just can't see how this controller was designed like this with the wear parts.Going to try and be optimistic, but these kind of problems typically get bad enough to warrant getting upset about right after they're out of the warranty period...I sure hope Nintendo isn't skimping on quality or product support these days.

title: A Must Have for Nintendo Switch Owners!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2018
text: Overall the switch is mostly perfect. However, the biggest problem with the system is the controllers that come with them, the Joycons. As many reviewers had said before, they were so small after using them for more than an hour my hands were starting to cramp. Well, I decided to put some money into it and purchase the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller. Here are my thoughts on the pro controller.The Good:-The analog sticks: They are accurate, responsive and have the perfect feel.-The ABXY buttons: The ABXY are big when big=better. Because gaming is about being able to hit the right buttons, having huge buttons really is really helpful.-The feel of the controller: I know this is subjective but personally, the controller just feels right in the hands. Playing Splatoon 2 never felt better.-The features: Probably the thing that stands out most about the pro controller is the abundance of features. Not only does it have the haptic feedback but it also has motion controls, an NFC reader (for amiibo) and even rubber on the back of the controller to provide extra grip while playing.The Bad:-The D-Pad: One of the biggest problems with the pro controller is the D-Pad. Because of the way it is built, if you don't press on the D-Pad a certain way, it might be read as a mispress, leading to Link dying more than necessary.-The Triggers: This isn't really a problem but the triggers don't feel triggerlike. They don't have much travel and compared to the Xbox 1 controller they are mushy and unsatisfying. But other than that they're ok.-The Price: This is probably the most obvious one. Paying $70 for a controller albeit a nintendo one is hard to justify. Sure there are more expensive options but there are also cheaper options. You should really only pick up this gamepad if you have extra cash to set aside.The VerdictThe pro controller isn't really a necessity for anyone who is just looking to have fun, but if you are a pro gamer or a perfectionist who wants the best experience, the pro controller is a must-have.

title: Animal Crossing Drift Fix!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
text: Solution to calibrate pro controllers in Animal Crossing and fix automovementsI wrote this solution to solve the drifting in games like animal crossing with pro controller in other thread, and it worked for me and other people than reply me.**Note**: These are the steps I did, but I don't know if all steps are needed. But it seems to work.\--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I have done next steps with both pro controllers and both are working fine now.1. Restated the Nintendo Switch holding power off button and selected it. No controller plugged in by cable.2. I have calibrated the analog stick. Before each movement during the calibration proccess I have forced the middle position correcting the drifting.3. I have returned then to the screen telling me to push the analog stick to calibrate.4. I have pressed reset controller button (beside the USB port) a few seconds. Lights in front side of controller starts to change. I have released the button, putted the console on the desk, and pressed home button.5. I have returned to calibrate controller and it works fine now. No drifting, no cable, and point returns to the center changing to the cross.Now I have both controllers without drifting and Animal Crossing and Luigis Mansion 3 (the only games I had with the new driffting movements) are working correctly.All is so weird.I did the whole process with the switch outside the docker, and controllers now work with the switch inside and outside the docker.After restarting the Switch controllers still work fine.

title: Almost Perfect
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2020
text: I play this mosty for PC games and steam. The controller has a nice feel to it and adds so much comfort to the hands from playing games in prolong time. Battery life is what makes this controller shine among the rest, long battery life is amazing, I charge my controller once or twice a month. It's really easy to sync bluetooth via PC to play games in steam.There are three things I do not like about this controller:1, it's the DPad, it's not very accurate when playing that mainly depends on it when moving, the arrows sometimes hits a combination between two unexpectedly and can cause frustration due to keys not registering properly.2, its the left and right top bottons, it does no justice when playing Racing games, it does not have the smooth feeling when using the xbox trigger buttons when you accelerate and reverse. The trigger buttons controls the speed in driving and this does not have it. If they added top analog trigger buttons it would make racing and shooting games a better experience.3, it's the three month manufacturer warranty, they should of stick to two years due to other peoples complaints of analog stick issues. Making players feel at ease with their expensive controller purchase with 2 year warranty would make this controller a lot nicer.Overall, controllers fine when playing with the original system and AAA games this was designed. Could of had better improvements that will make play other games a true fun gaming experience.

title: A Controller Every Switch Owner Should Have!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
text: I was skeptical of buying this controller since I was initially thinking that buying a pair of joycons would be the better option since it supports two users instead of a fixed one user; however, after months of playing with this controller and sharing it with my friends, I found out that both products have its uses and the pro controller is outstanding on its own. I was shopping for another pair of joycons, but instead I caved in buying this item from youtube reviews and friend recommendation, but I do not regret it for a second. I've had this product for a long time now and I use it for every game I've come across coming to over 50+ games. It is comfortable with a lot of features including rumble, gryo aiming, amiibo support, and compatability with a lot of games. The quality of build is also beyond expectations as this controller has been dropped well over 10 times from friends including myself without any hardware damages or any significant cosmetic damages. Not to mention, drift concerns are not a problem here since those affected the joy cons only. I would just like to sum this up by saying that as an Console user (Xbox and Playstation), it is a great way to ease into controls in switch games and it can be a lot more reliable, comfortable, and easier to play games on the switch. (Even if you play Smash Ultimate, it can be a great substitute for a joycon (unless you are a gamecube controller loyalist that is good on its own too))

title: Comfortable and much better than the joycons
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2021
text: I'll cover what I think are the most important aspects of a controller.Comfort - The comfort of use is slightly better than a ps4 controller. The handles are filled out so if you need to use your pointer and middle fingers to use all 4 shoulder buttons, you won't need to curl your ring and pinky fingers too much to hold the controller handles, and they are rubber gripped.Shoulder buttons - good size buttons that are easier and more comfortable to use than the standard joycon controller. You can comfortably have space to cover all 4 shoulder buttons at once without your fingers touching. The only strange thing is that the R/L-Z buttons are actual buttons instead of triggers like on the xbox1 and ps4 controllers - IMO just a subtle nuance to get used to rather than an issue.Joysticks - good grip for thumb. Comparable to the ps4 joysticks.D-pad - it's an actual d-pad rather than just 4 separate buttons. Personally I prefer it this way so that you can easily feel your directional inputs instead of clicking a single button like on the joycon controller.If you're playing a switch game that requires more than a single joycon and the game isn't super smash brothers, then this controller is a great choice.

title: Awesome
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2022
text: This controller takes gaming to a whole other level. After feeling dissatisfied with the joy cons small size, I was really impressed with this controller. Fits in my hands really well, comfortable handling and grip, and the buttons feel great and are big.

title: It's good
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2022
text: After using this controller, I could not go back to using joy cons man. Except when I'm playing BOTW, I need those joy cons. For games like Hollow Knight, Cuphead, it's been pretty comfortable to have a good feeling controller respond the moment I press a button.

title: Don't settle for less than the REAL thing.  THIS is it!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2021
text: I bought a knock off ProCon when I first got the switch in March of 2020.  I thought that did the trick, at the time.  That is--it did, until I had pairing issues and until I realized that there had to be a reason Nintendo made one official ProCon.  This is TOTALLY worth it.  Do not buy anything but this!  You'll be incredibly glad you bought this.  It's ergonomically sound, it's light weight, the haptic feedback/rumble is perfect, and the game play is optimized like I really never believed it would be.There is absolutely a difference, and you can't properly experience the Switch without this official version of the ProCon from Nintendo.  If you've invested in the Switch, please do yourself a favor and get the Nintendo licensed version.  You will NOT be disappointed.  I bought this at $59.99, and while that may seem like a lot, it dwarfs anything that tries to imitate it (I tried several others), and it never has a problem pairing with the Switch.  I'm not a heavy gamer.  Also, the Joy-Con grip really only takes you so far.This would get 6 stars from me if that were possible.

title: Comfort and battery life are great
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2021
text: First thing, this is actually quite a big controller compared to the Switch's tiny controller. Compare with Switch's joycon dock, this Pro controller is much beefier, and also a bit heavy. I don't know how this compares with Xbox or Playstation wireless controllers, but this surprised me on how thick and heavy it is. However, you will soon forget about it after you start playing the game.  The joystick placement is slightly different than the joycon, it's more spread out, your thumb will need to reach further to go from joystick to the D-pad.  The good thing is that the buttons are much bigger and vibrations are stronger. Battery life is also longer than joycon, full charge takes about 2 hours.  Is it worth it? If you mostly play single player games and feels the joycon are too small and crampy, you should definitely get it. If you just need another controller, you should think what game you are using the controller for, as some games need joycon style, some games for multiple players (expensive to get two of these instead of a pair of joycon). I use Switch in dock mode most of time, so getting this controller is great. If you play on the go perhaps you may not use this much.

title: Must have controller, best one in 30 years I swear by it
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2020
text: Very rare 5 star reviewUPDATE:After 3 months of use (soild use, everyday).This has been the BEST controller I've ever bought from ANY system in my 30 years of gaming.  The battery still last 40+hrs, and only takes 2 hrs or so to recharge.  Its durable as hell and holds up great. Buttons and stick still works like perfect.  And I have used it for 100s of hours since purchase.  A mist have even for the money wont.buy anything but from now on.( I've said that 3 times today but man, I've bought some good stuff)my 1st pro controller was the 30$ version amazon offers here n now.  I wore it out very quickly once I started playing fortnite.You get what you pay for.  This controller is FKIN amazing..  the smoothness the control and feel of buttons and the controller itself.in your hands is like holding liquid gold.  I absolutely must insist that you spend the money and get this pro controller. It will make you a pro all the way around.Must have for all gaming shooters will see a huge difference between brands. PromiseI will update as needed to see how long the controller will last. I see alot of review complaining about left stick after a short time...  I will let you know as it happens and my.use will not be lite.

title: Nintendo Switch Pro Controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2022
text: This was a gift for my son, who is a big gamer.  It was actually to replace the one he was using.  He loves it and I believe uses it every day.

title: I hate wireless controllers
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2022
text: I bought this hoping it would be an improvement from my 20-dollar wired controller I had bought for the Switch, but the cons are starting to outweigh the pros. I bought that controller because I have no interest in using the standard joycon that came with the system (I grew up with the old NES and enjoyed the wired controllers all the way through PS2 and I say if it ain't broke, don't fix it). Sadly, my old 20-dollar switch controller started going wonky with its left toggle and became very irritating trying to play Animal Crossing--my character kept trying to face south all the time and it was hard to move the cursor over items I wanted in my inventory.So, I bought this!I figured, well, it comes with a cord, maybe I can leave it plugged in all the time and screw the battery charging madness. It has rumble and the ability to use amiibo, so why not? I should've bought another 20-dollar one.On first impression, I liked the way this controller felt in my hands, the handles were slightly thinner than the other one I was using. But the buttons are not as tactile, which makes pressing them less sure than my old controller. The plus button is imbedded rather than protrudes, which makes it more difficult to press, a bad thing if you play Animal Crossing. I wanted to use the controller right out of the box, but it had to charge first. No problem, right? Wrong. The cord is super short! Unless you're a little kid who wants to sit on the floor, you can't play a game with this short cord, and that's not a good idea anyway. I had to sit forward on my couch to use it with the cord and my big modern tv started hurting my head pretty fast. I had to dish out more money to buy some other, longer cord that I'm praying will work. I had also figured I will put up with charging the thing and use it as a wireless controller. Nope. Just today, day 2 of having the controller, my AC character started walking left and I couldn't control it. Apparently, my Switch lost the signal to my controller: who tf needs that in the middle of gameplay? Also, the toggles are not as wide as my old controller. They are probably as wide as the joycon ones, which is not good. I bought the xbox-style controller for the bigger buttons and toggles. It's easier to grip and abuse the bigger toggles.I recommend this controller only if you like what I said above. You like charging your controller all the time? You like sitting close to your tv trying to play when you plug it in? You like mushy buttons and tiny toggles? Then go for it.

title: Pay to win
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2022
text: I feel like this controller gives me an advantage over every online player

title: Great way to use Switch as a Console
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2019
text: I purchased this to play Skyrim on the Switch, particularly in docked mode.  Now, the Switch comes with a plastic holder that you can slot the half controls into to create a standalone controller for free.  I'll call this the "standard" controller further down.  So, why pay $60 or so for this?Well, in contrast to the standard Switch standalone controller, this has a very different feel to it.  Because the controller is larger, the left-thumb control has a lot more "play" to it.  This means there is more distance from the center to the ends.  This gives me more precise control in-between the edges when using this than the standard Switch controller.  And that can be crucial for some games.  The standard Switch thumb control can only move a very short distance from center to end, making precise control between the edges much harder.Also, it has the vibration feature built in and a much longer battery life than the standard Switch controller.  It pairs seamlessly with the Switch, and if you are using the Switch in a Docked mode, and have paired this controller, turning this controller on automatically turns on your Switch.If you find you play your Switch a lot in the docked mode, this is probably worth your money.  If you mainly play your Switch in handheld mode, this isn't worth the extra cash.Also, if you do a lot of multi-player games such as Super Smash Brothers Ultimate, and feel like spending a lot of money, the Switch can pair with up to 4 of these at once.

title: A Great Wireless Controller for my Nintendo Switch.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2021
text: When I first got my Switch, I got a wireless controller to go with it. But the problem with that controller is that it uses AA batteries, which I had to change every single time the batteries ran out. Plus, it does not have an NFC reader. So I had to go to my Switch and detach the right Joy-Con to use it. And it was a pain to pair it with the Switch.With this official Pro Controller, I don't even need to do those things anymore. No wireless pairing required. With the cable that can be used to charge the controller, my Switch can detect it automatically when plugged in and docked. I can use the NFC Reader with most of the Amiibo-Supported Games without having to detach the right Joy-Con to do so. No more changing the batteries for me. With 40 hours of battery life, I don't need to worry about charging it until it tells me to do so.With a good investment, this Pro Controller can mostly help eliminate the need of buying another pair of Joy-Cons which they can get the Drift from wear and tear, and/or sending them to Nintendo to get serviced.

title: Great for the first year..then drifting issues.

text: Update 8/31/20: Upgrading back to 5/5 stars! Turns out I accidentally turned motion control on without knowing it. Once I found that and turned it off the issue was gone.Please ignore my negative comment below.I bought this controller in January 2020 and up until the last week or so (August 2020) it was working great and I absolutely loved it. I was totally fine with paying what I did and wouldâ€™ve happily done so again.Unfortunately around last week my controller started having an issue where the left analog stick was drifting the the left and nothing could fix it. I tried recalibrating the stick in the Nintendo Switch settings and it would fix it for about 30 seconds before it started drifting again.This issue is particularly noticeable in games like Mario Kart 8 Deluxe where my racer will start drifting to the left which makes racing almost impossible since I canâ€™t control my own car drifting while racing.Sadly my warranty expired and Iâ€™m really annoyed that I paid so much only for it to break in less than a year. I take good care of it and always wash my hands before playing so itâ€™s not an issue of poor treatment of the controller.I hope other people donâ€™t have this issue but felt I should mention it since it happened to me.

title: Almost perfect controller but not without competition
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 16, 2020
text: This is a Great Controller albeit at a price that's harder to swallow.I bought this alongside 8BitDo's SN30 Pro+ and both controllers have their pros and cons...Switch Pro ControllerPros- Good build quality and feeling in the hand- Great comfort and IMO the best layout of inputs- Ridiculously long battery life- All the features you already know for being a Nintendo controller made for the switch. (NFC, HD Rumble, wake up the console).Cons- the D-Pad feels like an afterthought. It is prone to unintended inputs and it's location is not optimal for 2D games or platformers- for the price, it should get better warrantyIn comparison the SN30 Pro+ is miles ahead regarding the D-Pad.It has many more connectivity options, the battery is both rechargeable and removable AND it allows for AA batteries to be used instead. The rumble is "regular" but it feels actually very good with different intensities.The main downsides are lack of NFC and inability to wake up the switch, but I mainly use it for pc anyway.Overall I am completely pleased with both devices and the Switch Pro Controller is the one to get if you only need one for the switch and also if you enjoy 3D games more than 2D or platformers.But if you need a controller for the Switch than also works great with PC, Android and Mac, the 8BitDo's SN30 Pro+ is the best hand down.4.5/5 for both

title: Outrageous improvement over joycons
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 2, 2019
text: I finally upgraded to the pro controller after much time contemplating if it would really make a difference to me. I've been using the joycons since the launch of the Switch and while not perfect I can still appreciate their design concept.The one aspect of the pro controller that had me on the fence were the triggers. Honestly, that is the one thing I really don't like about the joycons. Everything else about the joycons I can work around. Well, pictures don't do the pro controller justice, the triggers are absolutely fantastic and I certainly don't see myself ever using the joycons again when it comes to playing games that utilize the triggers extensively.Not just the triggers but everything about the pro controller is a huge step up from the joycons. The buttons are bigger, the analogue sticks give a great grip with your thumbs and the controller feels nice and snug in the hands. The material is much more friendly during longer sessions. That was another gripe I had with the joycons; after a period of time the sticks and triggers would be slippery. I managed it by having a cloth nearby to give it a nice wipe occasionally. Not the case with the pro controller, there is much more friction to it.It's a must have accessory for me and I give it a 5 star because I think it's a fantastic controller and fixes every issue I had with the joycons. I suppose if there is one thing I would change about it that would have to be the placement of the right analogue stick. Personally, I'd like it above the buttons so the two sticks would be symmetrical but I don't think it merits deducting a star.

title: Expected a bit more but not dissapointed
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 8, 2021
text: I wanted to wait a bit to give this controller a fair use before writing my review. It has had many, many hours of game to it now, and while I'm not aggressive with my controllers, I'm the "press the buttons harder to make the character jump higher" kind of player. I bought the Pro Controller because my joy-cons haven't suffered from the cursed drift and I wanted them for playing mostly Just Dance.The controller feels great, it's very well built and it was recognized by my Switch right away. I've played Smash, Mario Kart, BOTW, ACNH and even some games on Steam and haven't had an issue. This is definitely a great purchase;  as someone else mentioned, this is a great alternative to buying other joy-cons.I kinda wish I could give this controller a 4.5 review because of the D-pad. I've mostly used it for playing on Mario games and I've died countless times because I stopped ducking while pressing down on the pad. The D-pad is the only downside to the controller as it's unpredictable when it'll fluke out.

title: Always buy OEM.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 20, 2019
text: I got this within a week of buying the Switch, and probably the one piece of advice I heard from everyone is "just buy the Pro Controller from Nintendo". I got a cheap 3rd party authorized USB controller while I was buying games in store, played some games but quickly just decided to grab the Pro Controller. After I used it, I realized why everyone loves it. It's almost perfectly built, feels great and natural, and so many features for the controller. Wireless works fantastically, battery lasts forever, Rumble feels good, and the motion controls work wonderfully. The motion controls are probably the biggest here - I didn't realize that games on the switch actually depended on the motion controls, which I really missed out on when I had a third party controller. With this, there's so many opportunities for motion control to provide a natural third joystick, especially in games like Breath of the Wild. Works fantastically. My only gripe is that, since it is so convenient, I love to just throw it in my backpack with my switch and its case, and go out for the day. However, there's nothing supplied to help protect the joysticks in transit. I would have loved to see easily detachable thumbsticks, or some kind of bumper, so that I can quickly store + access the controller without needing a protective case or worrying about the condition of the joysticks getting jostled. I know that's not really a trend with many comparisons, like xbox or playstation, but given what I heard about this controller having long-term issues with thumbsticks, it would make sense to me.

title: Compared to the Joycons...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 19, 2021
text: We have a total of 3 pairs of joycons in our family and have always enjoyed using them. Their size fits perfectly for us and are useable with the grips. I decided to get myself this Nintendo version of the pro controller since I play some RPGs and figured it would go well and maybe bring back some good vibes from my youth. I say that since this is built like a normal console controller. Very similar to the Xbox. The controller is larger then the joycons and the placement of buttons is awkward at first and took some time getting used to it. It feels great though and overtime itâ€™s become my preferred controller. I wish however that it wasnâ€™t so noisy. Every top face button pressed makes a loud sound. (I play usually at night when everyone is asleep) I enjoyed the joy cons because they werenâ€™t as loud and I can separate my hands while relaxing on the couch or bed. If you already have joycons, and enjoy them, this is more of a luxury piece. I have not experienced analog drift yet with these though while I have on my joycons.

title: Loved it so much, I bought two!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 8, 2019
text: If you are a switch owner, this is a must have controller. This is probably my favorite controller of all time. The way it fits in my hands, it becomes a part of you. The buttons are clicky and the directional pad is much better than using the joycons. The battery life is amazing and it charges quickly through USB-C.If this worked cross platform fluidly, this would be my go to controller for all video games. It's very similar to the Xbox One controller, but the grips are a little bit thinner and I'm just able to get a more solid grip than the Xbox One controller.After months of use, it still works and feels like new. The construction is solid and there's no flex in the plastic when you grip it tight during intense moments.  I've gone through probably 3 Xbox one controllers because the plastic starts to squeak after a few months of use and the buttons become unresponsive. So Kudos to Nintendo for continuing to make quality controllers.The NFC tag works nicely for scanning amiibos if that's your thing.One warning, and this may have been fixed with a controller update, but after not using one of the controllers for a few months, the battery drained and would only worked while plugged in. Even with charging for a few hours, it wouldn't charge. I decided to just leave it charging for a few days (using the provided Nintendo USB C to A charger plugged into the switch) and it worked again.  The battery is the same as the 3DS battery and I guess when those are drained, they take a long while to charge. So for anyone whose controller won't charge, just try leaving it charge for a day or so!

title: Great product

title: Plays like a dream
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2019
text: This is a really well built controller! I'll get right to the point about what I enjoy about this:* joysticks play really nicely, very smooth and accurate* Great grips! The controller feels like it melts into your hands. In contrast to just using the joycon (which don't have grips) , you can actually give this controller a death grip and still feel comfortable.* Not advertised, but it works well on the Steam client! (Nintendo doesn't endorse it) Valve developers have worked on drivers to make this controller work on all steam games.* Durability feels excellent. It feels like it will not break for another 10 - 15 years.* Dpad feels good, a great leg up from the Nintendo 3DS DPad. Due to greater thickness than any 3ds, the controller allows for a more bubbly feel when pressing down on the DPad. 99% of games I've played: Mutant Mudds, the NES Library, and Megaman 11 feel awesome. It will suit just about anything you throw at it.There is however one caveat to this controller, while the DPad is great, I wouldn't recommend it for something like Tetris where you require incredibly precise controls. For expert play, it's possible to accidentally harddrop a piece onto the board. I don't know many other games that require intense precision on all 4 corners of DPad, but be aware that the DPad can make the occasional mistake.I'm generally satisfied with this controller. I try to use it as often as possible, as I feel that the joycon feel a little easy to abuse :P

title: The best controller for the Switch, hands down
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2021
text: Through first and third party products, the Nintendo Switch supports more controllers than any home console in recent memory.  So there's a strong temptation to skimp and buy a cheaper 3rd party model or some kind of adapter to let you reuse a controller from an older system. Don't do it. Don't waste your time. This is the best one.I purchased one of these shortly after buying my switch and tried a number of cheaper options to get around buying another one for "player two."  Yes, 8bitdio controllers work.  Yes, you can buy adapters that let you use Wii and Wii U controllers. Yes, they have those PowerA controllers that have the Gamecube design.  None of those options are as good as the Switch Pro Controller.I tried a PowerA controller (because I love the Gamecube controller) and it broke after a month.  Just don't bother with anything other than the Switch Pro Controller.  None of them have the grip, feel, weight and reliability.  The Switch Pro Controller is the best traditional-style controller Nintendo has made thus far.

title: Comfortable to use. Long battery life. No â€œdrift.â€ No complaints.

title: Probably the best controller Iâ€™ve purchased. Ever.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2021
text: The Pro Controller is my favorite game controller. It is big enough (for adult hands) to be comfortable for long gaming sessions. My 6 year old nephew doesnâ€™t have any problems using it either. Good all around fit. The controller, itself, is built like a tank. Iâ€™ve dropped it a few times and have come to the conclusion that it might actually be indestructible. The controller has a bit if heft to it, but isnâ€™t overly heavy. It does have a rumble function and an NFC reader for Amibos. My favorite thing about this controller is that the battery lasts forever. I donâ€™t remember how many hours it lasts, but Iâ€™ve gone easily more than a week without recharging it while using it for several hours a day. The only con I can think of is that it is a bit pricey, but it is so so very much better than the drift-prone joycons. This is one if the best purchases I have made in a while.

title: Nice controller
