title: Arrived used but in very good condition
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2022
text: I received it in a flat rate USPS envelope, which was odd but it was very well wrapped and came with a much longer cable. The left stick drifts but I can solder so that isn't a worry. Happy I got it for 45 dollars, otherwise I would be actually mad. Whoever owned it before me kept it in good shape, so I'm happy about that. Cheers.

title: Solid and Reliable
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2017
text: I really want to knock 1-2 stars off because the price is insane!  But I have to give in... this is my favorite controller.The charge lasts forever (supposedly 40hrs).  I haven't timed it but I think I have only charged it twice (I think) and I took it with me overseas as well as numerous "local" trips.  I have sunk over 100 hours in Zelda alone and have time in Mario Kart and Odyssey as well.  Not all of that time was with the Pro controller but so much so I have no clue how much.  My PS4 controller only lasts 1-2 gaming sessions before it needs to be recharged as a comparison ...and that's both the old and new PS4 controllers.In addition to the charge time it comes with the primary features you want of a controller (motion sensing and HD rumble pack).  As far as features go it does lack an audio port which is a pretty big omission.  If the rest of the controller wasn't so awesome I would dock a star for this omission.It feels great in the hand.  If anyone remembers the WaveBird controller this feels like it's genetically gifted sibling.  No fatigue using this controller.  Or a more comfortable XB 360 controller (which I also liked).While the PS4 is the worst controller I've used for durability (already have 5+ mostly because of the left analog stick) the Switch Pro controller appears (at least so far) to be the most durable controller I have.  Granted the PS4 controller is the only controller I've had an issue with, the Switch Pro controller still feels more durable than the PS4 controller by a sizeable margin.

title: You need to own one to preserve your Joy-Cons
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2018
text: Was on the fence about buying a pro controller but saw a YouTube video about peopleâ€™s joy-cons wearing down from sliding them on and off the Switch. Apparently the button you push in has a raised peg and sliding it on and off the metal rails of the Switch so many times wears it down and your joy-cons can slide off dropping your Switch. So I had originally opted for a second set of joy-cons instead of a pro controller so one set of joy-cons for now on will be attached to my Switch and the other set will not go back on the grip but used as two controllers sideways and I bought the pro controller so I had a controller to game on titles that need that many buttons like Zelda Breath of the Wild. The second set of joy cons charge on a slide in slide out charging dock, that donâ€™t click into place to damage that peg connected to Joy-Con release button. The first set stays attached to my Switch and charges in the dock attached to the Switch. Mind you I know I will have to remove Joy-Cons to play for more than three people but this solution of one pro controller and two sets of Joy-Cons greatly reduces the Switching involved to wear down my Joy-Cons. By the way Iâ€™ve been playing the Switch pro controller for 4 days now about 3-5 hours a day and as of this post I still have a almost full charge, although I donâ€™t see any drop off in battery charge icon, but it should have at least gone down a drop but if I had to estimate Iâ€™d say itâ€™s still full charged. Great product Nintendo Iâ€™m impressed!!!

title: Good Deal on Main Item

title: Durable, Good Battery Life
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 21, 2022
text: I bought this 16 months ago and have used it daily since. I have reached hours and hours of gameplay and the think still looks brand new. title: Love/hate relationshipâ€¦
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 28, 2022
text: I really want to give the pro controller a great review but after having to exchange 3 of them out within 2 months, Iâ€™m left feeling confused and dissatisfiedâ€¦The controller initially feels solid (despite the really cheap, non-grippy handles). The issue I have is either the left thumb-stick or the right trigger burned out on each one I received within a few weeks! I also had serious drifting on the controller with the thumb-stick issues. I just donâ€™t understand how these controllers can sell for the price they do and then consistently under-deliver. I really want to like it and give it a good review, but itâ€™s so hard after the experience I have had.The main reason I have kept my recent one is because I originally purchased a mount for the switch that is specifically designed for the pro controller. I love the mount so much that Iâ€™m forcing myself to hang on to the pro controller.Other than the issues I have mentioned, I will say that the buttons feel decent (when they work). I purchased rubber vinyls to go over the grips and buttons which definitely helped make the controller feel better. I would recommend these vinyls if your hands sweat. The natural controller grips made my hands sweat more than normal, which the vinyls helped cut down considerably.I love Nintendo and the switch but Nintendo has some serious quality control to do on their pro controllers and joy-cons. I understand controllers donâ€™t last forever but when they are $60 and burn-out in under a month from just an average gamer, then thatâ€™s a problem for me.

title: 150% worth it if you EVER play your Switch games docked. It feels so great.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 18, 2018
text: Even my tiny lady hands can't take using the Joy-Cons on the straps or on the small controller included with the console for long periods of time without cramping up. 8 hour sessions of Zelda or Xenoblade would get to be pretty brutal without the pro controller. The long battery life is splendid and it feels amazing to not have to stop playing on one of my few free days for a while so my controller charges because I can literally play all damn day without needing to hook up the usb. It's super comfortable, has a nice weight to it, and I love the d-pad on this (all the buttons feel good, but the dpad gets a special mention). It kind of reminds me of the Xbone d-pad, it's quite satisfying and I have a feeling it'd lend itself very well to any future fighters the Switch might get. And yes, it has the fancy rumble just like the joy-cons do and it feels just as nice here.I initially didn't see the need in a separate controller for my Switch, but after my left joy-con started getting the desync issue I finally caved and ordered one. Nintendo was likely to wipe my Switch during the repair and I was not too thrilled at the idea of buying a whole new set of joy-cons. I figured if the left one worked great still attached to the screen when I played it portable, why not just leave the joycons attached 24/7 and just get the Pro and never worry about syncing issues again. I'm very glad that I did because this makes long gaming sessions 10x better.Also special shout out to the slick design on this because it looks super cool.

title: Yep! This is what I wanted!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on November 28, 2018
text: I bought my Switch last year for Christmas for me from my husband â™¥ï¸. I love playing the Zelda games.The Joy controls took a little getting used to. I don't hate them but I don't love them either. I definitely did not want a corded controller, so the Pro A or Horipad wasn't an option (I think that is what they are called) so I just got used to the Joy con controls. My husband has really big hands so he really has a difficult time playing with the Joy Cons. He doesn't play the Switch that often so it wasn't a big deal. I didn't realize the Pro Controller had come out until recently but I didn't really want to spend the money at the time. However, I just saw that it was on sale after I bought "Let's go Eevee" so I hit the buy it now button and I am really glad I did!!!!  The controller is set just like a pair of Joy Cons so no trying to remember a new pattern. It fits very comfortable in my hands and my husband's hands. Similar in design as the Xbox and PlayStation controls (see photos for comparison) It has a more rounded feel opposed to the Joy Cons. It feels durable and the battery lasts...I played for two days, all day, while my foot was in a cast and it didn't die on me.So far I have played with it on BOTW, Mario Cart 8 and Fortnite. It is not compatible with Let's go Eevee, but there is the Pokeball plus for that. So overall I am very pleased with my purchase and I will probably get a second controller while it is still on sale.

title: Fantastic controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 18, 2017
text: This is a great controller.Currently my favorite controller is the Xbox One controller and I drew a few comparisons to it. This controller comes incredibly close in design to it and I find it very comfortable to hold, though not quite as ergonomic as the Xbox One controller, at least for me. I think so far it has earned a place as my second favorite controller. The buttons are large and responsive. The analog stick is very smooth. The d-pad isn't perfect but it suits my needs (see below.)Hooking it up to the Switch has proved easy and here I have no complaints. I only have Breath of the Wild and Shovel Knight so far and it excels at those games. I prefer it to the joycons due to comfort, and if you're planning on mostly playing in docked mode this is a superior controller. I recommend getting this over getting another set of joycons.Now, for the nontraditional. I have various Raspberry Pis set up throughout my house. It pairs up with it via Bluetooth pretty easily, though reconnecting can sometimes be a pain, I keep a wired controller hooked up at all times for these occasions. Usually if I pair it to the Switch and then try to go back to the Retropie I need to delete it's profile and re-pair. A minor annoyance, but it wasn't designed for this purpose obviously. That said, it plays classic games incredibly smooth.  The d-pad works pretty well, though after turning on the analog stick option it is surprisingly smooth for these old games.  I'm thinking when Nintendo finally releases the virtual console for the Switch this controller will work fantastic for their older titles.I knocked a star off because $70 is just a bit too steep in my opinion.

title: I'd recommend this over buying more joycons or replacing existing joycons
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2018
text: I bought this thing because the joycons that came with my console started having issues that recalibrating was not fixing. I was so used to playing with joycons after a year of only using them. They were very comfortable as a controller in their own right, with or without the shell. I still want to get the joycons repaired or replaced someday when I get more multiplayer games/It took me a day to acclimate to the new controller, but it already feels just as, if not more comfortable than the joycons in the joycon shell. It's heavier but not uncomfortably so, it's comfortable to grip for a few hours of gameplay. Most of the buttons have decent feedback. The battery seems to be almost as good as the joycons were, I got mine last week and still haven't had to charge it since the first day.If I had any complaints, it's that the home menu and snapshot buttons are in an awkward location and don't have any good feedback, as they don't protrude out at all. I used to be able to take a video recording in the middle of a Splatoon game without getting pulled out of the action, but now it feels like I have to stop the action to reach the button.EDIT: Just so you know... it turns out Pro Controllers are not immune to drift. I've got some pretty irritating drift that comes and goes.I still say buying one of these is better than buying any more of those stupid defective joycons. You only require joycons for what, one game? A bad remake of an old pokemon game nobody asked for? The only good thing about Joycons is that you can make them into two tiny controllers but i'd honestly rather splurge to have two normal controllers.

title: Brand name doesn't = great, more money efficient options elsewhere.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2021
text: Many Nintendo products have had a decline in durability, so unless you can snag these at $40.00 or below, there are other cheaper controller options with a variety of pros and cons depending on the product. While the controller is fine, you can easily get other wireless ones for cheaper, and there is enough of them on the market to allow you to choose which drawback(s), if any, you want. The main benefit to buying this controller specifically is because of the name and the official licensing. But that really isn't worth the up-to 100% higher price, as my experience is telling me that there is nothing special, even in quality or durability. I have 4 distinct controllers, and my Pro Controller has had no more or less problems than the others. In my opinion, it doesn't feel as great to hold, unless you like heavy ones, and the motion control function is used in nothing that you'd rather use the joy-cons for.If you just want to not use the base joy-cons, do your research into other controllers first. Getting a decent wired controller for $15-$20 is great if you're looking for a budget (they usually use even less electricity because of lack of battery if you're that cost efficient), and lots have long enough cables for reach to not be an issue.When your controller eventually wears down, if you make the right choice of controller, it's cheaper overall to buy a different one. This Pro Controller might last maybe 10%-20% longer, but if it costs 15%-100% more, it's just so much more cost efficient to choose third-party controllers.

title: Pretty solid, Flawless connectivity and almost non-existent input lag for the time I've had it
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 15, 2021
text: The pro controller is pretty solid. There was flawless connectivity and almost non-existent input lag when I was laying smash bros. The setting up/ pairing of the controller to the switch is almost instantaneous and incredibly easy. VERY, VERY long battery. I tested to see how long the controller battery would last without charging it and got up to 38 hours straight, but when I broke it up into daily game sessions, I got up to a week and a half without charging it. USB-C support and HD rumble are some pretty nice features. The textured grip and textured buttons are pretty satisfying. My problems with the controller have to be about 2 things. #1, the price is incredibly jacked up, I admit it's a good controller, but 70 dollars is way too much, even more than an entire switch game. 2#, the A feels way too of to the side when playing, as well as it feels like it's jammed sometimes.

title: Minor build quality issue with my unit but still a must buy.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 19, 2021
text: A must have for anyone using the dock to play on their television. The left grip on my unit has a slightly loose shaky feeling even from the first moment but the overall build quality and battery life makes it one of my favorite controllers, period. I would definitely like pressure sensitive triggers, rather than having them just be two additional buttons but it's not needed for any first party Nintendo games. It's usually just something I'd like to have playing any other games that benefit from pressure sensitive triggers, such as racing games.Can't imagine playing the Switch docked, again, without this controller like I used to. If you can spare the additional money and intend to play on your television or monitor very often, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this. The build quality may be inconsistent from unit to unit but it's still well worth the investment if you don't play in handheld as often as you do when the Switch is docked.

title: so I had plenty of time with the Joy Cons in different configurations
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 7, 2018
text: I waited a few weeks to order this, so I had plenty of time with the Joy Cons in different configurations.  But for games like Zelda: Breath of the Wild I found the Joy Cons attached to the default dumb controller attachment that comes with the Switch to be a little wanting.  My hands are a bit larger, so it's very nice to have a larger full controller to work with.One thing I did experience, the first time I sync'd the controller to my Switch I did have some small instances where the controllers tilt functionality was hesitant or laggy. (Example: When using my bow in BotW, it just didn't want to fine tune my targeting by tilting the controller.)  But it seemed to correct itself after only a few minutes of use and I've never experienced the issue again.It also holds a charge for a fairly long time.  I can go a number of days with using the controller an hour or two a day between charging.  However, I cannot detail exactly how many hours of use.  I simply decide that it's been a few days and I plug it in again between uses.If you use amiibos, there seems to be a sweet spot on the controller that can be a pain to find initially. It's not necessarily obvious on where that is. But once you find it and get used to it, then scanning your amiibos goes quicklyOverall it's a very solid controller.  I'm glad I bought one.

title: Fells a bit more traditional like an Xbox or PS controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on December 30, 2017
text: Fells a bit more traditional like an Xbox or PS controller.  The joycon seems a bit too easy to click the joystick down on accident while in the heat of battle that was the main reason I got this controller and for a bit more comfort.  The only problem I have with button layout is the + key is close to the Home key and the - is close to the capture button and it can be easy to confuse them or not feel comfortably certain you're gonna hit the right one while playing.  This is minor though as ur usually looking to pause anyway when going for those buttons and if u hit the wrong one it isn't terrible, also u get better as u use it I'm sure.  The joysticks have a lot of room for play yet don't seem to activate untill you've moved them about 50% towards the direction you're going.  Then the last 50% is where u have the control to manage speed.  I.E. if youre trying to walk slowly it feels like you have to move the joystick farther than you should have to before walking begins which leaves less room for control in the stride between walking and running.  This may be fixable in some sensitivity settings I'll have to play around.  Overall though great controller it feels much better playing Zelda with this over the joycon (which is decent itself with the grips)

title: Nice optional? accessory
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on November 17, 2017
text: Mama Mia, it'sa good. I like.Price is too high, but I got a deal on a refurbished one. Lasts a good while, several days on a charge for me. Up to a week, even with some heavy play. Nintendo put some thought into this, it's definitely quality like all of their other products. Very comfortable, comparable to a GameCube controller, which has always been my favourite, but with the motion abilities of a Wiimote.While I wouldn't say it's ABSOLUTELY necessary to have one of these for single player games, it sure makes lengthier play more comfortable and gives you the option to switch between charging this and switching to the joy-con and vice versa, if needed. I rarely need to, though. The battery is much longer lasting than the Ps4's dual-shock. (I suspect it's the lighting and possibly touchpad, speaker and maybe even powering a headset that also drains more.) What more can I say? Everything about it is A+ quality, except maybe the d-pad. It's a little...hmm... imprecise. The way the buttons are separated on the actual joy-con and comparatively, the Ps4 controller makes it easier to not accidentally hit something slightly the wrong way, say northwest-ish, instead of just straight north. I find myself accidentally triggering the wrong thing a tad more often on this controller compared to the joy-con. Otherwise, if you can snag a good deal, this is very nice... while making Nintendo a lot of cash--I mean, supporting them.

title: A very comfortable and intuitive controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 14, 2018
text: I have been a Nintendo Switch owner for almost a year, and while I love the joy-con controller and grip overall, sometimes I prefer a more reliable and "traditional" controller.  I finally picked this controller up on amazon this week.  I love it.  This is one of the most comfortable controllers I have ever used, which increases the enjoyment of my Switch games even more.  The battery life is good, the layout makes sense, and it has built in motion-sensors for gyro-scope aiming, which comes in handy for games like "Splatoon 2" and "Zelda: Breath of the Wild."  The only major downside to this controller is that the button layout for the "pause" and "home" buttons took a while to get used to, partially since the color scheme can make the buttons look similar.  Other than that, I have no real issues with this controller; the battery life is good, and the controller itself is very comfortable, maybe matching the Gamecube controller as my favorite Nintendo controller.  I would recommend picking this controller up for your switch.  I spent months playing hours of Zelda: Breath of the Wild but worried about the stability of the controller I was using to some extent.  Now I can comfortably sit back and play Breath of the Wild for even more hours on end with a controller that feels great!  The controller is a little pricey, but more than worth it.  So pick it up, and enjoy many hours of fun and comfortable gaming!Peace,Dana

title: Good

title: Game changer

text: I've used some of the generic brands and a lot of them died after less than a month. Buying the legit controllers was a major game changer.

title: Way better than holding a joycon in each hand
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 20, 2018
text: The pro controller is very good as far as controllers go. Of course the layout is very similar to an XBox controller, which I always found a let-down considering the GameCube controller was so uniquely Nintendo and also very comfortable and effective. That said, all 4 shoulder buttons are sized well and spaced out well; the trigger action on ZR and ZL are better than the PS4 and XBox controllers, in my opinion, because they provide the right amount of spring -- neither too much nor too little tension, which is what I prefer for shooters.I have 3 critiques. First, the A, B, X, and, Y buttons feel so cheap. They look generic, and there's something about how they feel when you press them that comes off as preschool-toyish. They're not terrible, but it's something I always notice. Second, the "rumble" feature is more like a stronger version of a cell phone's vibrator. It's just a generic, flat, buzzing feeling. Compare that to the PS4 rumble where it feels like some creature is crawling around inside your controller. Sometimes it's so jarring that I look down at the controller to see what's going on. I don't know what Sony's mechanism is, but it's more effective than Nintendo's. Third, naturally, is the price ðŸ˜± Nothing to say about that that hasn't already been said.If you're low on cash but still want a Switch, you'll be fine without the pro controller. I definitely recommend picking one up at some point, though. I might actually buy a second one soon.

title: Best official Nintendo controller ever.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 21, 2022
text: Better than the GameCube controller as the GameCube is a glorified Smash Bros controller and sucks with 2D gaming. If you're a Android user the charger that comes with it doubles as a charger for your Android. You're getting 40 hrs of playtime after each charge as well which is ridiculous playtime value.

title: Amazing General-Purpose Controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 27, 2019
text: The Switch Pro controller is an amalgamation of designs such as the Xbox 360 controller and the Dualshock 2. Having an outer ring, the analog sticks feel similar to the Dualshock 4's as well. The buttons are flat, as opposed to the convex buttons on microsoft controllers, which makes this more comfortable for me to press repeatedly. The back buttons are digital instead of triggers, which makes it more suitable to instant actions. I think this is the ideal controller for Bayonetta, and games like it.The D-Pad is outstanding given how generic in application this controller is. It is very slightly elevated in the center, meaning the hat switch is easy to rock back and forth. It doesn't hurt my thumb very much compared to a lot of previous Nintendo designs, but you may develop a callus if playing fighting games frequently.The controller's large button design can make it feel a bit clunky with some games, particularly in comparsion to playstation controllers. The placement of the D-Pad also is a bit unfortunate for games where you might want to use a claw grip on the left hand. Overall, this is a passable current generation controller to use when your switch is docked, certainly an improvement over joycons.

title: A great controller.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 3, 2020
text: If I had to pick my favorite controller from this generation of say that the Nintendo Switch Pro beats put the Xbox One Pro Controller and the PS4 dualshock. Comfortable grip for long play sessions, responsive buttons, comfortable sticks. As all controllers however I have my gripes. The D-pad, although far better than the buttons on a Joy-Con, is not the best Nintendo has ever put on a controller. This disappoints me a lot, I've owned many Nintendo systems and their D-pads have always been the best in the industry so to see this decline is a personal gripe I can't help but share. I do prefer triggers with feedback, but you won't miss much with the simple button like design on this. The biggest merit of the Pro Controller is the built in gyro, playing shooters is a far far better thing with this gyro enhanced aiming. Don't believe me? Play Splatoon 2 with and without it. Although awkward as you get your berrings, it will soon become natural and you'll find yourself unable to shake the habit of expecting all controllers you use to react to your subtle hand motions.Good controller, would recommend.

title: Yaaaaaaay

title: So expensive....Yet so good!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 11, 2018
text: I used my Wii U's Pro Controller so much that there is heavy wear marks on the analog stick hats.When I bought a Switch, I saw the price tag of this controller and thought it was ridiculous.  A gamer friend chided me, telling me I'd eventually get the Pro Controller.I got a Mayflash NS adapter and tried syncing my XBox One controller and Wii U Pro Controller to the Switch.  It worked, but the controllers either suffered from large analog stick deadzones, and/or incorrect neutral point settings on the analog sticks. In frustration I shelved the adapter and just used the Switch's side controllers with the included controller bracket.I have large hands so the Switch's side controllers were awkward to use.  After about a week, I caved in and got this Pro Controller.As the same friend said:  "Nintendo sure knows how to make a good controller".  The fit, finish, and battery life of this controller is AWESOME.  I've been binge playing Payday 2 with said friend plus another friend and even during long weekend gaming sessions, my hands aren't sore or cramped thanks to this controller's ergonomics.So is the price of this controller justifiable? In my case.... It was.  But I gritted my teeth as I placed the order here on Amazon.  As I've said in the past, Nintendo sure knows how to get me to open my wallet.  I don't think you'll need this controller if the Switch is mostly played by children.  But teens and adults may find the ergonomics of this controller too good to pass up.

title: Hands down the best!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 14, 2021
text: The price of an official controller was always a turn-off for me.  For a long while I simply used third-party controllers, and they'd work well enough for me for the games I played.  Now that I've finally bitten the bullet and gotten an official controller though, I have to say there is absolutely no comparison.  Better hand feel, better responsiveness, perfectly balanced button sensitivity (i.e. they're plenty sensitive enough for quick response when pressed, but not so sensitive that they'd be accidentally triggered when you're just resting your fingers on them, as was a problem with one of the third-party controllers I tried).  All around, this controller is just plain better!  Now that I've experienced it, I don't plan on ever using another third-party controller again.  It's 100% worth the higher price!

title: The best gaming controller so far
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 21, 2019
text: I think that this controller is the best controller that you can buy at the moment. It fits well in your hand, it functions almost perfectly (the d-pad is below average, but not awful, better than og gc controllers), has a long battery life (it hasnâ€™t run out on me since I bough it), and has seemingly no input delay. So why donâ€™t I give it 5 stars? Because there are a bunch of tiny things I have gripes with that donâ€™t apply to 99% of games. I think that the tops of the control sticks are too wide, but I enjoy the c-nub that comes on the gc controllers that a lot of people dislike. I like to slide my fingers over the face buttons when mashing our of grabs in smash, and these buttons roll a little to much for my liking. The fact that the sticks also donâ€™t have notches are good in some scenarios but bad in others (an example is when trying to do macro wavebounce neutral specials in smash; itâ€™s harder to do them bc of the lack of notches, but much itâ€™s easier to play shooter games like warframe and splatoon). The point Iâ€™m trying to make is that, if youâ€™re not me, you wonâ€™t have any problems with this controller at all, other than the d-pad being bad.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on October 2, 2020
text: This is a great controller, in my opinion it's worth the extra money to get this over the other aftermarket switch controllers, much more comfortable than the joycons, but still a little too small for people with large hands, you'll find yourself with one finger covering the shoulder buttons instead of two like you could comfortably do with an Xbox or PS4 controller. This is technically compatible with PC but you will have to use it wirelessly, and due to some odd bug the gyro glitches out the DirectInput controls if you have this enabled in Steam... so you have to manually choose between DirectInput OR steam, can't do both at the same time, with that said you'll still want to have an XBOX controller on hand for the occasional PC game where you find yourself wanting a controller. Otherwise this is great and a must have if you want to play really long games on your switch like Xenoblade or FE3H.

title: Fake Controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 31, 2023
text: This controller is advertised as being the real deal from the Nintendo Store, but the one I got turned out to be a reproduction. Furthermore, this replica has poor quality sticks it seems; barely 5 months in and the left stick started showing drift that made it unusable. Had to have stick replaced and after seeing the internal bits, the motherboard, and some research, it became clear this was not an original controller. Aside from the blatant misadvertising, the only reason this has 2 stars is because the rest of the controller is decent. Never had a quality controller before this one so the build quality had me fooled.

title: A must for when playing in Dock Mode...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 15, 2021
text: The Switch Pro Controller is a must for any owner of a Nintendo Switch... specially when looking for a second controller to play with while the Joy-Cons recharges. It's a bit smaller than what it looks like in the pictures, but holding it in hands feels fine and has a great quality build to it. It's packaged with a USB cable for charging, which can be used for the Switch itself as well. The rumble is subtle without being uncomfortable and the battery last a good enough amount of time. The greatest aspect about the Pro Controller is the feel of the buttons, they are all smooth, easy to push without tiring your fingers, responsive analogues that don't feel loose and a amazing D-pad that I wish Nindendo would use in the Joy-Cons. For all it is worth the price.

title: Excellent controller; try not to drop it or, Lord forbid, throw it.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 7, 2021
text: Out of the box, this controller is fantastic. Feels good, doesn't feel cheap, and plays well, too.However:I've had to order a few. I keep my controller on the stand beside my couch, and on occasion I have bumped it or knocked it off, clattering onto the hardwood below. After a few of these tumbles I can tell a difference in the handling of the joysticks, a bit of sticking, not quite as precise. For most Switch games this isn't a big deal; that said, for games where players tend to be competitive -- say, Super Smash Bros. Ultimate -- you will have some frustration there.Avoid this by not dropping it in the first place. Good controller, just take care of the thing.

title: High Quality Controller, Expensive Price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 23, 2020
text: When I picked up my Switch a few years ago, I picked up a pro controller to go with it. Why? Because I knew that I would use it on my TV a lot, plus with bigger games like Zelda Breath of the Wild and Mario Odyssey, I knew I would enjoy them much more with a standard controller. The pro controller reminds me a little of an Xbox controller, but a little bulkier. However, after time, it really fits your hands well. It's high quality and again, awesome to use if the Switch is either your main gaming console or your only gaming console (which it is for me). I also love it for games like Super Smash Bros, DOOM, Witcher 3, Skyrim and other titles. I would say, though, with the expensive asking price, if you use your Switch mostly in handheld mode or if you are only a casual gamer, or do most of your major gaming on another console/PC, then I'd probably pass on picking one of these up.

title: Works great until it breaks.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on August 7, 2018
text: I bought one at Gamestop and the left joystick stopped working after a few months.  I sent it back to Nintendo under warranty thinking it was a fluke and bought another one while it was being repaired.  The first one came back and worked fine but then after a few more months both failed, out of warranty.  The problem seems to be the ball cover of the joystick top rubs against the round opening of the case and creates all sorts of plastic dust that gets into the joystick electronic switches and causes them to fail.  I opened up the case, blew out the electronics and it worked for a little bit but then the problem came back, even though I kept the joystick top clean.  I tried isopropyl alcohol to flush it, vacuumed it out and it worked afterwards for a week of heavy use but then failed again.  I was quoted $25 or $29 to repair.  But instead I bought a third party one and it has worked longer than the other two and continues to work.  Until they fix this design flaw don't throw your money away.  Shame because when it works, its smooth and responsive and has a very nice feel.

title: Great controller!

I've read that there were more problems with controllers for the Switch compared to other consoles both with the pro controllers and joycons but supposedly Nintendo identified and fixed the production issues.The second Pro controller I ordered seems to work correctly so far.  I tried it on Zelda Breath of the Wild for a few minutes but will have to play more this weekend.  This controller is very comfortable just like the Wii U controller and comparable to PS4 and XBox controllers.  Hopefully this one will work for awhile. title: Buttoms Stopped Working Properly
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 27, 2022
text: Nintendo has an issue with it's controller. I had a PS4 for years, only one controller. I have a Series X, only one controller. I used a Xbox One Controller on PC for years, no issues. The only issues i've ever had with controllers are with Nintendo, way back in the N64 days, then in the Wii Days... and now in the Switch days.I have a Pro controller that has been working flawlessly since I bought a Switch back in 2017. However, the Joycon's that came with it have long since died and before they died they had drift issues.. I bought 2 of the yellow Joy Con's... those too died (one of them simply stopped working after 1 month). I bought a second Pro Controller... that one got drift issues too.So a few weeks ago I bought another one of these like an idiot. "Because my wife wanted to play Animal Crossings". What a schmuck. The brand new controller worked for a whole 3 to 5 days. Then suddenly it would randomly count 1 press of a button as if i had pressed it multiple times. Someone else said it already. These controllers are... good. They aren't bad... if they work.I'll say this though, sure I'm going to wait out Breath of the Wild 2... but that probably will be my last Nintendo purchase. I have played Nintendo for decades, but they have always been guilty of crappy hardware. I'm sure some of you have stories of how PlayStation or Xbox controllers have broken on you, but let's be real. I bet those are far outweighed by the sheer amount of people that have had to buy multiple controllers for Nintendo products. For me personally, i don't have issues with any other controllers than Nintendo's. 70 bucks for a paperweight basically.

title: A Controller that will take your experience up a level.

title: Great Controller, needed replacement after 1 mo. though.

text: I have a bad thumb resulting from an injury and surgery, and the Joy Cons are basically unusable for me. title: Great controller with some D pad issues
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2019
text: It's one of the most ergonomically comfortable video game controllers I've ever used. I have arthritis and cannot play on most controllers very long at all & this controller was a huge change for me, because now I can actually play video games for more than 20 minutes at a time again without pain. I like that you can also use it on PC for Steam games. I had some issues with mine where the plastic hand grips did not line up flush with the controller body and I had to return a few and do a Nintendo repair to finally get one that didn't have that issue, but that wasn't a serious issue and I think it's just that I really hate the feel of a noticeable edge on my hands. The controller does have an issue with the D pad sometimes registering the wrong inputs. I never noticed this problem until Tetris 99. For games like that or 2D platformers that require a lot of precise D pad inputs it is not the best controller. But for 3D games it works well. I loved playing Breath of the Wild with it.

title: Questionable material
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2022
text: It's probably just the quality of all the Nintendo Switch Pro Controllers in general, but I dropped this thing once and the bottom left side has jutted out ever since. Otherwise, it works perfectly fine.

title: Feels Right in Your Hands!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2017
text: I figured I'd be happy with the stock Joy Con controllers in the handle.  My hands are smaller than most gamers, so it was relatively comfortable for me to use them, until I tried to play Mario Kart with my brother with the individual Joy Cons...  Even my smaller hands aren't tiny enough to work them comfortably, and they aren't evenly matched since the buttons are sort of off kilter as a pair.I needed a second controller if I wanted to play properly with someone else.  Enter this beauty!  The Pro Controller instantly has a great feel right out of the box, with a nice sure weight that comes from its rumble pack and internal battery.  It works great if you have problems using the smaller Joy Con controller in its handle accessory.  The controller charges relatively quick, and pairing is easy with the console once you've plugged the charge cable into the Switch base at least once.My only beef with it is unless you have a special case that has room for a pro controller, its a pain in the butt to transport/travel with.  Anything that touches any button or joy stick will activate it and kill the battery in it.  I don't plan on traveling with it much, so for a home controller, it works perfect!  Love it!

title: awesome
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2022
text: great

title: A Joy to Use
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2017
text: When I first unwrapped the Pro Controller and held it I was astounded at how *good* it felt to hold it. I wouldn't have thought a controller could feel better than an Xbox 360 controller, but Nintendo's newest (and rather pricey) Pro Controller definitely surpasses it. I actually just pick it up at random, without playing a game, to marvel at the quality and amazing feel. Weird, I know.The design feels solid without too much weight, the handles have a comfortable grippy material pleasant to the touch, and the buttons and control sticks are larger than the Joy-Con's buttons and sticks. The good ol' Nintendo d-pad is nice to have as well.The cost certainly deterred me. When an extra DualShock 4 or Xbox One controller costs around $25 less (or $10 more if you design our own at Xbox Design Lab), this seemed a bit much. However, after feeling it in hand, playing with it and knowing there's a fair bit of tech in there compared to others, I've found it to be a good investment for myself and can recommend it to anyone who will be playing their Switch docked or with local multiplayer. For me it is definitely worth the extra time working to save up for it."It's dangerous to go alone! Take this."

title: Fails early due to poor quality control or workmanship!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2022
text: Iâ€™m over 60 but have been playing video games since the 1980s and found BOTW alone to be worth the the price of a Switch console. I bought and used this controller for that game for about 3 months and stopped playing for about 10 months. Picked up the Pro controller after a full charge and all was good for about a week. Now the controller wonâ€™t charge the perfectly good battery. I have to take the controller apart and charge the battery in an off brand controller that works fine and is older than the Nintendo controller.  Between all the joystick failures Iâ€™ve heard about from my grandkids along with this charging failure I conclude this product is poorly made and should not be priced this high with only a 90 day warranty. My advice is stay away from the overpriced Nintendo controller unless you need Amiibo or other special features.  Failure after such a small amount of usage by an adult is proof it is the productâ€™s fault and not abuse by kids.  Very disappointing, Nintendo!  Iâ€™ve owned every console since the original NES (except Wii U) and this is the first terrible product Iâ€™ve owned from Nintendo. I will buy an off brand wireless to replace this failed garbage one.  Note to others: Be sure the off brand model can turn on the consoleâ€¦ made that mistake before buying this â€œmistakeâ€ last year.

text: Great controller all around. (Advertised battery life is 40 hours or so)-Can be used for gaming in the Switch, PC and even mobiles phones.Cons- The left and right triggers are not analog, meaning that using the control for racing games is not optimal in the PC- Setting the control for PC gaming  can be a bit tricky and if your PC does not have a bluetooth adapter then you won't be able to use it. The included USB-C cable only brings in power and not data, so the only way to connect the controller to a PC is via bluetooth.Overall this is a great controller and I'm really happy with my purchase. title: Worth Every Penny
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2018
text: The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is, putting it conservatively, Nintendo's best controller yet in terms of functionality and comfort. Its understated clear/black finish belies its immensely satisfying buttons, sticks, and D-pad; additionally, button placement feels extremely natural, and the impeccable build quality will ensure that this controller will stand up to many long gaming sessions. Even with motion control, an NFC sensor, and HD Rumble, it lasts an amazing 40 hours on a single charge - half of what the Wii U Pro Controller did, but still more than the DualShock 4 and the Xbox One controller combined. The Pro Controller also works natively on Windows PCs via USB or Bluetooth, and is even compatible with Steam if the user participates in the Steam Client Beta. My only real gripe is that the HD Rumble in this controller isn't quite as pronounced as that in the Joy-Cons, but I chalk that up to the function having to travel through denser plastics, so it's really more of a nitpick than anything. If you have a Switch and want to graduate from the Joy-Con Grip, there is no reason not to own this controller - it earns its keep and then some.

title: Great controller for average gamer; Great connectivity and comfort

title: Extremely high quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2021
text: Going from joycons to this pro controller made an incredible difference!  The pro controller is so smooth, and feels far more secure and less flimsy than the joycons. I feel free to swivel the joystick as much as I want, or to mash any of the buttons as often as I like, and it still feels smooth and sturdy.  Though the transition between joycons and the pro controller took some getting used to (and a lot of stupid deaths due to overreaching for buttons), it's definitely worth it.  I'm sticking with the pro controller from here on out.

Big to hold, nice solid responsive buttons.- DEFINITELY a step up from split joycons as you probably could have guessed. You can play multiplayer games with both joycons (I use them without grips), and the pro controller. Also, you can count the pro controller as a 3rd controller if two others use split joycons. So over all, an additional controller.These are the key reasons why I think the controller is worth the investment.Edit:I forgot to mention a very huge plus:The Pro controller pairs with the System as smoothly as the Joycons. It is as if Nintendo just decided to make the most ergonomic and functional controller they could, and they did just that. It does not look super flashy, but it is a damn fine controller. The buttons are big and comfortable, the controller sits nicely in the hand, the triggers are designed really well so they feel great and are natural to rest your fingers on.I know the controller is pricey, but if you play the Switch a fair bit at home docked, then its worth it. Great investment

title: Best Nintendo controller in decades
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2017
text: This is a must have for the Switch. Gaming is so much easier with the pro controller than with the LR Joy Cons that come with the system (which I find buggy). If you are a fan of the PS 4 controller, you will love the Switch's Pro. Very similar. Allows for a nice grip and easy game playing. While everyone loved the Wii's motion censored controller, I often found i buggy and that it wouldn't synchronize well. There were also so many different ways to use it that it wasn't simple enough for me. I also prefer two handed game play. The Switch's Pro Controller allows both hands on one controller, and since it isn't a motion controller like, the Wii, and doesn't have two components to it, like the Switch's Joy, you don't have the issues of synching and connectivity. It's an intuitive controller to use, as well. You don't have to "think" while using it.Only reason I'm docking a star is because of the price. At $69.99 I find it really expensive, especially given how poorly the Joy Cons work for games like MARIO Kart. You will want two Pros if you have that game. But that is a $140 additional investment, not to mention tax.

title: Comfy controller with an amazing battery life
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2019
text: This is the official brand pro controller for the Nintendo Switch. In layout, it is very similar to an Xbox 360/One controller, with the exception of the ABXY buttons being changed around a bit. Ergonomically, it is very comfortable to hold, which is surprising since I have very small hands. However, the comfort of a controller is very subjective, so the only real way you will know is if you hold one for yourself. The controller is very easy to connect to the Nintendo Switch console or a PC and has a great wireless range. The controller includes a lithium-ion battery that has a killer battery life of 40 hours, which is so long that sometimes I forget I even have to charge this thing and get shocked when a low battery warning shows up on the screen. The $70 MSRP of the controller seems very steep, but for the comfort, battery life, gyro, and NFC reader, it is worthwhile if you play your Switch a lot. Since it's $50 rn, I would recommend it even more.

title: Very good controller, but difficult to use on PC.

text: This controller feels comfortable to hold, the buttons are very responsive, the analog sticks are easy to move with precision, it's basically perfect if you want to just use it for your Switch. It's definitely better than Joycons. I had a really hard time getting it to work on my PC though. It took me many headache inducing hours of downloading drivers, installing different programs, switching to different USB wires and ports, and I only got it to work by seemingly random chance. After FINALLY getting it to actually work on my computer though, I have loved using it for steam games and emulators.tl;dr the controller works really well, but be prepared for frustration when trying to use it for PC.

The inclusion of a proper D-Pad, is also a plus, as i found the 4 buttons on the joycon that act as the D-Pad, just felt weird, when i tried to use what should've been a D-Pad. The buttons and thumbsticks, just seem to react better overall. The battery life of the Pro, is really long. Somewhere around 40 hours, off of 1 charge. I only own Zelda BOTW so far, so i can't comment on the rumble feature, as Zelda barely uses it, and i also can't comment on the built in Amiibo scanner, as i have yet to use it, since i don't have any Amiibo. title: TRASH-Not For Incremental Movements
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on August 8, 2020
text: Is an okay controller and takes some getting used to for certain games. Not recommended for incremental movements for games that require motion detail, unless you're willing to spend extra time practicing for that specific game or unless the game has that all movement where you can physically direct the controller to position on screen. Once you know how to work it, it's okay; the joysticks are kinda stiff meaning they either go one way or the other and you can't move just right in a smooth, slow motion if you need to do it quickly like a computer mouse. Does last a long time on one charge which is a huge plus.Update:Pros - Charge lasts a long time, durability is great (but I mean it has to be, it's supposed to take a beating if it's a pro controller I assume)Cons - Very stiff and underdeveloped joy sticks. This is a major downside for me because my hands are getting more of a workout than they should and I have averaged sized hands. Incremental movements are a must in gaming and it makes it extremely hard when you are more focusing on disciplining the movement of your had to control the joy stick than the actual game itself. It's really more for the use of playing those Nintendo classic games where input is forgiving and not for more aggressive high action movement games such as FPS and BR games. I'm bored with Nintendo classics, make a true pro controller.Update 08/05/21:As you start gaming on a consistent basis and start tensing in the hands due to concentration and frustration, you'll start to notice the bulk of the controller and the placement of the left joystick is not conducive or practical for gaming and causes your hands to feel uncomfortable everytime you pick up the controller; it will start to feel unnatural to hold. Honestly, now that I put it all together,  Nintendo used this as a gimmick to just increase sales, there really isn't a good reason to spend this amount of money on a controller like this. You'll basically be overpaying for the battery life and that's it.Update: It's really a trash controller, marketed for those that really don't game and wouldn't know any better. Drift galore, but cleaning can kinda fix that. Controller died out completely a week ago and nothing can fix it. Lasted 4 years with the switch collecting dust for majority of the time; it should still be usable. I tried pairing again (the reset button at the top), tried updating...essentially came to the conclusion it's literally garbage now. I guess 4 years is better than ps5 dualsense controller's 1 year. Input lag/responsiveness very noticeable on this controller. Not sure if I mentioned before, but this really started to get on my nerves after a while. Have buyer's remorse with both the switch and it's so called "pro" controller lmao more like slow junk. After my ps5 purchase, the switch will be collecting more dust or I'll give it away to my baby cousins; that is if they'll even want and use it.

title: A 5 star controller that gets dinged just for price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 13, 2018
text: Let me say right away that this thing is 5 stars for every single reason other than price. I only put it at 4 because the price point for this thing is so ridiculous at $70. It honestly feels better in the hand than my PS4 controller does (the handles are a bit straighter and narrower) and Nintendo really needs to think about including one of these with the console. The battery in it is also phenomenal, as a single charge seems to last for weeks of standby and play. It's silly that you have to buy this thing in the first place, and sadly because of it's high price, I feel that few will get to experience the joy of playing with this. It really made my Switch feel more like a proper home console than the Joy Con did. I actually play it way more on the TV now than I did previously, and it's made me download a lot more of the indie games to play on the TV as well. Overall it's fantastic and I would say every switch owner really deserves one; it's unfortunate Nintendo priced it so very few will be willing to shell out the money for it.

title: Excellent controller for the Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on November 12, 2018
text: I have big hands, so the Joy-Con controllers that come with the Switch are difficult for me to use (and they tend to lose sync every so often, which can interrupt games).  The Pro Controller is almost exactly the same size as an Xbox One controller and feels just as comfortable to me, the sticks and buttons are good quality, the battery life is great, and it charges quickly.  And I have not lost sync with this controller once yet.  I received a second Pro Controller as a gift, and it works just as well, giving me a lot of flexibility.The only complaint I have with this controller has less to do with the controller itself and more with how Nintendo designed some of its games to work with the Joy-Cons.  Super Mario Odyssey, for example, has a few specific moves that can only be performed on the Joy-Cons because they require the Joy-Cons to move independently, which you can't do with the Pro Controller.  Thankfully, none of these things actually make the games hard to play.

title: Nearly Perfect
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 26, 2019
text: The Switch Pro controller is an amazing controller. I like everything about it, from the buttons to the analogue sticks. The HD rumble is great, and it's just the right size for my hands. And don't even get me started on the battery life. This thing's battery lasts so long that I often forget it even needs to be charged every once in a while.But I can't give it a full five stars. Reason being that the point where the analogue stick makes contact with the edges of the controller cause some serious abrasion. This has happened to both my pro controllers, and gives the analogue stick endpoints a slight grindy-ness for lack of a better term. It probably won't do anything serious to the controller's longevity, but it makes it lose its "premium" feel after about ten hours of use.I would love it if Nintendo offered an "elite" option like Microsoft does for the Xbox One. Even if it matched its price of $150, it would guarantee a premium-feeling controller that would maintain its premium feel for hundreds of hours of gameplay.

title: A Great Docked-Switch Accessory
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 18, 2020
text: Over the last few years, Nintendo has been largely absent from the "Pro" Controller sphere.  The last Nintendo Pro controller was for the Wii U and with very little use, it didn't last very long.  I had mine for about a year and it stopped working.  It felt cheap and in the end, it was indeed cheaply made.  With the Switch Pro Controller, we finally get a high quality handheld controller.  It feels great in your hands and I would say it's a must-have for docked gaming.  Some complain about the d-pad but I haven't had any issues thus far.  It's a bit expensive but it feels expensive (more so than the last Nintendo Pro controller); there's a certain heft to it. (It's not heavy but it's nicely weighted.)  Highly recommended!

title: Totally Worth It
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 18, 2022
text: Comfortable to hold, and functional (works perfectly!).At one point, tried a non-Nintendo equivalent ... looked *almost* the same, but just felt odd and uncomfortable.  Returned that one, and got another Nintendo-brand controller (pro).

title: Great controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 27, 2017
text: This is probably the most comfortably designed controller I've ever held. The buttons are nice and big and feel great to press, the weight is good, the sticks feel great, like all Nintendo analog sticks do. HD rumble and motion controls work fine and battery life is worlds ahead of the PS4 controller. The D-pad is a step down from typically Nintendo design though, having no ball underneath the center, so every direction can be pushed in at once, which can occasionally cause problems, but I've played a ton of Tetris and shovel Knight with it and it's still pretty solid. The erganomics are stellar though, to be sure. Feels better than any other controller that I can think of and I think the Xbox one S controller is pretty top notch comfort-wise. Also, with the right Bluetooth controller adapter it can be used on the PS3 and aside from the six axis crap not being present it works perfectly. I blasted through a good portion of uncharted with it just to test it. I bought mine used too which I'm normally leery of, but it's really study and I've had no issues at all. I love it.

title: Great Controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 19, 2021
text: I dock my switch a lot, but also play hand-held as well, got tired of constantly having to take the joy cons off the switch and put them back on. Plus, the controller handle that comes with the switch to use with the joy cons is too small to use comfortably for extended periods of time. I tried a couple of other controllers, but this Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is as comfortable as my X-Box controller and works flawlessly. My only complaint is that the A-B-X-Y buttons are reversed from the X-Box controller...gonna have to change the buttons on one or the other eventually...definitely worth the investment

title: Best Switch Controller, Period.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 18, 2021
text: Expert Info:Most controllers actually have high input lag. Especially when used with a cable on the Switch specifically. This happens because the USB-C connects from the dock to the switch.However, the Switch has bluetooth inside which actually makes wireless mode with the pro controller one of, if not the fastest methods to play.I tried 8bitdo too with a PS4 controller. It worked but heavy input lag you could feel. What gets me is that this controller and the R,L,Zr,Xl buttons feel way better than I expected. Actually like it over the PS4 controller which was really hard to admit.Love it!

title: Beyond my expectations
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 5, 2022
text: I bought this controller to play Zelda skyward sword. This controller made me have a second opinion about the game that I didnâ€™t like that much before. Comfortable, durable! Highly recommended

title: One star docked due to no analog triggers.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on November 5, 2021
text: Besides that, its honestly one of the best controllers out there. I really like the grip better than the xbox 360s. Long battery life, currently still on my first charge though ive only played about 8 or 9 hours with it off the charger. Its definitely a must have for metroid dread.

title: My favorite controller to date, just pricey
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 15, 2017
text: Boy do I love this controller. I've had every controller since the NES and the Gamecube and Xbox 360 controllers were always my favorite. This has taken the cake for sure. It sits in your hands very well, all button placements feel appropriate and ergonomic. The weight or heft of the controller is perfect, a little on the heavy side but not enough to fatigue you. Sticks are fantastic, D pad is arguably the best (you may prefer the Sony style, but this is easily second to that if so). It also uses USB C to charge so you can (likely) share the cable with your phone for years to come.Only complaint I have is the price, which when you factor in the battery life, amiibo function, motion controls, is understandable but still hard to swallow when you consider the library for this controller. You'll likely only use it to play Zelda for a long while until other Switch titles start rolling out. You can be crafty and use it on your PC for sure, but it would be nice if Nintendo made it plug-n-play for PC as Microsoft has done.

title: High quality Nintendo product
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 18, 2020
text: Sturdy and comfortable to hold.Works fine on PC. While most games do not support it natively, Steam offers native support. So if you launch other games using Steam, you will be able to use this controller without issue.I did not use the wireless connectivity feature on PC, but it works just fine with a Nintendo Switch controller.Tiny dimples in the handle of the controller offer some air flow and grip for your hands.Slight design flaws in the controller itself can be overlooked for most games. For example, I would never suggest using this controller for Super Smash Bros. Ultimate due to the size of the right-stick interfering with pressing the Y or B buttons. Especially if you have large hands.

title: Also Works for Noobs, Name Notwithstanding
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 15, 2019
text: It's a great controller. If you're looking to use something that feels more like a modern controller than the double joycon configuration then this is where it's at. The d-pad is always welcome. The layout feels much less cramped. The sticks feel sturdier and more substantial. The + and - buttons are much easier and more comfortable to access. The only downsides to the pro controller are that it uses standard rumble instead of HD rumble, it doesn't disconnect to operate as two controllers, and it costs an extra sum of money on top of the system itself. But for the amount of playtime you'll get out of it and the comfort it will afford you, it's easily worth the money. This one is a bit plain, but if you're not quite sold on the concept entirely yet then you probably won't mind knocking off a few bucks to get one without some special design.

title: Pictures dont do it justice
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 19, 2017
text: Until this controller is in your hands, you can't help but feel it's a waste of money- based on the pictures. But boy this is a beauty. Especially up close, it's a work of art. It feels extremely durable & very solid, it's got a nice weight to it and fits my hands perfectly. I'd go as far to say this controller is more comfortable than Xbox 1 and ps4 controllers. $70 may seem steep for a controller but let's remember there is an accurate motion sensor built into this. Plus the battery life is incredible, I've read it lasts 40 hours. I've played here and there for 2 weeks and still haven't needed to charge it.The reason I rated it 4 stars is because...well first and foremost, people don't trust 5 star reviews BUT also the controller is not very breathable. I believe it's mostly the material used for the hand-grips. So your hands will get sweaty sometimes. Nevertheless, in my opinion this controller was definitely worth the money.Also keep in mind the controls will be stiff until you break it in, and it will feel super goofy once you're used to the joycons and same vice versa lol.

title: Worth it for anyone with large hands
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 6, 2021
text: Excellent controller. The buttons are bigger than the joy-con, which I suppose I should have expected but it was a nice surprise. If youâ€™re like me and are looking for a bigger alternative to the Switchâ€™s small joy-cons, this is a great option. Only thing I wish this controller were cheaper (or even better, included with the Switch). Considering that Nintendo doesnâ€™t ship this with the Switch, it becomes an almost-required extra cost for anyone with large hands. That said, the controller is solid and the price is on par with the other major gaming brands.

title: Works as expexted

title: Great if you need a 2nd controller. Overall perfection!

text: You have to keep in mind if you need a second controller or not. I recently got MK11 so i wanted a second controller.  Playing with 1 joycon each is a cool feature but itâ€™s not comfortable. I looked into the cost of another set of joycons and the controller adapter (idk what thatâ€™s called but it comes with the switch originally but not with a second set of joycons) and this would be the less expensive option.I got this as a second controller because i needed one but my main intention was to use it as my main first player controller.Itâ€™s perfect. Super comfortable. Feels like a real controller versus the little joycons. I would recommend this to anyone in need of a second controller but if you only play alone, it might feel a bit expensive. In my experience itâ€™s well worth it.If youâ€™re considering it, just buy it, you wonâ€™t regret it.

title: Works, comfy.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2020
text: This controller doesn't require one to have large hands like the X-Box.I originally bought a "PXN" off brand pro controller for my Switch. Well, surprise, that one ended up with left stick drift after a mandatory Switch firmware update. Factory reset it multiple times and it starts to drift again within a couple minutes. This only happens when paired with the Switch. When paired with my PC or my Pi it works fine.So I bought this, and it works perfectly. It did get drift after a Switch firmware update but Nintendo fixed that one with another firmware update a couple days later. Thanks Nintendo!Anyway, if you want a pro controller and do not get a generic, get the real thing. This is the real thing.

title: Mandatory for switch, amazing battery
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
text: This is best nintendo controller and one of the best controllers around. The battery is freakishly amazing. I don't know why anyone else can't adopt this technology, even ps5 dualsense. Speaking of dualsense, just had one of the triggers on mine go after 8 months. Love that controller but can tell it's going to be problematic. Had my original pro controller for 4 years and no problems at all. I just bought second one of these just for company.

title: Awesome controller, as long as you're willing to pay the price for HD Rumble and Gyro controls.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2017
text: Great controller, its on par with the Xbox 360 controller in terms of comfort in the hand. The face buttons are large, which is great if you've ever had problems with pressing the wrong buttons in times of dire need haha. The triggers feel great and the entire controller sits right in your palms with all the buttons right at the ready for your thumbs. Only downside is the D-pad, it feels great but its not the most accurate, with no pivot point in the middle you can easily press more than one angle accidentally. Altogether great controller, not to mention its compatible with bluetooth!Pros:-Perfect button feel, with large face buttons-Very comfortable-Fingers lay right on the triggers-Analog sticks are catchy and never want to leave the thumbs-Bluetooth compatible!Cons:-Not the best D-pad, it's easy to hit multiple angles with one press accidentally. Easy to avoid over time though.-The triggers are all digital, which isn't necessarily a con but can hinder its virtual console capability-A little expensive. Although you are paying extra for the HD rumble and gyro controls.

title: Awesome to use BUT failure is common!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2018
text: This is a superb controller with a serious weakness! Five stars for the controller, 1 star for durability! The left toggle switch gets glitchy after two plus months or more depending on level of play, and it seems to be common from what I've read. None of the fixes worked for me. For $70 I expect it to last longer even under a lot of play time. Most reviews fault the left toggle.I bought it after I bought my Switch expressly to play The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild. I found the JoyCons awkward for this game. It is a fabulous, sumptuous and gorgeously realized game. However since this started, it has gotten to be more consistent in it's glitch to the 180 position. Link trots along or runs away from monsters, and as soon as I stop him, he does an immediate about face and starts walking off!!! I can't have him walking blithely to his death every time he stops in a dangerous place. I have to keep pushing the toggle back to get him to finally stand still, and it's become ridiculous, so I'm forced to order another if I want to finish the game! He's walked off cliffs, stood up from a crouch to walk away and been peppered with arrows, scared away game, and drawn the attention of enemies all because this left toggle is suddenly massively glitchy. I tried canned air to blow out any dust, but it seems like a part failure. He almost walked of a Divine Beast in the middle of the air!Nintendo needs to get this figured out and fixed, and needs to repair of replace my controller.  I've basically spent well over $400 just to play this game, and I intend to purchase the expansion. C'mon!

title: This is my new favorite controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2019
text: I used to be like pretty much everyone else with controllers: Xbox 360/one/s were the gold standards. However, this is my favorite now. It feels much more solid despite how it looks. Everything is in the same general format but for some reason it's easier for me to use. You can even use it with Steam if your PC has bluetooth!There are only a few issues:Sometimes this does not turn off on its own even after disconnecting this from PCThe triggers are binary; you'll still want to stick with the Xbox controllers for games that require a certain amount of "activation" (e.g. racing games).The A/B and X/Y buttons are swapped (probably for patent reasons or something) so you will have to configure how the controller works on Steam. If you switch back and forth between the Switch and an Xbox controller, it gets VERY confusing.All in all, this is the controller I like to use for Smash, BOTW, and PC gaming.

title: A Beast!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
text: I was extremely hesitant on spending 60 bucks or more on a Nintendo controller. However, after reviewing the knock offs that are not official, or loosely affiliated with Nintendo, I decided to buy a Nintendo licensed controller. This thing rocks! The joy sticks are super durable (so far anyway!) so there is no drifting or buttons that stick. I've been using this for months now, and I will buy this product again when that time comes..

title: Excellent controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2022
text: This is the ideal all video game controllers should be aiming for.

title: top quality gamepad, if a bit ugly
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2018
text: Feels like a quality piece of Nintendo peripheral out of the box.  Links up to the Switch with no issues, with no noticeable intermittency during use in my experience.  The Sony Dual Shock 4 has been my favorite gamepad for a long time, but I'd say this beats it out by a small margin.  The layout is great, and all the buttons and sticks feel very tactile with just the right amount of stiffness.  The rumble that we expect from Nintendo controllers is back as well, and then some.  As for the negatives, in my opinion, the cosmetic design is pretty ugly; it doesn't look like a consumer ready product, and appears more industrial.  But being a "pro" controller [whatever that means], maybe this was the marketing intent.  Additionally, for those Steam users out there, apparently Steam is working on native support for this gamepad, so there is some added value in that respect (hopefully Nintendo doesn't get in the way with that...you know how they are).

title: Itâ€™s good, but Iâ€™m looking for a different controller

(So instead of reading my input, it reads the recoil from the stock bouncing back.)

title: Good everything but bad d-pad

The controller fits well in my hands and while it isn't as full of features like a dualsense, or value orientated like an xbox controller, its definitely Nintendo's best controller since the Gamecube

title: no drifting issues yet, 5 stars

title: Switch Pro definitely an upgrade. Still not perfect, but pretty good.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 10, 2020
text: The Switch Pro Controller works pretty well, but I wish there was a hard-off, as it will turn itself on in travel and if you are using your Switch in handheld mode and someone or something messes with the Pro Controller, it will hijack your game. This also can prematurely drain the battery. It is comfortable to hold on my medium to large sized hands and a bit daintier than the replaceable battery version by the same brand. Charging is convenient with the same cable I would use for the Switch. Can be used plugged in. After a while of use thumb caps tried to pop off. I make sure they are seated well before a session of play.

title: Great controller, not-so-great price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 6, 2018
text: I really do enjoy this controller. It feels great in your hands, and I like the weight of it. It's basically a better-feeling version of the WiiU Pro Controller, for anyone who's used that.  70 dollars for it is way too much though, especially when part of that price tag has to do with it having stuff like 3D rumble. Unfortunately, it's pretty much mandatory if you want to play your Switch locally with friends, or even if you just want to play by yourself on your TV. (The joycons are fine as the tablet's controllers, but they're not great when you disconnect them to play on the TV.)This controller's saving grace is that it connects very easily to a computer, making it great for PC games with full controller support. It would be much more convenient if it was XInput, but oh well.Overall, I'd recommend buying this controller if you have a Switch, especially if you play PC games as well. It isn't the greatest deal in the world, but my friends and I have gotten a lot of use out of it.

title: Comfortable and very Responsive

text: I was one of those people who thought the Joy-Con Grip was enough. This is one of the few times I was happy to be proven wrong. Definitely a great companion if one plays docked most of the time, and an investment that I wish I'd made sooner.

title: High Cost, but You Get What You Pay For

title: Surprisingly Nice Controller

title: Don't Settle for 3rd Party

title: Just buy the Nintendo version.

title: If You Have a Switch And Just Use The Joy-Cons...
