title: Worth it if you are into docked gameplay on the switch.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2019
text: While a bit expensive, this is the nicest controller I have ever owned. The build quality is excellent, and thank goodness Nintendo didn't cheap out and put a stupid micro USB port on this controller. I am really happy I pulled the trigger on this instead of getting a cheaper alternative. While the joycon grip is ok, I think it's worth it to spend $65 to buy this. It comes with a 6 foot USB C to USB A cable so you can charge it with the switch dock. The HD rumble is awesome and so are the motion controls. It has NFC too for amibo but do people even use that feature? So there is lots of tech packed into this hardware and I believe it justifies it's price tag.

title: I like this controller better than their WiiU Pro
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2018
text: I like this controller better than their WiiU Pro. What I donâ€™t like is the price and that in order to use your old WiiU Pro youâ€™ll need a dongle. They should add support for them, they really should. I prefer the shape on the WiiU Pro better but this one actually feels more comfortable to me. They finally offset the analogue joysticks which makes gaming easier. 40hr battery life vs the old at 80hrs is a step back but they use the exact same battery just this one has hd rumble and an nfc reader. 40hrs is still long enough for even a hardcore gamer. You donâ€™t need the joycons to play the switch. I brought my switch screen and this controller to work and played Mario Kart during lunch. Left the joycons at home. I like that the buttons arenâ€™t so tiny like on the joycons. I have average adult hands and the joycons are just too small for me. I canâ€™t use them comfortably. This is the best wireless option without a dongle.

title: Worth it
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on November 30, 2021
text: Comfortable grip. No button stick, Or joystick drift. I bought one, not only because Iâ€™m used to controllers in this style, but also because Iâ€™ve heard from friends that the joycons are notorious for stick drift. I figure I want to save them for when my switch is actually on the go. So the pro controller makes for a great at home addition.

title: Pleasantly Surprised
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 4, 2019
text: I originally bought this controller because I hated how difficult it was to play Super Smash on the regular switch controllers. The sticks are too small, and I feel like that whole controller is better suited for portability and smaller hands.The price of one of these controllers is HALF of what it costs to get a second set of Joycon controllers and a grip, so I was a little worried that it was going to feel cheap and unpleasant to hold. Thankfully, this isn't the case.The controller has a wonderful texture to it, and feels great to hold in your hand. The sticks are smooth, and the triggers are WONDERFULLY tactile, some of the best I've felt on a controller. The buttons are also nice and smooth, and have a silent tactile bump at the bottom. The whole controller feels really great, and very premium. I bought a second one for my wife because she liked it so much.

title: More great Nintendo products for your arsenal.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 6, 2019
text: Bought this so controlling the Switch would be easier, obviously. This works so much better than the Joycons. I like to play Overcooked where itâ€™s really essential that you turn and pivot real fast and with the Joycons, sometimes I just want to smash something because it just will not register at all. This is all fixed with the Pro Controller although I only got one so basically my boyfriend and I have to fight for it.I hate that itâ€™s so expensive but itâ€™s also so â€™necessaryâ€™ so Nintendo just takes all my money and I guess Iâ€™m okay with it. Battery lasts pretty long and charging is easy through USB-C. It also supports Amiibo so I donâ€™t know anything about that. It definitely feels better and is more comfortable as well than the Joycons in the controller shell. Clearly a sales tactic. But itâ€™s working.

title: Switch today!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on November 8, 2021
text: The opposite of con is pro, correct? So the opposite of joy-con must be pro-controller? Using that logic, your hands wonâ€™t cramp up after 20 minutes of pulling weeds because you havenâ€™t played animal crossing in 9 months. This sleek fashioned controller with its offset analog stick (best way to make a controller) feels amazing when you slay calamity Ganon for the 11th and a half times.

title: Expensive accessory but worth it
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 17, 2021
text: Considering I already had multiples joy con controllers this seemed redundant. I had tried the comfort grip where you slide the two joy cons but didnâ€™t really care for it. After a lengthy play of BOTW and Mario Kart decided to go for it. Really glad I did as my adult sized hands donâ€™t feel the fatigue they did before. My oldest daughter started using it over the joy con as well which was unexpected. If your hands get fatigued after awhile Iâ€™d suggest you give this a go as well.

title: REALLY comfortable, Great for serious gamers! TAKE MY MONEY NINTENDO!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 22, 2018
text: I ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT! TAKE MY MONEY, NINTENDO!THE GOOD: Really good bluetooth range, no input interruption while playing the Switch docked from about 10 feet away. Feels great in my hand, and the larger buttons are nice. The D-pad is very responsive and feels as good as the classic D-pads Nintendo has made in the past. Pairing was a cinch and the battery last a long time on one charge.THE BAD: Only bad things I can say about the Pro controller is #1, its expensive! #2, that it's hard to go from the pro back to the joy-cons because the pro feels SO good in your hand. But maybe that's more of a bad for the joy-cons and not the pro, haha.OVERALL: If you are a gamer, you will love the pro controller. The pro will feel much better in an adult hand, but not so big that a child cant use it. My 4 year old uses it all the time too and loves it.

title: Do I really need to say anything?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 30, 2021
text: It's a no brainer.  For consistent quality and all the basics, you can never go wrong with OEM controllers.  I've tried a couple of 3rd party "pro" style controllers but have never been completely happy with their build quality.  Nintendo's Pro Controller is built solid with a legit D-Pad and smooth analog sticks, and it fits in my hands perfectly.  And the USB-C charging cable they provide is surprisingly robust!  Like, seriously heavy duty compared to your average charging cable.  Well done, Nintendo!

title: Works as advertised. Stick to OE Nintendo controllers.

title: It works

title: Now You're Playing with Power!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 16, 2019
text: The Nintendo Switch has quickly become my favorite of the current generation of game consoles. It has such a Nintendo charm to it, that keeps bringing me back for more.That being said, the Switch has one pretty big drawback; Scratch that, two significant drawbacks. Joy-cons one and two.Yeah, they make for a neat party trick (Look ma' they click in on both sides), but when the time comes to actually to sit down and play games with them, they fall short. That's where the Pro Controller steps in.The controller feels great in your hand and the pseudo-transparent look is killer. It reminds me of a semitransparent Gameboy or Nintendo 64. The buttons are great and clicky, the combined d-pad is solid (looking at you joy-cons), and the USB-C port is spectacular, seriously, thank you Nintendo.If you are looking to get more out of your Nintendo switch, then this controller may be for you.

title: Better than Xbox One
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 13, 2021
text: This is a well crafted controller. It legitimately feels better in my hands than the Xbox One controller, and the weight kind of reminds me of an Xbox 360 controller. Inputs work plain and simple, no problems with R1 L1 or whatever they call those buttons, which I could never say for Xbox. My only complaint is the handles look grippy, but sadly they are not with my dry hands. Grab some Okeeffes working hands lotion, and game on

title: Good
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 17, 2022
text: Good controller

title: One of the best controller!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on November 29, 2018
text: At first, I was a little hesitant to buy the Pro Controller (price, obviously) for my Switch, but I caved and bought it from Amazon anyway. Once I received it, holy cow, I was impressed! The buttons, joysticks, and motions are very responsive. The vibrations from the HD rumble is really detailed, unlike anything I've experienced from my past controllers. The battery lasts a long time, I was playing Mario Kart 8 and Odyssey for a few hours every day for a few weeks before I finally had to recharge it. I cannot give you my answer on the NFC touchpoint, because I don't own an Amiibo, yet. The only issue I have is that Nintendo should make the home and capture buttons stand out a little more, so I don't have to keep looking down at my controller when my thumb couldn't find one of them.If you're looking to buy a regular controller for your Switch, I recommend getting the Pro Controller!

title: Worth the price, and it feels pretty nice.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on August 1, 2018
text: The controller is my favorite to use across my switch and PC. The price may be a bit expensive, but the fact it is rechargeable and runs for around 50 hrs on a single charge is well worth it in my opinion. The controller has a good weight and feel that I can play for hours whether it be rocket league, or an adventure game such as Zelda: BoTW. Steam works well with it either hard wired connected or via Bluetooth, allowing you to customize every button to be what you wish.It connects and charges via the same usb-c the switch charges with, and includes a usb -> usb-c cable if you would want to charge it off of the switch dock as well.I've only had one trouble with the device itself, it randomly stopped working/charging one day (approximately 3-4 months after buying it), but after calling Nintendo they happily sent me free shipping labels and repaired it free of charge.

title: Excellent Controller but Too Expensive IMO
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 16, 2017
text: This is a great controller. It has a roughly 40 hour battery life, it is far and away a better experience than using the Joy-cons on the comfort grip or by themselves, and it feels very sturdy and well made. It is very reminiscent of an Xbox controller and I really prefer using it for Zelda while I'm playing on my television.Overall I really like the controller but I just don't see why it is more expensive than a dual shock 4 or Xbox One controller.  Maybe considering the battery last much longer and it has NFC for the Amiibo figures but I just didn't see $70 here. While I can recommend it since it is a great controller and currently is the only option besides the Joy-con controller I can't recommend these scalped and inflated prices that you see while stock is limited. If you can find it for $70 and you really wanted the full controller like I did, then go ahead and get it otherwise it may be worth it to see the other options coming out in the next few months.

title: Missing data cable, but otherwise legit preopened Pro controller.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 16, 2020
text: Bought from Amazon warehouse so the product was preopened and missing the data cable, in exchange for 10% off an already reduced price (under 50 w/tax)Appeared to be a fake at first glance (semi-transparent casing, not entirely see through like my legit pro controller), but the battery inside appeared to be the same, the buttons, sticks, and triggers worked properly, the plus and minus weren't sticking out any further, and the HD rumble was working perfectly (tested with Kirby Star Allies), and it even had the secret message under the stick ("THx2ALLGAMEFANS!)It seems to be a legit controller, just with a fake casing. Will update review if it fails though. Minus one star for now, due to missing data cable.

title: Brand Power is worth it.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 30, 2019
text: I like getting officially licensed Nintendo products when I can, but the price tag on these controllers sort of delayed my initial purchase as I wanted to buy several controllers for playing with my kids or buddies.  When I started playing a game competivley though, I felt like my response wasn't quite there with the Pro A off brand controllers.The look and feel of this controller in your hand is incredible and makes all the difference, I still think the Pro A off brand controllers are great for what they are, and at a 3rd of the cost, but if you want precision and reliable performance, then you want one of these.Also note many of the Pro A variants don't have rumble, or a rechargeable battery depending on which version you buy, this has both and again, I have to gush on the grip, it feels great in the hands.

title: Worth every penny.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 15, 2022
text: Way more comfortable then joy cons. Need for all fighting games and platformers

title: It has a nice, ergonomic feel
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 15, 2018
text: It has a nice, ergonomic feel. My middle, ring, and pinky fingers feel right at home wrapped around the grips, unlike many other controllers for the console.Great stick height and nice buttons, but I wish they were in more of a diamond arrangement, instead of a rhombus.The triggers aren't analog triggers, just glorified buttons. Like, the GameCube had analog triggers, 3 console generations later and we're devolving? Slowing down at a corner in any racing game is no longer a tactic, it's a chore, not to mention the fact that it's less effective.D-pad is awful, do not recommend for fighting games or really any 2-D sidescrollers that take advantage of the diagonal inputs. It's as if the thing doesn't want to make inputs that are in any of the cardinal directions, because it always slides into a diagonal input unless I'm very careful to make sure it just goes in one direction. I literally had to hard-mod my controller just to make games like Celeste and SteamWorld Dig 2 playable.

title: Nintendo replaced it under warranty with a new one.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on December 4, 2017
text: During a couple months of use, the forward sensor for the left thumb stick was failing. Instead of the hero moving at a full walk when the left thumb stick was all the way forward, the hero would move slower as if the left thumb stick was partially forward. After talking to customer support, Nintendo emailed me a shipping label with mailing instructions. 3 days later at Nintendo's expense, I had a new replacement (Nintendo had a contract repair company in the next county over.)The controller feels amazing and may be the best console controller I've ever used. Aside from questionable internal parts quality, my only complaint is the location of the D pad. The left thumb stick and D pad locations should have been swapped. The current D pad location makes it easy for the player to accidentally press diagonal up/right or diagonal up/left, which is the D pad issue people are complaining about. BTW, the controller is $10 more than the MSRP for the PS4 controller, but the PS4 controller does not come with a charge cable.

title: Perfect addition to an already great gaming system.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on October 23, 2019
text: As much as I love my Switch, it is hard to use the controllers while attached to the system. I bought this because I miss the feeling of a full size controller. It was easy to set up and I have not noticed any lag between the controller and the system. This has an amazing battery life as well. I was shocked that I charged it once and then was able to use it all week with about an hour average per play. The battery was still strong every time that I picked this up to play some games. Extra bonus is that the power cord that comes with this controller will also charge the Switch. That is a huge plus for me because it means having to carry less charging cords when I am on the go.

title: Mandatory Purchase For Adults/Gamers
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 18, 2018
text: If you Play games on a regular basis this is a must buy. The Joy Con controllers are outclassed by the Pro controller in every concievable way except for the lack of HD rumble. The fantastic ergonomics will make extended gaming very comfortable and the controller was supported by every game I've played so far (its especially good for shooters). It pairs up even better than the default Joy Cons. It has a good battery life. It has a REAL D-pad and not that nonsense that everyone pretends is a D-pad on the left Joy Con. The analog sticks are also positioned much better than the Joy Cons are when they're connected to either side of the Switch. The triggers aren't the best when compared to the Xbox One and PS4 controllers but that is a nitpick. If you are above the age of 10 and play games as a hobby you NEED this controller. Let your friends and small children play with those Joy Cons.

title: The Bee's Knees
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 16, 2022
text: I found out the hard way to not get a cheap Nintendo controller. It costs a little more but definitely worth it.

title: Itâ€™s a really nice controller. It feels larger than the joycons with ...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 22, 2018
text: Itâ€™s a really nice controller. It feels larger than the joycons with the joycon grip. The buttons on the pro controller feel higher quality and are larger than the joycons which is great for games like Splatoon 2 where the ZL and ZR buttons are used frequently. It takes a while to transition from the joycons to the pro controller if youâ€™re used to the joycons alone, but the pro controller becomes natural to use. I just wish it wasnâ€™t so expensive so I can buy a second pro controller for myself. Other than that, this is a great upgrade from the joycons. It has the same features from the joycons like motion controls, NFC for amiibo, snapshot for photo and video, home button, and rumble. It comes with a charger which you can plug it in to your Nintendo Switch to recharge your pro controller. Overall itâ€™s is a great controller and I hope itâ€™ll last for a very long time.

title: Not for smol hands
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 4, 2021
text: Not great for adults with smol hands. My left thumb has to reach just slightly higher than is comfortable to properly control the joystick. The directional accuracy of the joysticks is also wonky. For games where you want to point the joystick directly left or right, it wonâ€™t always go where you want it to. It does have a nice heavier feel to it and the buttons are very smooth, plus the biggest selling point: the extremely long battery life.

title: The Pro Contoller is top notch.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on August 8, 2017
text: I have two sets of joycons and a pro controller, and I really like the joycons, but if you're trying to decide between a second set and a pro controller, I'd recommend going with the pro controller. The Pro Controller is top notch. It was easy to link up with my switch, and it has become my preferred controller since I started using it. Prior to purchasing this controller I really enjoyed using the joycons with the grip, but this controller feels so much better. It fits perfectly in my hands and has been great for long gaming sessions.The battery life on it is excellent and after you're done using it, you can plug it into the wall and not have to worry about it ever running out of juice. I haven't run into any D-Pad issues that were mentioned in previous reviews, but I will update if I run into those problems. It's a great controller and I'd recommend picking one up if you're in the market for an additional controller.

title: Love
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2021
text: It arrived so nicely, and brand new. Of course, that's what you expect anyways, but I haven't gotten a Nintendo Pro Controller before. It came fully charged and has now become my prime way of gaming.I bought joystick grips to cover, but they were for the Switch light and joycons. So they don't fit the controller, but if you want grips I suggest getting Playstation or Xbox joystick grips, they cover perfectly.

title: sturdy with long lasting charge

I recommend this replacement for anybody who doesn't mind not being able to use the JoyCon feature on the standard Switch controllers.

title: Authentic

title: It's NOT a knockoff!

text: You have to be extremely careful buying these controller these days. There are some crazy good knockoffs out there which include the nintendo branding. title: Buy it.

If youâ€™re looking for a smooth and sleek experience with a controller, this would be your controller. I would go as far as to say that this controller is a necessity when having a switch.

title: The Best Controller for Switch and PC Gaming
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2021
text: This is the ideal controller for the Nintendo Switch. I've been using the combined joy-cons for a couple years now, and once I picked this pro controller up, I realize what I've been missing. The pro is a full-sized and comfortable controller for adult hands. The analogs and buttons have accurate force, although the d-pad is a little stiff. This will connect wirelessly to the Switch and I'm also using it via the included usb to play PC games [Steam supported btw]. This is the only controller worth buying.

title: Expensive, but takes your game to another level
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2018
text: I was torn between buying this Pro controller or another set of Joy Con controllers + grip. The latter was actually more expensive but naturally you could turn the Joy Con into two smaller controllers, accommodating more players. However, I went with the Pro Controller and haven't regretted it since. I use my Switch docked 70% of the time and this controller makes gaming on it perfect. The build quality is superb, the buttons are responsive and it just feels premium. I've been using it for about 20-30 hours so I'll be sure to make an update around the 1 month mark (which is when it seems the left joystick craps out on a lot of these controllers). If you play a lot of solo games docked, get this controller. The Joy Con + grip is definitely serviceable, but take your game up a notch with the pro especially if you play games like Splatoon 2. Highly recommended, so far.

title: Way Better Than What I Had
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2022

title: Excellence that is Nintendo

title: Pretty good controller

title: Great controller to use with other platforms too.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2018
text: This is a nice controller to use with your Switch, but also with a gaming PC.I have it paired currently with my MacBook when I want to stream games to it. The controller is super-easy to pair, and even reports battery status when connected. I love that it uses a USB C port because I can actually use my MacBook's Apple charging cord + brick to charge the controller (just like the Switch itself).Nice build quality, it fits nicely in my hands and has a sturdy weight to it. The triggers are not too soft. The sticks do feel a bit small, but I am comparing them to a DualShock 4. They feel a little light but it does not seem like a problem.I would easily suggest buying one of these. It is a no-brainer if you like to have extra controllers handy, especially if you can get it on sale.

title: Donâ€™t buy bootleg versions

title: Great controller

text: Good build quality, makes playing some games easier than with the standard controllers. The battery, although not as long lasting as a Playstaion controller, is decent enough to allow for a good amount of play before needing to be recharged.  I have had it for a while now and I have not noticed any degrading of the controls or the battery.

title: Save your money! Only has 90 day warranty! Phantom joystick drift started within 7 months!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2022
text: I originally purchased the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller to replace the connectivity issues and phantom joystick drift that started on the original JoyCon's that came with the system 3 years prior. Within 7 months the "Pro" controller has developed the phantom joystick drift. I am a light to medium gamer. This product should not have degenerated this quickly. (Heck, I have OEM N64 controllers that accept the joystick input better!) While connectivity issues are non existent and the larger buttons improve the user experience; that's where the positives end. The product has been rendered useless within 7 months and only comes with a 90 day warranty! If you do a quick google search you can confirm this issue is being reported widely in reviews and forums online. Clearly Nintendo is aware of the problem and is offering less than the 1 year warranty that is the industry standard and substituting an initial high quality product with a subpar repair program. It should be criminalized! (Sounds crazy, but the EU is working on it, and why shouldn't we demand products that last?! It's better for the planet!)Nintendo's does offer a repair program that has the potential to be free, but when I sent the JoyCon's in for repair I ended up with poor quality repairs on the left and a replacement in worse condition than I sent in for the right controller. Why bother using the repair program then? I never thought I'd recommend 3rd party manufacturer over Nintendo OEM. The Nintendo brand has lost all cachet for me :(I wish I could recommend this product, but save your money. You are better off looking for a 3rd party controller with a 1 year warranty. Best of luck and happy gaming!

title: Excellent controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2022
text: Gotten as a gift for my wife to replace her drifting joy cons. So far no issues very easy to connect and use

title: A Must-Have for All Nintendo Switch Owners
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2017
text: The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is a must-have accessory for anyone who owns a Nintendo Switch home console. Although expensive, it's necessary for hardcore gaming while at home, due to the Joy-Con device buttons being too small and primarily designed for handheld use instead. Although it's a step down from the previous generation (the Wii U Pro Controller took 4.5 hours to charge and lasted 80 hours total, while the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller takes 6 hours to charge and only lasts 40 hours total), the Switch Pro Controller does have additional features, like Amiibo support, motion controls and HD rumble. The position of the Control Sticks on the Switch Pro Controller actually brings back memories of the Nintendo GameCube Controller, which was designed in a similar way. Perhaps this is Nintendo's way of bringing back the GameCube fans who left for Sony and Microsoft during the Wii and Wii U eras. In any case, I highly recommend it, especially for games like Zelda, Mario Kart Deluxe and Splatoon.

title: Solid controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2021
text: It is what is says it is. This is the best controller for the Switch. My son and I have gone through about 7-8 controllers. My son abuses it playing Fortnite and likes it -I think. He doesn't like to talk to me while he is playing. He gets mad at me and says "stop distracting me!". Do you think that is normal? Anyway, it is a very solid controller and I expect it to last a long time.

title: Works with Steam too! And Android!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 23, 2020
text: Obviously it works with a Switch. But it also works with Steam, over regular bluetooth. Steam even lets you swap the a/b and x/y buttons to make it like *every other controller* where the bottom button is yes and the right button is no. Not only that, it works with Steam Link on android, which passes the full controls through, meaning you don't need any special configuration on the Android side, the Steam configs work just like they do when you connect it directly. I'm super happy with this setup, it lets me have one controller for all my games, no matter what I'm playing them on.

title: Must have for a Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 26, 2019
text: I tried the xbox 360 controller route with an adapter-- which I loved, but there was lag and dropped connectivity from time to time-- which was hellllllaaaa annoying. i decided to get an actual nintendo controller, and I gotta say I am very happy with it that I got 2 more. The only thing is that the LEFT/RIGHT may sometimes act like UPPER LEFT or UPPER RIGHT.. so playing something like tetris 99, you might accidentally do a hard drop when you didn't mean to. There's a youtube video online that shows you how to fix that by leveling the D-PAD up, haven't tried it yet. Overall it feels good in the hand because those joy-cons are too tiny. Also the officially licensed nintendo ones,  PowerA, those are not rechargeable-- you gotta use batteries. happy I got these, you can just use the USB wires to charge.

title: Better than Joycons
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 29, 2019
text: I know, I know... blasphemy, right?  I am more of a traditional console gamer and I like the solid feel of the Pro controllers.  I have three Pro controllers and three sets of Joycons.  My kids and I choose the Pro controllers over the Joycons almost every time.  Not that the Joycons are bad, but I've found that I have a harder time getting them to sync and they don't feel as solid. The Pro is a nicely designed controller that really feels good in the hand.  Of course, there are certain games that only use the Joycons, but they are few.  The rest of the time our Joycons are paired together to act as full controllers anyways, so... save yourself the money and get a Pro controller.  You won't be sorry.

title: Well built controller

title: Raises the Gaming Experience Especially in Docked Mode
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 29, 2018
text: The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is a game changer (pun intended). I first thought that I loved the Joy Con controllers included with the console more than anything. It wasn't until I got the pro controller as a gift that I found out what I was missing. I fee like I have way more control over my games with the pro controller as opposed to the very small joy con controllers. The battery life on this thing is outstanding. I can play 3-4 game sessions of 4-5 hours each before ever getting a low battery notification, and they charge quickly. If you have not given the pro controller a shot because the price tag being almost as much as a game, I totally get it. I would much rather have a new game over a controller too! Once you have a few games that you play consistently this comes worth getting for sure.

title: Worth Your Money
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 13, 2019
text: This controller is overall highly rated, and with good reason. I'll explain further:Pros:Solid designDecent weightFeels naturalRidiculous battery life (40 hours of play time for a 6-hour charge)It is a much better gaming experience on the television than the dual-con gripVery smooth, precise joysticksDpad is actually practical compared to the joycons designLarge buttonsCons:Rather on the expensive side ($56 at the time of the post, however, it used to be $70)Not suitable for more handheld inclined playersRequires separate charging port (USB, included on the dock)Overall, it is a great controller, and I believe that some will enjoy it. It is a bit pricy, but if you consistently play on your TV and want a great, comfortable, and immersive experience with Smash Ultimate or Breath of the Wild, this is for you.

title: The Best Controller!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 10, 2018
text: As much as I love the joy-cons on the Nintendo Switch I still wanted a conventional controller for playing in docked mode. Do you absolutely have to buy this controller to have an enjoyable experience? No. However, as many have stated you are paying for a quality product that is not only built well but also extremely comfortable! The battery of the controller will last you a very long time. I myself typically don't play more than 2-5 hours at a time due to my hectic schedule but I rarely charge it and I have yet to drain it's battery entirely. If you're on the fence like I was just know that you won't be disappointed with the purchase. A huge thumbs up!

title: The best controller out there right now, and by far the best by Nintendo.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 24, 2018
text: One of the most comfortable controllers I have ever used. It's size is roughly akin to that of an xbox one controller, but without the grooves, which works in its favor. I love the bigger size of the face buttons (XYAB), which i was originally skeptical about. It makes moving your thumb from the right stick very easy and fluid. The actual d-pad is a massive improvement over the joy-con controllers. The bumpers and triggers (L R and ZL ZR) are more or less 1:1 with the joy-cons. It did take me a small amount of time to get used to the position of the +. -, home and share buttons, but it hardly drew away from the overall controller experience. Additionally, you can use this controller for PC gaming via bluetooth if your computer supports it or a micro-usb cable, though you will need the proper drivers (which can be easily found online.).

title: Great for Steam, too!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 22, 2018
text: This controller was a hard sell for me at the price, but especially now that Steam has beta compatibility with this controller, this is my absolute favorite controller to use anytime I need one. The only downside is the reversed Nintendo buttons, which causes tooltips to be backwards after you change the controls to a more American layout. This doesn't seem like it would be an issue, since you don't usually look at tooltips when you know how to play a game, but it manages to have a subconscious influence that leaves me often pressing the wrong buttons for certain games. Steam also has support for the gyro controls, though I cannot vouch for the feature myself.As an aside, if you play Splatoon 2, this controller is the absolute best way to play. Very comfortable for other switch games too, even Super Mario Odyssey, which rewards playing with detached joycons.

title: Excellent for casual gaming NOT for competition.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 7, 2022
text: I give this controller a 3.5/5 at the current price when I am writing this review which is 70 dollars.  I have seen it for 60 dollars at times and at that price I would bump up the score to 4.5/5.  The pros are HD Rumble, extremely long battery life and amiibo compatibility.  The cons are horrible D-pad and a left analogue stick that wears out fairly quickly if you are a competitive Splatoon 2 or Mario Maker 2 player.  Even at 70 dollars I recommend it for casual gaming.  Overall thumbs up.

title: Excellent controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 28, 2020
text: This is a very good controller. Easily tied with the Xbox 360 controller for my personal favorite. The analog sticks are excellent, responsive, but soft. This results in an extremely smooth feeling actuation, which is a common theme for this controller. All the buttons are nice and soft, but firm. Tactility is on point. The controller itself is also a good size for my large hands. USB-C is much appreciated.My one criticism is the translucent plastic used for the faceplate. I get the aesthetic they were going for, but it just reminds me of the dreadful electronic shells of the early 2000s.

title: Excellent controller, not-so-excellent price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 4, 2017
text: This thing is far, far nicer to use than the Joy-Cons that come with the Switch. I have large hands, and the Joy-Cons are really not very pleasant to use, no matter whether used with the grip or not. So I picked this up to play Breath of the Wild with, and let me tell you, it is a world of difference. It's very ergonomic, the buttons and sticks are now a proper size for your fingers and feel good, and the build quality is great. Not great? The price. With both PS4 and XB1 controllers going anywhere from $40-50 at time of writing, this thing is at a minimum $30 more expensive for practically no reason. And as far as I can tell, those controllers technically have more features than this controller does (touchpad, headphone jack, big lights, etc), making the price even more disappointing. But considering it's either Joy-Cons or this, you don't have much of a choice if you want a nicer playing experience.

title: A work-of-art controller with a great feel. It is pricey
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 30, 2017
text: A work-of-art controller with a great feel.  It is pricey, but it feels like an expensive controller, not a cheap controller.  I suppose that's a good thing. The charge it holds is incredible; I didn't know it had amiibo detection capabilities, but that is pretty cool, too.  I also used the C to A cable that comes with it to hook up the switch itself to an external battery pack to add another three hours or so of Zelda play when I was away from the base unit.  I have the xbox One S as well, with those cool white controllers and I love the feel of them, but this is actually a bit of a cut above those.  Like others have mentioned, this is a great controller for playing Zelda on a big screen and also is nice for Mario Kart to add a third player to the mix.  Good job, Nintendo.

title: What's not to like?

text: I've had this product over 6 months now and it's been working great! I originally bought this because my left joy con started displaying joycon drift, making games difficult to enjoy or play. However, it is a lot more convenient than the joy cons, even at this price. The internal battery makes it so I hardly ever have to charge it and the controls are so much smoother than the original joy cons.

title: Comfortable, some minor issues with the computer
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 3, 2019
text: Was exactly what was advertised and works great with the console. One issue I have run into is when using it with any kind of emulator on the computer, the joy stick does not seem to be calibrated correctly. Using the OpenEmu emulator, during many games the character will not go into a full run forwards, and will go ridiculously fast if I pull back making them go in reverse. I do not notice this with the games on the consoles Iâ€™ve played on, so maybe they are able to adjust for the miscalibration while the computer programs just canâ€™t seem to calibrate it totally correctly. My solution has been to switch the controls to the D-pad while playing emulated games. Overall, itâ€™s great though, and much more comfortable than the joy-con controllers that come with the Switch.

title: A dang good controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2017
text: This controller is super comfortable. The analog sticks feel buttery smooth, literally the best feeling analog sticks I've ever used. The slightly larger buttons was a little odd at first but they also have a good feel to them. All the shoulder buttons also have a really great feel to them, all four are digital (you don't need analog triggers as much as you think you do) and the ZL & ZR buttons have an ever so slight give to them, they are easy to reach and comfortable with using either one or two fingers grip style. The gyroscope works really well with Splatoon 2 (global testfire tested).The only thing I can state as a potential weak point (besides my personal preference of top side analog sticks) is that the d-pad is quite firm, and isn't as nice to use as a primary character input as the Wii U Pro Controller's. But it's still better than most other d-pads.

title: wise decision

title: My Favorite Controller Ever

text: Genuinely feels like a premium controller. This is the most comfortable controller I've ever played with. It has a very nice feeling to all of the buttons and a non-slick design. If nothing else, it is worth to pick this controller up to have the option of play if you want a more traditional feeling controller over the more innovative and experimental Joy-Cons. It also has motion controls so you're not missing out on anything using this controller. I would recommend this controller to anyone, "Pro" or not.

title: Nintendo's best controller to date

text: An absolutely comfortable controller, one of the most so from Nintendo that I've used. I have normal sized hands but cannot stand how small the joycons are even attached to the holder. Has a great weight to it, D-pad is well made especially when compared to the joycon option. I especially like the feel of the ZL,ZR buttons, they fit the contour of where your fingers would be perfectly. It's a must for a second controller if needed, but it is my go to pad for playing everything, notably Smash Bros. Ultimate where a normal sized controller is more suited for. I find the joycons to feel extremely cheaply made, also evidenced by the rubber tops coming off after only a few months. Battery life is quite good on it as well, I really have nothing bad to say about it.

title: Wow this is an excellent controller

text: I really wasn't expecting much out of nintendo but it's probably my favorite controller to use. It's great to lean back and play like a normal controller. I love my joy cons to death but every so often you just want something that fits your hand a little better. Also, when playing smash bros ultimate, "tilts" are sooo much easier to pull off with these joysticks versus the joycons. If you're struggling with tilts, this is the way to go controller wise. Though if you want a controller "purely" for smash, maybe the gamecube controller is better. But this is preferable to me as it works with almost every game! The only games it won't work with are games that demand half a joycon like super mario party.

title: Game Changer!!!

title: High price point; worth every dollar.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2017
text: Simply put, this is the finest dedicated console controller that I've had the pleasure of using in my 30 odd years of gaming.It has a 40 hours battery life, responsive rumble, gyro control, perfectly laid out buttons that are the rights size for my slightly large hands, and a tough exterior that allows for hours of comfortable zelda playing.The only bad points are a lack of a headphone jack, digital analog triggers instead of plunger style L2 R2.Finally, the price point might steer people away from the pro and towards the joycons (which are fine controllers however the vertical layout slows switching between the right analog stick and buttons severely), or towards 3rd party controllers that will have to strip features or quality control to get to a lower price; however the 70 dollar price tag doesn't feel inflated, and will likely pay for itself in relaxed hands and years of use..

title: Great for Smash Ultimate and other games!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on December 11, 2018

You can go with either the Gamecube controller or pro controller for this game. I believe that the pro controller does  lose 1 frame with inputs around ~20% of the time. Not even noticeable in normal gameplay, and definitely wouldn't effect any casual smashers! (Google input comparison between the two for better details)For those considering buying this for any other games (Super Mario Odyssey, Breath of the Wild, Rocket League): You can't go wrong with this controller. A gamecube controller would get the same effects MINUS the screenshot and video recording capability, as well as the home button.

title: Worth the investment for TV-players
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 30, 2017
text: If you see yourself playing the Switch primarily at home on the TV, this controller is definitely worth the investment. So far I've used it for LoZ:Breath of the Wild and the Splatoon 2 global testfire, and with both games I have had no problems with any features (gyro aiming, amiibo scanning, triggers, d-pad, control stick, buttons, etc.). The controller is a tad expensive, but since I primarily play on my TV, I already feel like it's worth the money I've spent. Compared to just the joycons, the buttons, sticks, and triggers are much more comfortable, particularly the size of the buttons and the placement of the the sticks. If I had to rank controllers, it would be among the top, or at the very least above the WiiU pro and GameCube controllers. Now I just hope there are many more games coming to the Switch so I can continue to enjoy this great controller for years to come.

title: BAD D-PAD, Fix it Nintendo.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 29, 2017
text: I am on my third controller now and all of them have D-Pad issue. When I press left or right on the D-Pad, I would get up instead of right or left. I've used the Input Test on the System Settings to confirm. Now what happens with the D-Pad is if you hold a direction and then shift or roll your thumb perpendicular to that direction the input changes. It also happens when if I press the a direction off center. The issue is the same for all three controllers, I returned the two previous ones. I have to keep this third controller but I am thinking of returning it, I just can't play with the joycons. They are less precise and the Switch Pro Controller is really great for the Breath of Wild. The Pro controller helped me beat so many Lynels in BotW but it also cause me to die in the game. I would be in the middle of a fight with a Silver Lynel and my sword breaks. I press right on the D-Pad to quickly change to another weapon but I get the runes instead. I press two more times and I get the runes both times. Then I die from its AOE blast. It is very annoying when that happens. I don't have the game Puyo Puyo Tetris yet but people on forums have written that's impossible to play with the Pro's D-Pad. I don't think the majority of the people have noticed this problem or maybe they think that they only pressed the wrong button while playing. I want to love this controller but D-Pad issue is a big deal breaker for me. Could it be bad luck and I just got three bad controllers in row? I read on a forum about other people returning their controllers and still having the same issue with the replacements. Some have sent theirs for repairs and still have the issue. I don't know if I can justify the $70 price tag now with this D-Pad issue.If you have read this review, please test out your controllers in System Settings.Update:4/25/17I just got my replacement for this and it's even worst than the first one I got from Amazon. I also just recieved Puyo Puyo Tetris and it is almost unplayable with this D-Pad. Bricks slam down when I just meant to move right. I will be returning this one also. I will just wait for a third party controller to be available for now.

text: I believe this is an essential to any Switch gamer that spends a lot of time with the console docked. I find it especially useful for Mario tennis aces, or any game where the right control stick is used. I find myself accidentally bumping it and messing up my game on the joy cons. title: Favorite controller

text: I really like these controllers. I prefer them over the Joycons. One warning is that they have a known issue. The joysticks will create dust when you use them, and this dust eventually causes drifting. Mine lasted for over a year with so many hours of gameplay I can't really complain, but I also made sure to keep the dust from getting into the controller. I have heard that some people's controllers start drifting in as little as a month. You can also choose to get metal joysticks, which are easy enough to install. This will prevent the dust issue entirely. I give this product 5 stars based on my personal experience.

title: Update, no longer recommended. FAILED TWICE!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 20, 2018
text: Update: June 15th 2019:I had Nintendo replace the controller that was JUST OUT OF WARRANTY and ended up paying almost 50 dollars, and now the new controller is failing AGAIN, two months out of the new 90 day warranty!  I highly recommend getting a protection plan for this, it would be well worth the money as these controllers are not made well.Update, July 8th 2018:The L2 and the plus button stopped working at the same time. The controller is useless now and is just out of warranty. It was never dropped or thrown once. No longer impressed, and am hesitant to buy any more Nintendo controllers as we've had issues with the joycons too.I am impressed; this is a truly fantastic controller.  It reminds me of the good old original Xbox controller due to it's larger size, joystick layout, and general build, but the button and joystick response is more reminicent of a PS3 controller.  I dig it.I ordered this because my wallet cringed at the thought of paying 80 dollars for a pair of joycons, and I figured I would enjoy playing BOTW on something a bit more substantial.  I have fairly large hands, and this controller feels great!The battery life is stellar as well, I have only had the low batt warning once, and that was after days of play with no charging!  Seriously, this thing must have a beefy lithium in there!  I also love that this uses the same charger (USB-C) as the switch, so you can get by with only one cord.I recently tested the Amiibo function with some self programmed NFC tags I purchased here on Amazon, and it works perfectly!Gripes:I do wish that the rear triggers were located a bit further down as the old Xbox controller were, so I could easily use my middle fingers in concert with my pointer fingers on the front triggers...Oh well, I've grown accustomed to the PS3 controller trigger layout, so I can deal.The plus, minus, cam, and home buttons can be a bit hard to locate if you are unable to look down at the controller, but it only takes some getting used to.  I honestly had more issue getting accustomed to the A button being on the far right...Oh Nintendo, you so silly, the A button goes on the bottom.  Maybe next time 8DAlso, I would prefer the Dpad to be seperated buttons, but it isn't a deal breaker only a personal preference.  It does what it's told.Overall, I highly recommend this chunk of plastic and metal and would stake my reputation on encouraging you to get one too.

title: So much more comfortable to use than the standard Joy-Cons

text: Everything about this controller is a huge improvement over the standard Joy-Cons that come with the Switch.  The controller has a nice heft to it and fits larger hands a lot better than the standard Joy-Cons.  My hands don't cramp up using this controller like they did with the other ones. The vibration feedback is improved as well.  Battery life is great too.If I had any complaints it would be that not all games support the controller, some for more obvious reasons than others.

title: A solid controller for the Nintendo Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2018
text: I was hesitant to buy this controller at first because of the high price compared to 3rd party models. But after receiving it I can understand why.  This is a solid controller.  It weighs more than the joy-cons with the adapter which I was surprised about at first.  But then was immediately comfortable with it and appreciated the weight.  It feels great in the hand, controls are where they should be and you can turn off and on the Switch with it.  Battery life lasts forever, and has rumble features built in.  Something which at first I didn't think I'd need but really enjoy.  Its like the Wavebird was for the GCN.  Completely necessary for most games like Zelda, Warframe, Doom.

title: The DEFINITIVE controller for your switch.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2018
text: If you're even considering to buy a Nintendo Switch, this Pro Controller is essential to enjoying the switch. Firstly, it gives you another method of playing switch games. While the joycons are fine for most games, and even are better in some games (Puyo Puyo Tetris) every other game just feels so much better with the Pro Controller. The sticks are much bigger and comfortable on the Pro Controller, and everything is positioned and slanted in such a way that it feels AMAZING to hold in your hands. Some may complain that the triggers aren't analog, but they feel really nice too and have their own feel that is still great. If you need a second controller, or are looking for a better game to play your games, you NEED this.

title: Quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2022

title: Love the controller

It has good weight, and the feedback feels almost identical to the Switch joy cons (or whatever they are called). Haven't run the battery down yet to see just how long it lasts, but so far, so good.

title: You need it.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2020
text: I've been using the joycons until they drifted. I know nintendo can fix but I don't want something that'll just break in a month after using it so I bought the pro controller.I don't know why it took me so long. I love the weight and the feel in my hands 10000x better than the janky little joycons (even in their holder). 400hrs later and still no drifting so I'm sold. If I had to buy it again I would.

title: This is such a great controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2022

title: Good an Responsive controller

title: Joystick drifting after 1 day

Changed my rating from 1 star to 4 stars. It's weird to me how this was a software issue, but glad it's fixed. :)

title: Expensive but worth the price

title: Great controller... wish the price were a bit lower

title: The best Switch controller.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2019
text: I was going to get an officially licensed PowerA pro controller for like half the price but decided on the real deal. I'm not super worried about those features but I didn't want to need them in the future and come up short.  If I buy a 2nd controller I probably will get the licensed aftermarket one and not spend as much as this thing (which is a little absurd for a controller).

title: Improved Switch gaming experience
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2018
text: Pros:- Feels nice in my large hands.- All black.- Does not require batteries.- Good battery life so far. Lasts almost a week when playing for about 5 hours per day.- Solid weight and construction.- Built in gyro sensors for motion control.- HD rumble.Cons:- Analog sticks should have better grip. I recommend getting caps.- The + and - buttons could be placed better, perhaps further up the controller, and they should be bigger to be easier to press.Other thoughts:- It looks like the X, Y, A, B labels are printed on the buttons, so they could rub off over time, but they have been fine so far.- Wish it came with the Switch.- Worth it in my opinion.Overall score: 4/5, above average.

title: A must-have for the Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2019
text: One thing that held me up from playing our Switch were the terrible controllers that come with it.  For my large hands, they are impossible to use singly, and even when mounted together, the spacing is way off and strange.  With Smash Brothers Ultimate being released in December, these controllers were a necessity. They fit the hands nicely, they are well built, and I feel like I have finer control over any game I play.  Docked one star for the cost. Seriously, Nintendo?  Drop $20 off the cost and I'd give five stars.  One nice feature is that they can be charged with a common USB-C cable, meaning that we no longer have to spend money on proprietary power supplies.

title: The best controller I've ever tried

Battery life is fantastic, Amiibo functionality is flawless, motion controls work without issues, and the rumble is indeed a step above regular rumble on other controllers.The price is high, but so was the other controller's on release, and they have less features.

The sensor doesn't seem to function any differently from the joycon's, but most people seem to prefer aiming in Splatoon with this and I agree. It might just be that the sensor is coming from the center rather than the right joycon. Could also just be the familiarity of holding a more traditional controller making the gyro aiming feel more natural. Either way, I prefer it.

text: This thing is very comfortable. It feels great in my hands, is nice and weighty, and I appreciate the larger buttons. So far, the wireless signal has been flawless, and the battery life is great (at least 30 hours).The one and only downside to this controller is the D-Pad. It's too sensitive. For example, when you press "right", it often activates the up or down directions as well. It makes 2D platformers a bit of a pain, and Tetris 99 is nearly impossible with this D-Pad. title: Pretty good.

text: It's pretty good; feels nice in your hands and most of the buttons feel pretty good, and definitely feels better than the joycons in most regards.My only nitpicks are that the d-pad doesn't work great with rhythm games, and that there's lots of crevices where dirt can get trapped. Otherwise it's perfectly fine; got mine back in January and it's still working fine as of now.

title: Great controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2022
text: Loved this controller. This was definitely better than the joycons for certain games.

title: Way easier on my wrists! Not today, carpal tunnel!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on July 13, 2019
text: I work as a hairstylist, and that alongside doing art and playing video games, it really takes its toll. I buckled down and got a pro controller because I've started seeing some warning signs of carpal tunnel syndrome in my right hand, and this controller. Holy crap. It's awesome. Well worth the money. Splatoon is way easier, Mario kart is way better, and Legend of Zelda is the best experience with this controller. I don't like using the pro controller for Tetris 99 however, the buttons sometimes don't do the right control, so I'll use the joy cons and grip with that game, otherwise this is well worth the money.

title: Best Replacement
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on February 25, 2020
text: My left joystick became unresponsive on my OEM joy-con so I started looking for a replacement. To replace the left joy-con itself cost almost the same as this Pro one so IMO its a no-brainer. This Pro controler has a nice weight to it and feels better in hand than the regular splitable joy-cons. It charges via usb so no need for batteries either. Bottom line is if you need a new controler, need an additional or just want to have the best Pro controller made by Nintendo buy this one.

title: Best controller for smash bros
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 25, 2021
text: The buttons are really light and there's no drift. It's not heavy and pretty easy to connect to the switch. I was also surprised that you could connect it to your computer via bluetooth.

Hopefully they will last a while because at $60 each, they are not inexpensive.

title: Really worthwhile purchase if you're using your Switch in docked mode a lot.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 20, 2018
text: I really like this controller. I found myself using my switch in dock mode a deal more than expected and ended up getting this because the joycons get uncomfortable after a while. It also had the wireless and rumble functionality just like the joycon, something a lot of the 3rd part controllers lack.It also just feels really nice and I can play comfortably for a long time with it. The battery life is amazing, I've had it for a few months now and charged it maybe 3 times after the initial charge.

title: Great controller until..
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 24, 2021
text: This controller was perfect in the beginning. After spending $70 a pop on 3 joy cons, we gave this a shot. Granted, if it were just adults playing with it, it would probably last longer. But for an excited 9 year old who gets pretty intense while playing, the left knob starts it's "sway thing" just like all the others.  I have bought and still own every Nintendo console ever made and I have never had any issues with the old contollers. This is too expensive to have to buy these every few months like the crap xbox controllers we use on a PC.  Now at $50 I'll probably have to get another one anyway, as most of the generic ones aren't working with the amiibos. I'd like to see Nintendo revise the product to last.

title: Great controller

title: A very good controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 21, 2017
text: Nintendo got the design of this controller right. It feels very balanced and comfortable. It has some similarities with the XB360/XB1 controller shape, so if you're used to that, this will feel pretty familiar. Construction quality is very good, too. It doesn't feel cheap. It's worth the money, so long as you're not buying it from some jerk who has spiked the price due to availability issues.I don't know that I'd say this is a must-have for the Switch, because in my opinion the grip for the joycons is pretty good too, but this is definitely much more comfortable. It's not a bad idea to get the pro controller if you're going to be doing a fair bit of gameplay on your TV rather than using the Switch mobile.

title: The $70 Standard Controller from Nintendo
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 1, 2017
text: I like this controller a lot and is a lot more comfortable to use than the grip in most situations. My only problem is the D-Pad as it varies as to how sensitive the D-Pad registers up or down when your pressing left or right from controller to controller (For example, while I play Puyo Puyo Tetris I would "accidentally" quick drop a tetrimino when I just wanted to move to the right). It's like a gamble since there's a chance you'll get a really messed up D-Pad and have to send back or get it "repaired" when this shouldn't be an issue in the first place for a $70 controller. It can also work as a PC controller too if that interests you and are willing to pay $70 for it.

title: I felt like the buttons were too "gummy" but it's actually a ...

You need to try it to understand the difference in "feel". I got these on sale, I think. I'm kind of a cheap-o so I probably wouldn't get these full price...yet I still use it every time I play on my switch. Go get it if you can get a decent discount. It's nintendo so I guess any discount is a decent one.

title: Very disappointing.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on January 16, 2020
text: Very disappointed. I was excited to get this controller that everyone has been praising for being ergonomic and having a long battery life. Here are the problems I found:- The thumb pads are not sticky enough so my thumbs kept sliding around and I had to put a lot of pressure to keep my thumbs on without sliding. This was tiring.- The controller is way too big. I had to uncomfortably wrap my hands around the controller and felt like I was stretching my thumbs to reach the thumb pads. (I have normal sized hands for a man whose 5â€™10â€)- The thumb pads were too tall. This meant I had to stretch my thumbs even further.- The - and + buttons are further from the neutral thumb positions than on the joycons. Making reaching them take slightly longer.- The - and + are barely raised above the controller surface. So, theyâ€™re harder to find tactically. This is something I could probably get used to eventually.- The cherry on top for me was that L and R buttons sometimes donâ€™t register when you push them past their â€œclickingâ€ point. You have to press them just a hair harder for them to register. This meant when I was pressing them quickly in-game, that every few button presses were skipped. I donâ€™t know if this a defect or what but. I donâ€™t like buttons that click but donâ€™t register instantly.So in short, the controller wasnâ€™t ergonomic or comfortable for me. The regular joycons on a controller mount are a million times more ergonomic and comfortable for me.

title: Left Joystick Started Drifting Down After 6 Months
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 3, 2019
text: Unfortunately the left joystick started drifting down after about 6 months. I'm not a pro smash player or anything, so it seems hard to fathom that I used it more intensely than most during that time. I also kept it really clean, regularly wiping off the residue that easily accumulates on this controller while in use with a soft, dry towel.The other sad part is that Nintendo isn't taking de-facto responsibility for this issue. After I contacted them, they informed me that Pro Controllers purchased outside of the console are only under warranty for 3 months. After I insisted that I would not pay any amount of money for a controller they call "Pro" that malfunctioned in 6 months and pointing out the similarities with the class-action joy-con suit, the rep put me on hold to see what he could do. After he returned, he offered me a "one-time" free repair.Considering the potential repair costs, if the controller were to malfunction ($30 is 1/2 the cost of a new controller, not to mention however much shipping would have cost), it's hard for me to recommend this product. The main reason I left this at 2 stars is because I had to be quite forceful when talking to the Nintendo rep on the phone which made the whole experience very sour. Had Nintendo taken responsibility more readily for an already known issue (assuming that whatever is plaguing joy-con is also plaguing my Pro Controller - which I could see given how many fewer Pro Controllers there must be in the wild compared to joy-con) I would have likely given this 3 stars, if not 4.

title: A great conroller

Its battery life is half of most wireless controller from other systems, but I don't personally find it as an issue (you can just connect it though its usb cable and charge it while you play).  A must-have controller if you like to play various games with a standard controller layout or multiplayer titles.

title: Almost perfect

This is one of my favorite controllers. I've enjoyed playing games on my Switch more since picking this up.

Overall, it's a very fantastic controller.However, if you're buying more than one, the price adds up rather dramatically, as they cost $60-$70 each. title: Excellent quality controller!  Very stiff pricing!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 21, 2020
text: Let me start by saying that this is a great controller!  The fit, the feel, the overall quality...they're all top-notch!  But you know that a LARGE company like NINTENDO could do well by pricing their controllers somewhere closer in price to what the little, unknown companies can, even with the superior craftsmanship taken into account.  Either way, Nintendo has us coming and going and that's just all there is to it!

title: Bad D-pad
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2019
text: Overall, this is a pretty good controller. Ergonomic with a good battery life, and easy to set up. It certainly feels far better to use than two Joycons on a "comfort" grip. Unfortunately, the D-pad is poorly designed, and will often input the wrong direction. So I can't recommend this for anything where precision is necessary, like Tetris or NES games, but it's great for games where the D-Pad isn't essential like Smash Bros or Mario Kart. It's just unfortunate that Nintendo would get this wrong when they had this down in 1983. If they would fix this oversight, I'd consider this an excellent controller.

title: A must-have for long gaming sessions on the Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2018
text: A must-have for anyone who intends to seriously play on the Nintendo Switch for hours on end. The joy-cons are an interesting concept and are sometimes fun to use, but ergonomically speaking, they're not the greatest for long gaming sessions. That's where the Pro Controller comes in and saves the day. This is a well-made controller with pretty good haptic feedback. It fits well in the hands, and has good quality buttons and texture. The battery also lasts quite a while, and can be recharged using the included USB-A to USB-C cable, which can be attached to any USB-A port on the Switch's dock, or plugged into an appropriate USB-A wall outlet or adapter.

title: If you plan on using the d-pad, don't get this until they fix the issues!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on December 7, 2017
text: I bought this controller to use when my switch is docked, but unfortunately I had to return it. The controller was generally pretty good, but had in my opinion a fatal flaw: the d-pad.The d-pad is way too sensitive, and judging from many online reviews it seems like a poor design rather than a defect with my specific controller. First of all you can press the entire d-pad down from the middle, which is kind of weird because the d-pads I've seen in the past generally pivot around a center point that does not depress. But the issue is that pressing left/right buttons on the d-pad and applying even the tiniest force in the vertical axis will trigger up/down presses. There are videos of this on youtube which match my experience exactly, leading me to believe this is not just a single instance defect.Aside from that, I also found the analog sticks a little too tall. This may not be a problem for others, but after getting used to the stubby joycon analog sticks it was hard to get used to the tall analog sticks on the pro controller. It wasn't a problem in BOTW, but affected my gameplay in Puyo Puyo Tetris, where I found it hard to be precise with the pro controller. Maybe the sensitivity is a little off here too, since I found myself making a ton of misdrops even though I don't make any with the joycons.To summarize:The d-pad alone ruins this controller, and it seems to be a widespread issue. If you press the d-pad buttons at any angle other than directly head on, prepare to get phantom presses in other directions. Giving 2 stars instead of 1 because of the other redeeming qualities.Pros: - Comfortable size and weight - Comes with a nice quality USB-C cable - Buttons are large and clicky, layout is nice - Build quality is seems solid - Looks niceCons: - Expensive - D-pad is way too sensitive!Shoutout to Amazon for processing my return so quickly, no questions asked. Y'all continue to offer some of the best customer service I've seen.

title: The smallest error during gameplay -- unacceptable. Two units tested.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2021
text: I'm one of those guys who only writes bad reviews, or rarely cares enough to write good ones. I bought one of these, and I think these controllers could be the most comfortable for the switch. There is a problem with the left joystick however where there is slight feedback drift. I found this out while playing pokemon. For the first one, every once in a while when I either pull the stick all the way to the left or all the way up -- and for the second one it was all the way up or all the way right -- the controller would track briefly in the opposite direction after I released the joystick. This would foil attempts to evade pokemon, and interrupted normal navigation of the game at times. This is incredibly stupid. I'm not going to pay for this controller until nintendo fixes their pro controller lineup completely. Completely ridiculous to pay for a controller at the same price as a playstation or xbox controller when the latter almost never have errors at that price point.

Again, my controller is under warranty so I sent it to Nintendo and theyâ€™re fixing it again.Other than that, the controller is great. But this problem makes it unusable. Especially when  controllers for other systems have stood the test of time. For now, I refuse to buy another pro controller. I will seek a third-party option.

title: Must Need Controller for Nintendo Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2021
text: If you have a Nintendo Switch and play it a lot, then you really need this controller. It greatly improves the experience due to improved ergonomics and complete support from Nintendo.

title: A whole new dimension to the Switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2018
text: This controller brings gaming on the Switch to a whole new level. It's comfortable to hold and all the buttons are easy to reach. The Xbox One controller is widely regarded as the pinnacle of gaming controllers, and this Switch controller one is very similar, so it's quite easy to make the transition.One thing that sets the experience apart from using the joy cons is the placmeent of the + and - keys, as they are much easier to each. The shoulder buttons are also much more solid.Highly recommended.

title: This controller is the best you'll get for a switch
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2017
text: This controller is the best you'll get for a switch. It feels very nice in your hand, and looks pretty decent too. I think the buttons are responsive, the sticks feel comparable to the other two big guy's controllers. I wish the console supported analog triggers but for digital triggers these are fine. I prefer the batteries be rechargeable (which these are) as long as they don't lose their ability to hold their charge anytime soon, but so far so good. I wish it were slightly cheaper, but you'll prefer this to the joy cons for sure.

title: Sad you have to purchase; joycons SHOULD work
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
text: We bought two of these now because the regular JOYCONs that come with the system are essentially unusable.  Nintendo will fix them for free but they need to be shipped, time to repair etc.  We even bought JOYCONs a year and a half after getting our Switch and they were still completely defective.  Why NINTENDO continues to put out such inferior hardware is beyond me, especially when it effects 100% of the JOYCONS, and they obviously know about the issue.  These controllers are heavy for the kids but actually function.

title: Solid Controller, although expensive
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2018
text: First of all, I'll have to admit that, although this is a good controller, it's still a bit too expensive compared to what other competitors such as Sony and Microsoft offer.Pros:- Well built- Design, it's semi-transparent, the patterns inside looks cool- Comfort- Good battery life, my battery life never goes below 50% even though I only charge them twice every week (and using it every day)Neutral:- No analog triggers, so far it doesn't bother me at all. I prefer digital triggers personally.Cons:- Price. :/

title: Great Controller!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2018
text: So I was lucky enough to pre-order the Nintendo Switch upon initial announcement. I instantly fell in love with it. Loved the versatility of the "pick up and go" concept, the detachment of the controllers to create the Joy Con Grip, the games! I never thought the Pro Controller was necessary because I had everything I needed with the stock Nintendo Switch equipment...I was wrong. The Pro Controller feels great, works amazing, no lag. I wish I would've bought it sooner. Absolute must buy if you have a Switch.

title: Perfect Switch controller!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2021
text: I can't believe I didn't get this sooner! So much better than the flimsy JoyCons! Comfortable. Good battery life. Makes a real upgrade to the Switch gaming experience.

title: Yaay!Grandkids really like this product !
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2021

title: Everything
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2021
