title: Amazing controller with just one downside
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2018
text: This controller feels really good in my large adult hands, the buttons are large and easy to reach, and the analog sticks are very smooth and solid. The only downside is the D-pad, it's very squishy and you can press all of the buttons at once. And doing diagonal moves/attacks with this controller doesn't feel nice at all, and sometimes the buttons don't input as you wanted. If you're getting this controller just for the D-pad itself I suggest looking for another controller.

title: Great Controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2019
text: Feels Great in my hands, holds battery for a good amount of time. The Charging cord is long enough for me to play while charging if I sit a few feet away from my TV. Also, the controller doesn't have the Ghosting Problem like others do, (Where the analog stick registers that it is being pressed either left or right, so when you are not using the controller, it is moving the camera or your character without any input from you.)

title: Well worth it!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2019
text: I do not like the standard JoyCon controllers with the Switch.  I knew I was going to invest a bunch of hours into Breath of the Wild, so it seemed a no brainer to get a controller that fit my hands better.  It seemed better to go with the name brand in this case and this controller has been worth every penny!  The range is decent, the controller is holding up well, and the fit is perfect!

title: Necessary evil.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2019
text: It's an overpriced  xbox 360/one controller with nintendo slapped on it that has analog sticks that like to get stuck. But if you play your Switch docked you already know how annoying it is to take the joy cons on and off for charging, so you''ll likely break down and purchase this eventually.It does have a long battery life , and the rumble works well. But come on, the regular price is just too high..

title: Nintendo's best controller yet
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2017
text: If you're gonna be playing on the TV with your switch this is almost a must have. Controller feels great in the hand, all the buttons have a nice feel, especially the D-pad which may be my favorite I've used. Price is the only downside at 70 bucks, but it does pack some nice tech in there like HD rumble, and an amiibo reader. You also can't beat the 40 hour rated battery life, as well as the included high quality USB-c to USB-a cable. Going to be getting at least one more once Mario Kart 8 Deluxe comes out for some good multiplayer.

title: Good quality, but expensive.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2017
text: I really like the design of these pro controllers. They have nice button layout and the analog sticks are all responsive and seem pretty durable. The d-pad is pretty iffy but that's nothing new for Nintendo or XBox. I really wish Nintendo would go back to analog triggers, it's the only thing keeping them from being able to put GameCube games on the eShop and there is no reason for them not to at this point. Additionally, these are way too expensive. I really have no idea why they are either.

title: Better gaming experience
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2021
text: Very comfortable. It feels great. Better than the joycons. Definitely improve my gaming experience on the Switch. The battery last a couple of my gaming sessions (I only play a couple hours a day) so that's great.

title: Very Happy Nintendo Brand All the Way
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
text: Works as expected, love the fact it is rechargeable and does not require batteries that have to be switched out once depleted.  It was a breeze to match to the switch. title: Great battery life; bad d-pad.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
text: Mine came with a faulty A button, but I couldn't send it back (bought it in my travel to the US). One of the shoulder buttons had an issue also, but I fixed it myself. But if you are to buy one because of its d-pad, I can't recommend it (too many wrong inputs).

title: Left stick has snapback and squeaks, still works but disappointing for what I paid

title: The Perfect controller

It might be off putting to spend the extra money on a separate controller, but it's worth every penny.

title: Worth the money? Probably not. Good to have? Absolutely!

Button clicks not as satisfying vs joycons as it does not have an actuation "click," where Joycons behave like MX Blue switches and the Pro Controller behaves like a MX Red. If the high price point doesn't faze you, you should definitely get in on this.

title: Better than the side mount controllers

Bottom line: This controller is an amazing piece of hardware of superb quality and fantastic tactile feedback. It is, however, simply too expensive, hence 4 stars vice 5.

title: Works great

title: Simply the best Switch Controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2017
text: This is the perfect controller for playing Switch games on a big TV. It's definitely the most traditional, and most ergonomic of the Switch controllers, and I prefer it to anything else. This controller is a must for gamers with larger hands or looking for more precise inputs, or for longer play sessions; the joy cons make my hands sore after a few hours.Unlike the Wii U pro controller, which felt flimsy and like a toy, this controller has a good weight to it and feels like a much nicer piece of equipment.

title: D-pad is awful, but can be disassembled and improved
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2019
text: Purchased in February 2019.The directional pad wrongly registers key presses. This is all over the internet and it's just poor QA done on the product. I bought a switch and this controller, exclusively to play tetris 99. That's all I play.I found two approaches, online, for improving the functionality and correcting the problem. I chose not to cover up the contacts with tape and instead raise the d-pad height by putting tape underneath the center of the d-pad. I had to remove the tape and reduce the number of layers of tape after it wasn't ideal. I was so glad that it worked better that I played and haven't adjusted the number of layers again, but I'm sure I could fine tune it a little better if I did.Other than that, it is a comfortable controller to hold.3 stars because it should work properly out of the box. Nintendo needs to manufacture a new d-pad.

title: OK I like the controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2017
text: OK I like the controller...did not like the price but that's my bad for choosing to pay that much.I was buying the switch for my husbands 61st Birthday. He never asks for anything for his self.He is not a Gamer...The only gaming he has gotten into is Zelda.We have bought a new console for each Zelda and he's played each and everyone one..I am what my grandsons call a Back Seat Gamer.We enjoy the time we spend together with Zelda!So I chose to pay the extra $35. Hubby Deserves it with out a doubt..

title: Excellent Buy
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2019
text: This controlleris heavy which I can appreciate.  The button input is smooth and quiet--no 'clicking', which I also appreciate.  it has a nice wide frame for my hands and feels comfortable for hours of play.  It takes no effort to recharge and can be used even while charging.  it can even be used while charging from an external source (i.e. not directly connected to the Nintendo Switch).  A must buy for any Switch owner!

title: Super comfortable controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2017
text: Super comfortable controller, probably one of my favorites! The only gripe I have is connecting it. My SO and I each have a Switch, but purchased one of these to share. In order to pair it, you have to briefly plug it into the console you want to connect with. No easy connecting with the shoulder buttons like the Joycons have. Once it's paired though, it stays paired. Battery life is fantastic. I still rate it five stars because the pairing issue is a unique one that most people will never experience. Definitely worth the money!

title: One of the best controllers I've used...until the sticks fail
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2022
text: Bought a Switch around launch, loved it for a while, bought the Pro a year later just to play Splatoon 2. But about 3 years later the sticks on my joycons started to "drift", they got almost unresponsive at times and made my favorite games unplayable.  Then after them came my pro controller which was shocking, didn't think it would happen, tried opening it up like I did to my joycons (which as an average consumer you should never have to do), but to no avail. Makes me reconsider Nintendo as a company that brought value to it's customers, I still have Wii/GC controllers that work perfectly fine, but this is ridiculous. Not even worth the price.

title: Quality Feel

All these things make it uncomfortable to play for long periods of time. Especially if your playing online games, you could find yourself playing for an hour easily.My BIGGEST DISLIKE about this is that there isn't any ON/OFF button. While in a bag a joystick can be moved or a button pressed and it turns on to search for a device KILLING the battery. There's basically no way to put this in a bag to travel with, without your battery being drained.

title: Big improvement over Joy-Cons, but there are two major flaws to know about
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2019
text: I initially bought this controller to play Zelda Breath of the Wild, MarioKart 8, and Fortnite. It was a huge improvement over using the Joy-Cons because of the great ergonomics and the freedom of motion in the analog sticks. The battery also lasts for a VERY long time. My main initial complaint at that point was that it didn't have a headset jack like Xbox and PS4 controllers have, not a huge deal. However, when I started playing Tetris99, I noticed a new flaw that became infuriating: the d-pad doesn't work well. When you push left or right, sometimes it pushes up or down too. In Tetris99, that means you're accidentally doing to do a "hard drop" when you intend to rotate the piece. I stopped using the pro controller with Tetris99 because I was so frustrated with it. Given the price of the controller, I would think that the d-pad would be better.

title: Decent Controller, Some Flaws
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2018
text: It's a good controller, but if this is as good as it gets, the future of racing games on the Switch is almost nonexistent, the two biggest flaws of this controller are the following:-The ridiculously expensive price tag.-Lack of pressure-sensitive trigger buttons. This means there will be no smooth throttle or braking in any future racing games unless you were to make use of the right stick for that purpose.It's worth noting that the overall build and feel of the controller lacks some of the soft touch plastics and rubbers of many modern controllers, Xbox One controllers usually have a pretty soft touch plastic at the grips, and you can custom order one with rubberized grips, the back of the Pro controller looks like it would have rubberized grips, but it is in fact the hardest plastic I've ever held with a controller.

title: Great until it's not
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2019
text: This controller is fantastic at first, but is destined to have problems. Know that if you buy a Pro Controller, chances are, you WILL have problems down the line. It's such a bummer that this is a common issue among Switch owners. I take great care of my things, and my Pro controller has 2 significant problems after about 6 months of use.1) Left stick issues. When pushing the left stick upwards, the controller experiences what I've been calling "reverse drift" -- it pulls the input down. I've calibrated dozens of times, and this fixes the issue momentarily, but it always comes back.2) R-button issues. The R button's input works OK, but only if you push the button down with a bit more force. If you're playing a game that requires holding down the R button (like checking the map on Hollow Knight for example), the button will lose input unless you're really pushing down.This is my 3rd Switch controller to give me issues. I have 2 sets of Joycons that experience joystick problems as well. I love my Switch and am super bummed by their controller issues.It's worth noting that this controller is pretty expensive for the issues it experiences. I've had multiple DualShock 4s for years, with much more playtime on them, with no issues. Same with Gamecube controllers -- some of which I've had since the early 2000s. This is simply unacceptable for a company of Nintendo's stature and a controller of this price. Please Nintendo. Please fix this. Fix your Joycons. Fix your Pro Controller. Thanks.

title: Solid controller, necessity for big hands
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2017
text: No complaints here. Ergonomics are fine, buttons are responsive and reasonably stiff, motion controls work well, solidly built. Minor quibbles are the minus button being hard to get with it's location past the left stick, and the usage of a USB-C connector instead of much more common UBS-micro and mini connectors. It may be expensive but if you're finding the Joy Cons to be small and flimsy, especially if you have larger hands, this will save the day and you'll be glad you spent the money for a legit, serious gaming pad.

title: Useless for Mac gaming
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 30, 2021
text: The build quality on this controller is excellent. If you are buying it for a Switch, or I imagine for Windows gaming, you will probably be pleased.But I bought it for a Mac, and it has been a nightmare to use. In theory it should be simple to just pair over bluetooth, but that rarely works. It either won't connect at all, or if it does it will be with extreme lag, making any remotely action-oriented game unplayable. You can also plug it in directly with USB-C, and this typically works better, though it will still often be totally unresponsive, or not work with certain games.If you are looking for a gaming controller for a Mac, this is not it. Look elsewhere.

title: Great, but only lasts 2 years.Warranty is 90 days. Ridiculously overpriced.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2021
text: The internet is awash with people complaining about "analog stick drift", both with the standard JoyCon controllers (which Nintendo has quietly acknowledged and is repairing for free), and also for this Pro Controller. It seems to not be very durable.Mine worked fine for 2 years of moderate use (I'm a full time business owner so don't have the same time for video games as I did in my teens), after that the left analog stick would randonly act as if it was being held down in games, and in the Switch controller calibration screen. Nintendo support informed me that the repair price would be $50, since the warranty is only 90 days.I don't know about you, but 2 years of use out of an already overpriced controller is not really good going.

The button placement Is very familiar to other consoles and it feels very durable. Buttons are all very clicky and responsive. I would definitely recommend taking a look at this if you own a Switch, it is a must!

title: Bad stick calibration out of the box
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on October 16, 2020
text: I got the controller primarily to play some pc games while also being able to bring it to things such as friends houses or smash tournaments where i cant play in handheld. so I boot up some yakuza 0 and i notice that i cant move my camera with my right stick and when i try to calibrate it and it goes crazy saying that its imputing my sticks without me pressing anything (this is happening both wired and unwired). so i check the calibration on dolphin and it shows me that not only is the calibration slightly off center but it is also not consistent in its directions either. although it works fine on switch (most likely because the switch doesn't read the whole input there is a slight space before you hit the end that it doesnt read.) it is still insanely frustrating that this slight calibration of the controllers makes it unusable for pc games.

title: LOVE This Controller. However, Tetris & Puyo Lovers, Beware...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on November 12, 2018
text: This controller is awesome. It's almost big enough for my ape-sized hands (by far better than anything else out there, comfort-wise) and the battery lasts longer than any other. This thing got me to 100% on BoTW, and I use it for every other game I play. EXCEPT...This controller is trash for Puyo Puyo Tetris, and any other game requiring d-pad precision. Worst d-pad Nintendo has ever made. It's embarrassing. Each of the 4 directions occasionally presses other directions simultaneously. So sometimes I'll want to go left during Tetris, and BOOM- 2 hard drops in a row. Just like that.I've lost many a game to non-formidable undeserving foes due to this junk. Avoid for specific games at all costs. A pleasant side effect - my Tetris error remediation has become excellent.

title: Great controller, until it isn't
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 30, 2019
text: Really comfortable and battery life is great. This is way better for anyone who doesn't have tiny hands. The joy-cons are not very ergonomic and have tiny buttons. This controller sits comfortable in the hands for extended periods and the buttons are easy and comfortable to press.UPDATE: After a year of casual use the left joystick drifts downwards frequently. When I am trying to walk forwards in many games my character randomly stops in place or even walks backwards. I had some drift with the joy-cons after a couple of months, but I ignored it since I just used this controller instead after I got it. I was very happy with this controller at first, but honestly if I have to replace my controller every year it's not worth it. I'll just be getting cheap knock-offs with a similar style or moving back to Xbox or something. I never had controller problems with Xbox controllers, and I didn't even treat those nicely. It's really a shame, since apart from not doing its job it is a good controller in all other aspects. If it were reliable I would recommend this, but honestly I am embarrassed that I have recommended this to anyone in the past. You're basically buying a 1-year subscription to a functional controller. If you buy this, expect to buy a new one before too long.

title: Premium-feeling controller with a terrible D-pad
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2017
text: The controller feels very sturdy, and the grips are nice. It feels like a premium productâ€”although definitely too heavy for long periods of use. The sticks have a rigid feel compared to other controllers. The face buttons are nice and large, which sort of reminds me of a Genesis controller.The huge downside is the D-pad. It is poorly designed, with zero tactile feedback and no tilt-nub in the center (you can literally press the entire D-pad down all at once), resulting in a squishy, vague sense of control. What's worse, many people (including me) have received defective D-pads, where pressing one direction will activate an adjacent direction. Instead of sending mine back for a replacement or repair (because it didn't solve the issue for many others), I opted to open up my controller and fix the issue by placing a small piece of electrical tape over part of the contact that was giving me trouble.For its price, this is a disappointing controller. The D-pad issues are inexcusable at any price point, but I feel that Nintendo should've invested more into the design and quality control if they're asking for this much. Add the fact that the left JoyCon doesn't even have a true D-pad, and it's really unforgivable for Nintendo to get it so wrong on this controller.

title: This makes playing games like Celeste very difficult toward the final levels - not ...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on May 24, 2018
text: This is mostly okay, but doesn't quite fit my expectations for a "pro controller". The buttons are too mushy, and the d-pad is all one piece. This makes playing games like Celeste very difficult toward the final levels - not because of player skill, but because you will often need to switch from left to right on the d-pad. Those kind of switches causes d-pads that aren't separated to hit up/down along the way, and one mis-click can ruin a game.It's nice if you want to casually play switch with a more-conventional controller, but labeling it as "pro controller" is maybe the wrong move here.

title: Yes, it drifts, and No, the d-pad isn't very good.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2020
text: At $70 (I guess they recently lowered the price to $60), this thing really ought to at least operate correctly. I mean, sure, everything on it functions as intended... except the left joystick likes to "drift" and register inputs that aren't being made... even when it isn't in use at all. Lovely.The d-pad is middling at best... there are plenty of better third-party options out there, especially the 8BitDo controllers like the M30. The Pro feels fine and all, but that drift... oh, and the placement of the Home, Capture, +, and - buttons are kind of odd, making it very easy to hit something you didn't intend to. Sure, it has amiibo support which no third-party products can have (and do we reeeeeally care?), but so do the Joy-Cons that came with the system.Overall, a pretty big disappointment considering it's the "official" non-Joy-Con controller. Ended up selling mine and getting an 8BitDo.

You can imagine my surprise and anger when less than a month after I bought this controller, the top left analog stick is drifting. Weirdly, I have barely used this controller and it hasn't seen nearly the abuse my original pro controller has, yet it's already having this problem (none of my joycons drift either, I have 4). This is unacceptable and I would've expected better from Nintendo, especially seeing how I bought it full price brand new. Obviously not a fault on the seller either, just a bad product.

Many online report this issue.I bought a really popular $20 switch controller on here. The joysticks on that one felt a lot smoother to move. title: Controller Works Great.  Amazon has a policy of one controller per account.  Useless.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
text: I bought one of these controllers to test it.  When I went to purchase a second controller for two player games, the Amazon checkout refused to allow me to purchase it.  I received an error message that said I have exceeded my purchase limit.  Amazon customer service informed me that there is a one controller purchase limit.  So....if I want a second controller or the first one quits working, Amazon will not sell me another one.  This makes purchasing from Amazon a waste of my time.  Customer service could not offer a reason for this policy.  It was suggested I use a different Amazon account to bypass this restriction.  I am purchasing from their competitor.  No one controller limit, same price and same day delivery for free.

title: Solid construction, good battery life, poor joystick and d-pad quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2019
text: I really want to like this controller.The good: feels very solid, is comfortable to hold, and battery life is outstanding.  No issues with wireless connection to console (though I usually play wired anyway).The bad: the d-pad is awful and it's way too easy to accidentally activate a diagonal. The joysticks cross the neutral position when releasing them from the edge; if you release the joystick while holding it against the edge, many games will read it as a slight activation in the opposite direction. This is very frustrating in fast-paced games where accurate input is critical.I would much prefer the d-pad style of the joy-cons (four distinct buttons) as well as the joysticks from the joycons over the garbage d-pad and joysticks in this controller.

title: Make sure your seller is Nintendo
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on December 31, 2020
text: This was NOT a brand-new controller.  The box was opened once and then closed back up with a clear circle sticker.  You could still see that the image was lifted off the box from the first time it was opened.  The controller inside has a piece rattling around.The D-pad does whatever it wants.  This is most evident when playing SNES or NES games, where the joystick usually puts you at a disadvantage.  Every press of the D-pad left or right has a 20% chance of reading as a diagonal.I intended this controller to be my new primary while I passed my old controller to my 4-year-old, but this is completely unusable for me.In short, this was not a new controller directly from Nintendo, as the product info led me to believe.

title: Never buying a used product on amazon again!

text: I bought a Switch Controller to replace the one that was stolen from me.It came dirty which was to be expected but the left bumper is completely broken and does not work, the left trigger does not even press in.Considering I payed $52.99, which is close to the price of a new Switch Controller which costs $56.99.This is completely unacceptable.I bought from an Amazon seller called â€œWellness Prioritizedâ€ which has a 97% positive rating over the past 12 months.The description wasâ€œComplete in box with Official Nintendo Pro Controller and original charging cable. Controller has been charged and 100% tested for full functionality.â€They obviously lied when they said it was tested.This should be a lesson to all of you not to buy used on Amazon, this product was even listed with a picture of the controller and it looked completely fine.What I am saying is, you never know what you are going to get and you should be careful regardless of seller rating.

title: Great initial quality, but poor craftsmanship internally
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2017
text: Well I rarely used this thing and it lost charge very fast everytime. They claim you should get 40 hours out of a charge , however, every time I picked the thing up, it was dead. Now, after being out of town for a month, I try to turn it on and it wont even turn on, even while its plugged in.I called Nintendo technical support, and the warranty for this was 3 months. Like I said, I was out of town for a good portion of that and am outside of that 3 month window when I picked it up again and it wouldn't turn on. A repair would be $30 plus $10 shipping plus tax. Needless to say, I'm pissed with the poor craftsmanship. I'm having joy-con issues too, but their warranty is 1 year. Makes no sense to me, this pro controller is in pristine condition. I expect more for my $70, and now I have an expensive paperweight.This is my first Nintendo console, and I will not be buying another one ever.

Tried Mario Kart and the first thing on the screen is to press L and R, right? Still nothing!Tried Test Input Devices, updated the controller, held the buttons for a long time and still to no avail. Im returning this product.Initially checking the product too, it looked like there was a â€œsplatâ€ sticker behind the controller (last owner was a Splatoon player perhaps?) Not sure if they were constantly jamming the buttons. If they knew it wasnt working to begin with, they shouldve fixed it first or contacted nintendo. title: Brand new but completely defective
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2020
text: I personally love the pro controller. However, mine came completely defective straight out of the box. I even bought mine brand new figuring Iâ€™d have less of a chance of getting a defected one. I bought a pro controller about a year ago for a friend and hers works beautifully and hasnâ€™t had any issues since- but mine came with a drifting control pad and half the buttons didnâ€™t work, had severe lag, or didnâ€™t have any response whatsoever. I tried updating the controller but there were no updates for it. I was having issues with my right control paddle that came with the switch console so I got the pro to avoid that, only to get a controller that had more issues right out of the box. Amazing. title: Garbage, just pure garbage
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2018
text: Literally the worst pile of garbage I've ever used. Here's a fun question, what does the PlayStation THREE controller have that's better than this atrocity? For one, the buttons I intended to press actually do what I intended to do. Do you enjoy playing Breath of the Wild, trying to quickly switch to a different weapon and then accidentally opening runes for the millionth time because the D-Pad is such an abomination? If yes, then this is the controller for you. I really hope whoever designed this turd is in a hole somewhere crying, while feeling intense shame from making something so horrible. I genuinely hope sometime in the future Nintendo realized how awful this thing is and puts out a better controller. I've used some truly awful controllers before (Dualshock 3), but this one certainly takes the Cake. What's even more embarrassing is that something so awful didn't come from a 3rd party company like Nyko, which I've also bought some truly terrible controllers from.

title: Ordered and returned three times
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
text: So I've been trying to get a good cheap switch controller for a couple years, and all of the ones I got (including powerA) only lasted around 6 months before issues start appearing. I eventually got fed up with buying new controllers and went all in on a pro controller. When I got to the first one I ordered, the controller felt weighty and obviously high quality. HOWEVER, DAY ONE, not even 5 minutes in, the left stick drifts down. Returned and got a new one. This one drifts down on both sticks. I know this is a great product, but if you want to get one online, be prepared to return it.Edit: got a third one, still drifts right out of the package

title: Great until the left analog stick broke
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2019
text: I bought this last March and all was great. But today the left analog stick broke while playing Mario Tennis. I heard and felt a pop in the left analog stick.Now it will either not recognize down input or the controller gets stuck and keeps the left input pressed. I can hear something broken inside the controller.This is pretty unacceptable for the cost of this  controller. Add the fact that it hasn't gotten nearly as much use as the joy-cons as I mostly play in handheld mode. I'm extremely disappointed in the quality of the build.If these things can't even last a year of moderate use, then you're better off buying a cheaper third-party controller. It's amazing how much more durable my Wii U pro controller has been and still is.I guess Nintendo has quality control issues.

title: Left Analog stick started failing after one month
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2018
text: Worked perfectly for a month. Then about two weeks ago I was playing Splatoon and I noticed that sometimes when I would be trying to run forward my character would instead walk very slowly. It has now gotten to the point where my character will completely halt for a solid 2 seconds before moving again. In Splatoon, this is absolutely game breaking. I've recalibrated and reset the controller a dozen times and nothing has fixed the problem.I couldn't find any option to contact the seller to ask for repair/replacement so I guess I'll have to go through Nintendo themselves. Very disappointed that I paid $70 for a controller that only worked for one month.Seller, if you read this, please contact me to save me the trouble of going through Nintendo support.

title: D-Pad Design is Flawed
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2017
text: I'll get the good parts out of the way, good controller, as should be expected for a $70 pro gamepad from Nintendo.All the rumors you may have heard about the d-pad are 100% true. I didn't believe it at first, that it couldn't possibly be true and must be exaggerated. It is absolutely broken. It's a fundamental design/manufacturing flaw. It is possible to hold down one direction on the d-pad an push it in such a way that you can trigger both adjacent directions. Not only that, but if you really want  to, you can trigger the opposite direction on the d-pad. Nothing short of Nintendo going back to the drawing board on this and offering free fixes/replacements would be satisfactory. Incredibly disappointing. A Nintendo Switch Pro Controller this is NOT!Seriously Nintendo, you've got to fix this.

title: GREAT but HORRIBLE in the same breath.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2020
text: Everything about this controller is GREAT, except ONE important detail... Which is why it gets 1 STAR. (I would put NO STARS if I could) When using this controller, the left directional thumbstick changes direction randomly at the WORST possible moments. It feels like a flaw in the design, where it overshoots from snapback. If you press the thumbstick all the way one direction and then let go, (which happens naturally when I play), it snaps back into position, then overshoots and changes direction. When playing platformer games, (which I'm CrAzY about), this flaw makes the games nearly unplayable. Considering the cost, this is an issue that should NOT exist.Most disappointing.

title: The DPAD is unusable
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2018
text: I bought this to play Celeste (which is an amazing game!!) because the joycons weren't up to the job (the joysticks were mis-calibrated and you can't really use the buttons as a dpad).Unfortunately the dpad is unusable. Every other press goes in the wrong direction. For example, you hang on a wall and press right (into the wall) and the character goes up the wall! So it's registering a diagonal press instead of a horizontal one.I can't return it because I decided to follow an online tutorial to stick tape between some of the contacts. That did improve it but it's still flaky enough to drive me crazy when playing a game as exacting as Celeste.For a $70 controller this is totally unacceptable.

title: Not for competitive gaming
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 4, 2021
text: With a $60 price tag I was expecting the best option for getting an edge in competitive gaming. This was not the case. Expect poor latency, mis-inputs, and average battery life. Just to be clear, if you are considering this as a controller for competitive smash bros, avoid my mistake and get a gamecube variant. It doesn't work all that well for other games either. Also this listing set off my cake review checker pretty hard, Nintendo's been buying reviews most likely. Just do yourself a favor and find a different controller, there are tons of variants that are cheaper, and better.

title: Left joystick not working after light use.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2019
text: I expected this controller to work longer than 6 months. After very light use(I own a ps4, xbox and gaming pc) of the controller, within 6 moths the left joystick stopped working in the up position. I only use the pro controller when playing more than 2 player games like mario cart. I contact amazon support and nintendo support they told me the controller has past the 3 month nintendo accessory warranty, so an exchange is not possible. Nintendo mentioned a $40 dollar repair fee since it is out of warranty. Very disappointed with nintendo because the pro controller is very pricey. Again, I expected this to work longer than 6 months with very light use.

title: Very Disappointing Product for a Premium Price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on April 6, 2017
text: The left analog stick on the unit I received had a permanent drift no matter what I did to calibrate, and during calibration the stick could not reach the 4 directional inputs reliably.The digital triggers were also disappointing, with a lip on the bottom edge that felt like it would eventually catch on something and snap off.The d-pad behaved...oddly.  That is all I can say.  Twenty years of gaming on d-pads and never have I struggled as much to input a single direction.Overall I believe I received a unit with a defective left analog stick, however the issues with the rest of the controller are such that I will be waiting to purchase a Pro Controller for my Switch until a significant design overhaul is made.

title: Got a Defective one
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2020
text: Be careful when you buy a used one for those who want to go cheaper. I bought a "Like New" one, and it came out of the box barely looking acceptable. The overall quality of the controller was very poor, having scratches and tears everywhere. I tried to overlook that and tried to play it on the switch. Sadly, the right analog stick won't even work. I tried to calibrate it but no success. I'm not sure whether to be upset for the company lying about the status of the controller, or how over-priced these controllers are, leading me to end up wanting to buy a used one.

title: Left control stick has infamous "drift" issue
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2020
text: After about a year or two of use, the left control stick began exhibiting the infamous "drift" issue. Even when not touching the control stick, my character would walk slowly to the left in games, making it very hard to control my character precisely in most games. Nintendo told me that since my controller warranty had expired, I would have to either pay them $40 for repairs or just buy a new controller. Considering this is a manufacturing defect, Nintendo should take responsibility and offer everyone affected free repairs like they started doing for the joy-cons which have the same issue.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2018
text: It's a great controller that obviously has a serious defect. This is the second pro controller I've bought that have the same issue. The left joystick (upward control) stops working after a month's worth of play. I primarily use it to play Splatoon 2, which requires the user to use the up joystick motion the majority of the time. It's expensive for a typical controller, but it's worth it because of the motion control; however, as I mentioned, it's got a big defect that definitely needs looking into. I've also researched the internet and other users who play Splatoon are having the same issue.

So it felt as though there was a lag after using the joycons which have as much â€œsmallerâ€ or I guess â€œshorterâ€? Joystick. I would just stick with the joycons that come with the system because at least you don't have to worry about them not working.

title: Never buy used controllers.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2020
text: Didnâ€™t pay attention that the description say â€œused-like newâ€ which isnâ€™t the case. The controller frequently inputs Right on the joystick as if I was holding it down when Iâ€™m not. If this has ever happened to one of your controllers you know it is extremely frustrating & basically makes the controller unusable in most cases. Itâ€™s unfortunate I work overseas in a remote location so I donâ€™t have the luxury of just going to the post office to return this. So I left this review to show my frustration. NEVER BUY USED CONTROLLERS.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on September 14, 2020
text: I have two Pro controllers bought at separate times.  One started disconnecting and reconnecting rapidly, then would lock up and become unresponsive.  It would not shut off (even if forced) until the battery ran out.  Updated firmware, re-sync'd it, did everything the Nintendo support said to do, nothing worked.  They will not exchange, they will just try and repair it for $30 plus shipping for each controller.  So far every controller i have bought for the switch has failed.  Nintendo can't make reliable controllers.

title: Left Stick degrades quickly
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2019
text: As many other 1-star reviews have stated, the left stick degrades and starts to drift after a couple months of play (conveniently just outside of Nintendo's ludicrous 90 day warranty period). The running theory is that bits of plastic from the stick rub off into a white dust and then gets stuck inside, interfering with the sensors. I usually don't recommend off-brand controllers, but when you're spending twice the price on something that'll be worthless in a couple months, how can you not go with the competition instead?

title: The best? Maybe not...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 16, 2019
text: I bought one of these locally at Wal-Mart with my first Nintendo Switch since given away. I am buying another Switch for myself and I'll buy another Pro Controller (on Amazon because they're cheaper than WalMart) but I was looking to see what third party controllers have come out since I last looked.For the most part, I still think this is the best wireless controller for the Nintendo Switch. The only one close to it is the PowerA one. The PowerA wireless controller is very comparable though and has different features that I feel most gamers would use. By this I mean the back customizable buttons and the option to use rechargable batteries instead of needing to charge the controller through USB-C. That being said, I feel more comfortable buying the "Official" one made and sold by Nintendo. Knowing it's made with top notch plastic parts that just feel right and it just works and always should (except the D-PAD sometimes doesn't work right I've heard.)I would fault no-one for choosing the PowerA one over it though. lf you want an improved D-PAD (this is pure opinion) and don't care about losing the rechargeable internal battery and have your own rechargeable batteries then you might want to consider the PowerA. Not having rumble nor the ability to scan Amiibos is not that big of a deal. However, it DOES have motion control and mappable Advanced Gaming Buttons with the two more buttons on the back. More or less it's otherwise identical to this pro controller and 99% of gamers would be satisfied with it in comparison. They have many options to choose from with some nice custom designs some even featuring Zelda or Mario since they are an officially licensed wireless controller through Nintendo. You can get blank design simple colored controllers too if you just prefer something more basic. They range in price from $35 - $49 USD on Amazon currently.There are plenty of wired controllers out there too though -- that run cheaper generally than these two wireless options. Losing the wireless freedom of range and movement is something most are not willing to give up but if you are you might want to think about one of these controllers instead. Honestly you're going to be playing Nintendo Switch games so controllers are not going to matter as much as they would on the other two consoles IMO. Not saying that there isn't competitive action-paced games on the Nintendo Switch but the majority of the top titles that have mulitplayer or that are competitve are turned-based with the few exceptions like Super Smash Bros. Ultimate or something akin to that.One of the new options here is PDP's Faceoff Deluxe+ Audio controllers [ASIN - B07RV6XS6L]. They come with microphone jack built in which lets you plug in and use any headset via the 3.5mm audio jack. I'm not sure how many games on the Nintendo Switch will support in-game audio/USB-chat but this might be the best controller on the Switch if multiplayer is your thing. Of course you can always meet up with your friends and chat on something like Discord too. This controller lets you adjust volume on-the-fly using the D-pad on the controller and also has dual programmable paddle-style buttons on the back similar to what the PowerA offers. They too are officially licensed by Nintendo but currently only come with a couple color choices in the form of interchangeable faceplates. They don't have rumble, gyro motion controllers, or Amiibo support either. And yes they are wired with a 10' cord. That being said they are only $25 so they would make for a great alternative controller if you need more than one for when friends are over.

title: Nintendo Switch Pro Controller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on October 14, 2017
text: The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is very well built, it's comfortable, has some weight to it and has textured grips to keep the controller from slipping out of your hands. There's no creaking or bending of the controller while playing, It's the alternative choice for those who want a more traditional way to play games compared to the Joy-Cons setup with the standard Attachment or Charging Grip. It comes with a USB-C cable and can be charged from the Switch docking station or AC adapter.It's an overall improvement over the Wii U Pro Controller, ditching the odd right joystick placement and moving it below the primary buttons, resembling a Xbox controller. It also has larger trigger buttons up top and larger X, A, Y, B buttons which are certainly welcome but it does still lack the pressure sensitive secondary analog triggers that both the Xbox One and PlayStation 4 controllers have - I personally like having that when it comes to racing games. The analog sticks feel smooth and rise slightly around their circumference to prevent your thumbs from slipping off.  The classic D-pad makes a return again on the Pro-Controller, It's the same size as the d-pad on the Wii and Wii U Pro Controllers. It feels responsive and has the solid quality clicks you've come to expect from Nintendo controllers but I found that in a few instances, I've accidently click one direction when pressing another, thankfully it doesn't happen to me all the time but it could be improved.  The + and - button placements are easier to use compared to the Joy-Con setup and are more in reach this time around compared to the Wii U Pro Controller but I wish the buttons would protrude outward more like the Wii U Pro Controller. While playing and without looking down at the controller, I find myself feeling around the for the + or - buttons because they sit almost flush with the controller face and it makes them somewhat difficult to press. The Screenshot and Home buttons also sit very flush and sometimes I'll accidently end up pressing them instead of the - and + buttons.The battery life is phenomenal, I can't remember the last time I plugged in the Pro Controller to charge it up. It can hold a charge for 40 hours and takes 4-5 hours to fully recharge. The Controller has the advertised "HD Rumble" that's been featured with the Joy-Con controllers. As far as I could tellâ€”with the handful of games I've triedâ€”the rumble feedback functions about the same as it does with the Joy-Cons.  It also has Motion Sensors and built-in Amiibo functionality, you can place the Amiibo figure on top of the switch icon of the controller to scan it.It connects to the Switch via Bluetooth so you can easily use this controller on your home computers or smart phone as well. I've had some trouble getting it to connect on Windows 7 but then I tried Windows 10 and it was as simple as having your PC search for a BT device while holding the sync button on top of the controller for 3 seconds. Once the controller is properly synced, you can use it just like any other Bluetooth controller. Initially, I had some issues getting the Pro Controller to connect to my Switch but since then, it's been connecting every single time, one push of the Home Button and it takes 2 seconds.Just like the Joy-Cons, the bottom of the Pro Controller has four LEDs that represent which player it's set to(starting from the left) and if it's properly connected to the system. It is a pricey controller, at this point it cost $69 and that makes it a good $15-20 more expensive then it's competitors. It currently does not have a headphone/mic jack.Comfort wise, It could possibly be the most comfortable controller out there. Sometimes I even forget I'm still holding it when gaming for a while.  If you own a Nintendo Switch and want a more traditional way to play your games that provides a proper d-pad, larger primary buttons, ergonomic shoulder buttons, extremely long battery life and is very comfortable to hold..  the Switch Pro Controller is certainly a step-up from your Joy-Cons.

title: An (almost) perfect controller for Nintendo's latest innovation.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on March 17, 2019
text: FULL DISCLOSURE: I paid for this with my own funds and am giving solely my opinions in this review.I have had this controller since I got my Switch in Dec 2017 and have used it extensively since. I have played upwards of 60 hours of Mario Kart and 25 hours of Rocket League as well as my other games almost exclusively with this controller and can say that it is without a doubt responsive, comfortable, and worth every cent. I also happened to snag it for $60 on Prime day back then as a plus, making my purchase that much more satisfactory.In my time in gaming I have used numerous controllers and know what I love and hate. I like the Xbox One S controller for its ergonomics, excellent triggers, and premium build and strongly dislike the DualShock 4 for its unergonomic feel, mushy face buttons and symmetric analog sticks. However, on my ranking of favorite controllers the Switch Pro is now tied in first place with the GameCube controller (only because of childhood nostalgia).(Mostly) every feature of the Switch Pro is better than any other controller I have used, including the XBone S controller. The analog sticks have the perfect amount of resistance. The face buttons are large and have great actuation. The motion controls are some of Nintendo's best efforts in that method of control. The battery life is quite impressive, beating out both the Xbox and PS controllers by a significant margin. The icing on the charging cake is the USB-C compatibility which is so much better than micro-USB. The shoulder buttons are all a short pull and feel incredibly responsive.However, after extensive use of the Switch Pro, I have run into a few gripes that I hope Nintendo improves on in the future. First, the d-pad. It is, like others have noted, inaccurate and very fiddly feeling. It moves around much too easily and can be pressed all at once like a button. Given Nintendo's history with the d-pad, this is surprising.Second, lack of analog triggers is glaring, on this and the Joy-Cons, given that Nintendo was one of the first to implement analog triggers in their controllers. For racing games, this will be sorely missed.Third, the overall construction of the controller feels less premium and more plasticky despite the high price when compared to my Sport White Xbox One S controller which MSRP's for the same price. It's definitely weighty, but slightly cheaper feeling.Lastly, maybe this is just me, but my HD Rumble seems to have worn out somewhat and seems more like a mild grinding sound now instead of the revving engine I first felt in Mario Kart when I got my Switch. After using my XBone S controller which revs like a lawnmower, I really started to wish I had a similar feel on my Switch Pro. This deterioration appears to be a common issue with most of the Switch's controllers, with Joy-Cons wearing out in a year's time.But, even with the cons that are there currently, I still recommend this controller for those who use their Switch in docked mode for at least half of the time. If you're a mostly portable player, then I'm hard pressed to tell you to go out and buy one of these. If you're like me and you play docked a lot, then you NEED this. I'm telling you! You NEED this! It absolutely stands among the best of the current gen controllers.

title: Overpriced, nothing Pro about it
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on December 9, 2017
text: This controller is essential if you want to game on the Switch. Not only does it feel great in the hand, the offset joysticks (like the Xbox) are a welcome change from the Wii U controller. However, I've never been sold on the reversed XY and AB placement that Nintendo chooses to use on its controllers. I'd prefer if I could change the order of these buttons. I prefer the layout on the PS4 and Xbox controllers and I'd like to put this same layout onto the Nintendo controller.After switching from the Xbox One or PS4, I am forever finding I press B instead of A or Y instead of X. It always takes me at least a week or so to get back into the Nintendo layout. Sometimes I just forget and press the wrong button. This is a real problem that Nintendo refuses to address. For any gamer who's used the Xbox or PS4 for long enough, moving to a Nintendo is a very frustrating experience. If you're going to give us a Pro controller, let us swap the AB and XY placement to match the Xbox or PS4. This is supposed to be a Pro controller, right?The biggest problem is the ease with which this controller connects to the Switch. With the PS4 and Xbox One, you have to press the PS or X button explicitly to get the controller to connect. Unfortunately, Nintendo designed this controller to connect on any button press (including the shoulder buttons). This means that if the controller gets lost under something, you can find that controller randomly connects to the Switch, begins controlling the unit and moving the cursor (much to your displeasure). Thankfully, Nintendo includes a 'Find My Controller' feature by running the rumble on the controller. So, it's relatively easy to find the controller (as long as it still carries a charge). However, finding the controller easily doesn't help much when you're fighting against that same random controller which is now connected and continually moving your cursor.The controller includes a 60 inch (5 foot) long USB-C charging cable. You can never have enough well made USB-C charging cables. Unfortunately, it's not quite long enough to be useful as a wired controller unless you sit close to the Switch. I prefer the 10-12 foot cables that let you game using a cable. Again, this is a miss by Nintendo. Make the cable longer.The battery in this controller lasts a long time. Besides the random connect issue, the NFC reader is easily the weakest part of this controller. It can be difficult to find the location of the NFC reader location and when you do, the Amiibo has to be touching the controller perfectly. The NFC reader has a very weak reader signal and will sometimes fail to read an Amiibo entirely. Because of this, I don't necessarily trust writing often to my Amiibos for fear of corruption. I'd prefer if Nintendo would decouple this feature from the controller and offer us a separate standalone reader where we can leave the Amiibo on the pad. Just take it off of the controller if you can't really make it work well. Note that the NFC reader on this controller does work marginally better than the reader on the JoyCons, which actually offer no solid place for the Amiibo to touch.At $69, it is overpriced for a controller with its features. The price for this controller should be no more than $49. It's definitely overpriced. Though, I will say that the wireless connection from the Pro Controller to the Switch is rock stable. I've never once had the connection drop even at a reasonable distance away (10-12 feet), unlike the JoyCons which seem to have frequent disconnection problems no matter the distance. Unfortunately, this controller cannot be used like the JoyCons. If you have a game that needs to use the hand pointer control (like the Wiimote), you're stuck using the JoyCons or you'll need to pick up the Switch and use the touch screen.Overall, it's a decent controller, but it doesn't deserve the 'Pro' moniker. It really does not offer 'Pro' features in any real sense. You can't reprogram buttons, you can't change the joystick tops, you can't plug headphones into it, it has no expansion slot and there aren't any rear paddles. In short, it's a standard controller labeled as 'Pro' in an attempt to command the overpriced $69 price tag. However, this controller is still leaps and bounds better than the unreliable JoyCons.

text: Overall this is an excellent controller that looks and performs as great as you would hope. The only catch is that for me, the value does not match the MSRP pricing.PROS: - It's a dream in the hand - super comfortable and big chunky buttons for players with large hands.- The build quality is epic, everything just feels solid. It is definitely more premium feeling, although not as premium as an xbox elite.-  The analog stick height feels very nice and they are super responsive.- Easy USB C charging and easy wireless sync to the console- It is black and looks very cool.CONS:- It feels like they took the same vibration motors out of the joycons and stuck them in this thing which is much bigger, so the vibrations are still accurate but feel less intense and less dynamic - more muted.- L2/R2 triggers are short throw distance and feel cheap compared to xbox/playstation controllers.- The price is way too high. The price to value ratio is simply not here. This is a great controller, but the fact that it outprices an xbox controller is a crime.

title: Almost perfect - 9/10
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on June 19, 2020
text: The controller feels fantastic in your hands.  This is especially apparent after trying to use the tiny joycons with their even tinier buttons and joysticks.  If your an adult with moderate to large hands you need this controller.  Playing games like Resident Evil 5 or Doom feel worlds better with a controller that is designed for hands larger than a 10 year old's.  Using the controller mount for the joycons is not a substitute for a pro controller.  After using the pro controller, you realize that the joycon's tiny buttons, joysticks, and shoulder buttons are things you tolerate.  Even if you decide against buying this controller (most likely due to the price), buy a cheaper third party traditional controller.  Comfort - 10/10The buttons are large, which I love, reminding more of the larger buttons seen on the original SNES controller.  The buttons along with the D-pad have a matte finish that feel great.  A special mention of the D-pad must be made.  This D-pad feels fantastic.  Compared to the 8bitdo SN30 pro, it is NO CONTEST.  The D-pad for Nintendo's pro controller is top of the line and blows the third party D-pads out of the water.  The Joysticks feel good, maybe even great.  They have raised edges with ridges for increased grip which feel good on your thumbs.  I still prefer the concave shape of the Xbox One joysticks but the switch pro controller joysticks are comfortable, responsive, and accurate.  Compared to the Wii U pro controller, the joysticks feel less sturdy though.  The Wii U pro controller feel sturdy and require more effort to move them, which I like.  This is not a big deal but I feel some may not like joysticks that have less resistance. Buttons and Joysticks - 9/10When it come to the value, the switch pro controller is a sea of grey.  It really depends on the value you place on each individual feature found in the pro controller.  The third party enhanced switch controllers are around 20$ cheaper and feel close to the same but lack many of the features the pro controller has (it doesn't even have basic rumble).  You can also find even cheaper controllers that don't have even the most basic features of a pro controller but are still fine controllers if all your looking for is a comfortable gaming experience for your hands.  I like the HD rumble and motion controls and would like to have the convenience of amiibo support (even though I don't really see it lasting much longer) so I don't mind paying the 70$.  Nintendo's controllers are also known for lasting forever, so you most likely won't need to buy another one for the rest of your life (I still use the gamecube and Wii U pro controllers I got at the launches).  Overall Value - 8/10

title: Disappointment!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2021
text: This is utterly poor quality. I paid roughly $60 for a used- excellent condition controller and they send this poor quality controller in its place. I would like to request a refund or another controller if possible. Very disappointed!

title: DOA

text: Would not charge on arrival but connects to the console and works when plugged in. This is apparently a somewhat common issue. Unable to return. Hoping Nintendo can fix the issue.

title: Like new?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2020
text: First of all the fact that this wasn't new, was a surprise to me.  Second the box is badly taped together.  The price was the same as a new one.  What game are they playing here.  Will return and look for a new one.

title: After 5 months of use, Buttons failing
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2020
text: After 5 months of use, the D-pad is giving false upward pushes.This is obviously after the 3 months that Nintendo warrants this product. Typical.The analog D-pads are fine ironically - no drift - it's the one I don't use that often that had an issue.

title: Left Stick Drifting
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2020
text: Experiencing drift in left stick after roughly a year and a half of use. Already tried to clean, but still not working. Nintendo said I could either pay 40 bucks to fix or buy a new one. Would not recommend unfortunately, as I love this controller otherwise.

title: drift
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2020
text: This controller was great until just outside the warranty window when both sticks started to experience drift.  Calibration did not fix the issue and cleaning the sticks was only a temporary fix.  A controller this expensive should not have this issue.
